We don't care about the characters or their sub-plots, we only care about good old Godzilla who happens to have minimal on-screen time and never manages to make a decent appearance.The important situation is that the movie is visually stunning and is held by memorable sequences (the eye for example). Plus there were many interesting things behind the movie: the MTV support that always helps a movie to be successful, the Puff Daddy "Come With Me" song (poor Jimmy Page), and of course the monster itself.I would only recommend this movie if it airs on Sunday morning or when you don't have anything else to do. Overall, a mediocre disaster or monster movie that didn't have economic success because it never defined where it tried to go.

I don't understand why so many people think this movie is terrible. I love it. Granted it is a big difference from the original Godzilla legend, but still. It's not meant to be that realistic anyway. I love this movie, I really do. It's funny and I love Matthew Broderick. This movie is about Godzilla. A big lizard, basically. After atomic bomb tests in the South Pacific, Godzilla makes it's way through the Panama Canal. They call a scientist in, Niko Tatopolous, to help investigate what the creature is. They figure that the giant lizard was created by the atomic bomb testing. Who knew? Godzilla makes its way to New York City where he destroys the city. Everyone, including the combined U.S. military, must come together to try and figure out a way to eliminate the unusually large reptile.Overall, I give this movie a 7 out of 10: Great.

This is a very good movie. But the name "Godzilla" should have never been attached to it. As a monster flick it is quite good. But this is NOT the Godzilla I love.I'm going to try to be fair here. I LOVE the hokey old campy "Godzilla" monster movies of the 50's and the 60's...the 70's and the 80's even. And the idea of Godzilla being an irradiated iguana is preposterous. That not withstanding, this is still a good production; highly entertaining; and creatively directed, enacted and presented.Matthew Broderick is wonderful in his role as Dr. Niko "The Worm Guy" Tatopoulos (Project X, Ferris Beuler's Day Off, Election, etc). I've never been much of a fan of his work because I've never been able to identify with his characters. And I thought he REEKED in "Inspector Gadget," but to his credit, that was more the fault of the direction and a really stupid script, than his.Maria Pitillo (Olivia Honey of Roseanne Barr's "She-Devil") demonstrated her best talents in my opinion; the best of her career. (For my review of She-Devil, please click my name and then click the corresponding link.) After a long string of obscure titles, this vehicle gave her a chance to show her true abilities. Her portrayal of Audrey Timmonds is open and appears genuine. She makes you care what happens to her character. That is the start of a good performance. But she never loses that open quality which makes you feel as if you know the character as a person. That is the mark of a great performance; such as the one with which she presents to the viewer in this production.Although the scene in which Dr. Tatopolous finds himself standing inside the footprint of Godzilla was directly ripped off from the '76 remake of "King Kong," the rest of the movie was quite creatively done; written, directed, filmed and presented. I had a lot of fun with this movie, by ignoring the constant references to Godzilla, itself. The "monster" featured in this film is NOT Godzilla, but rather some "Jurassic Park" rip-off of Godzilla. I can enjoy the movie for what it is, rather than what it is supposed to be. What it is supposed to be is a modernized remake of a classic monster/horror movie. What it is, is a top quality monster movie which bears NO resemblance whatsoever to the original.PLOT: "Godzilla" is a colossal irradiated iguana who has come to NYC. The US Army, Corps of Engineers, and a band of French nationals know that "Godzilla" has found a home in the sewers of NYC, but have no idea where. After bombing and blowing up several buildings (the Chrysler Building, for one..."Negative impact?! That's the Chrysler Building we're talking about here!" Mayor of New York City), they finally decide to listen to their hi-jacked expert, Dr. Nico Tatopoulos, and allow him to bait the monster to lure it out into the open. Well, that works, but not as planned. (Do their plans EVER work right? lol) So now, Dr. Tatopoulos, his ex girlfriend (a would-be reporter), and the leader of the French Secret Service unit sent here to monitor and intervene in the capture of the monster, must go down into the sewers to find this elusive terror. Dr. Tatopoulos determines through scientific methodologies and just good old fashioned horse sense, that the monster is in NYC to find a breeding ground for his/its(?) brood of world-dominating spawn. It seems that it reproduces asexually and therefore needs no mate. "What's the fun in that?" Audrey Timmonds. But when they discover that our little "friend" has not only been busy, but very Very busy, in its egg-laying capacity, no one will listen to Nico's insistent pleadings to destroy the building in which the eggs reside, and it is up to our hero to save the day.Excellent monster movie, if you can just ignore the obvious and constant "Godzilla" references. Horrid, atrocious, blasphemy of a remake in the field of "Godzilla" movies.As a Godzilla movie, it rates a 1.2/10.As a monster movie, it rates an 8.9/10 from...the Fiend :.

Review title: Who said that this is a bad movie ?!
Review_body: After a recommendation from a friend, I went to watch it on 11 / 8 / 1998. The theater's huge screen was replaced by a multiplex. I convinced myself to endure one of the new, very small, screens. Then, I sat at the last raw, which is something I regretted, since I discovered that the ancient, almost tumbledown, projection was on in a room right beside me, and what an appalling noise it was producing!Though, I savored this movie to the max. It's utterly fun. It has wonderful action sequences (the taxi's chase is epic), lovely comic atmosphere, non-stop thrill (the eggs' sequence still blows my mind), sedate editing, splendid music and impressive special effects. Maybe it missed more bankable stars, but the movie's cast managed to do well. Nobody was bad in any way. The team of rescue at the end was so funny and impeccable. Jean Reno, in specific, stole the show with memorable wit and charisma. The side characters were funny and interesting too. And I loved a line: "Time changes. / Some people don't!" which is so rare to happen in a disaster movie!It's, as a whole, an expensive comics, done so rightly. If something was possibly bad; then it could be about how the monster was kind when it came to killing. But this is PG-13 after all, and for my taste I love the no bloody movies. So you can predict my surprise when I heard after the viewing that the movie was hated in its homeland, cursed by critics, and nominated for 5 Razzie awards!!!That was a shock. Especially when I knew that it already made good deal of money, locally and internationally! I asked myself: were all the viewers in America drunk?! Maybe it's different than the original Asian Godzilla? Maybe they didn't like Matthew Broderick in an action? Or maybe they needed any laughingstock of a movie for that year?It won the Worst Supporting Actress, and the Worst Remake or Sequel. While feeling a massive rage, since the lovely Maria Pitillo wasn't close to "awful" or "not good" in no case, and the poor thing didn't get to be in movies again, I feel more rage when many perfectly Razzie material in 1998 didn't even get nominated under any category. Remember these and weep: Free Money, The Godson, Senseless, Hurlyburly, Crazy Six, Krippendorf's Tribe, I Still Know What You Did Last Summer, Phoenix, The General, The Naked Man, and yes The Thin Red Line. Actually, with that, unfairness hits a super level!Roger Ebert smashed the movie (he was parodied somehow through the character of the mayor). He saw it as bad disaster movie, giving it the famous thumb down, while - in 1999 - he gave something named (Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace), a positive review?? AHHHHHHHHHH!!! The lesson to be learned here is: while searching for a laughingstock, some reviewers turn into one themselves!I give Godzilla A-Plus as huge B entertainment. It will go down in history as one of the most wronged movies ever. Enough to say that it made me forget the projection's appalling noise one time, and makes me forget the critics' more appalling stupidity every time.

Many Godzilla purists rejected this CGI-based reinterpretation of the story (#23 in the series) but it is not a bad kaiju outing in its own right. The Toho release (Godzilla vs. Destoroyah, 1995) preceding Emmerich's version continued the trend toward improbable monsters, new-age subplots, and self-righteous greenery and I found the US version to be a refreshing return to the original concept: humanity vs. a single, destructive monster born of radiation. Typical of Emmerich's unsubtle style, everything is very big (Godzilla) or very numerous (e.g. helicopters) and the human drama of the 1954 original, which treats the monster's destructive rampage more as a tragedy than an adventure, is replaced by light-weight shtick, primarily revolving around the Roger Ebert-lookalike mayor (apparently an Emmerich in-joke). Godzilla itself is (IMO) quite well done with a very different look from the original (reflecting 'iguana' rather than 'dinosaur' origins) and the production has fun with the sheer scale of the monster. The opening credit scenes, which establish Godzilla's genesis, are extremely good and the film builds well from there to the arrival of the monster on the shores of Manhattan Island. The cast is fine: Mathew Broderick's playing the scientist who seems to always guess correctly and Maria Pitillo and Hank Azaria as intrepid reporters (both tropes familiar to anyone who has watched the Japanese films). Jean Reno is great as the French secret-service agent trying to ensure that the role France's nuclear tests in creating the current disaster remains unknown and he (and his team) have best lines in the film, riffing on both Gallic unflappability and the challenges of running a clandestine operation in America. Within the context of the film, a general plausibility is maintained (other than reconciling Godzilla's size and its ability to fit in the New York subway system) until the 'third act', an overdone and ridiculous chase scene that is by far the weakest part of the film. Future Japanese entries in the Godzilla franchise make the occasional amusing dig at Emmerich's fish-eating version of the iconic kaiju, but overall, I thought that the film (the 23 outing for the big guy) was was a worthy effort at 'Americanising' Toho's famous monster and liked the film more than most viewers (based on IMDB) and certainly more than most Godzilla-philes.

This movie could have been good. It could have had a real Godzilla in it with the budget and realism seen only in a good Hollywood movie. But no, for some reason the producers decided to blow up an iguana to Godzilla size and call it Godzilla. Why they did this is just beyond anybody's comprehension. But I guess same thing did happen to Catwoman, and few other icons that made a translation from other medium to the big screen. But this was especially bad because it was a big screen to big screen translation.Godzilla is supposed to be invincible. Not die with mere missile fires from F-16. Such weakling does not deserve to be called Godzilla even if it looked like Godzilla (which in this case didn't).Casting was (uh) bad. Story was confusing with so many characters crossing paths but didn't contribute in making the plot better. This includes the baby monster iguanas too.I'd like to see the real Hollywood Godzilla. Done like the "Last Samurai" which would make the original pale. Anyone up for the challenge ?

I've been a huge fan of Godzilla since as far back as I can remember.  I remember that every Saturday I would go to the Blockbuster Video and rent "Godzilla vs. Gigan" or otherwise known as "Godzilla on Monster Island". It was my favorite Godzilla movie for numerous reasons.  Along side that, I also rented "Godzilla vs. Mechagodzilla", "Terror of Mechagodzilla", "Godzilla 1985", and "Godzilla vs. Biollante".  After that, as the Internet was growing increasing popular and easier to use (this was just about four years ago), I would often go to different web sites and basically catalog anything I could get about Godzilla and every single other monster that the "Big Guy" has ever been affiliated with.  Then, during one of my usual cataloging sessions, I somehow came across an advertisement for the new Americanized version of "Godzilla".  I automatically knew that this was going to be good.  I also knew that since this was coming from Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin whose two previous films "Universal Soldier" and "Independence Day" I was a fan of.  The movie was also going to star Matthew Broderick, who I had been a very big fan of since "Ferris Bueller's Day Off".  Anyway, I eagerly waited for that special day (May 19, 1998) to come. Finally, the big day came and I went to see it.  Boy I was blown away by this masterpiece.  It had everything I expected from it: action, more action, and the brand new "Godzilla".  I came out of that movie theater a very proud customer.  During this films run at the movie theaters, I saw "Godzilla" a total of six times, each time getting better and better. Also during this time, I grabbed up every single piece of literature about the movie as I could get as well as the films soundtrack, which featured music from P. Diddy (who people need to just back up off of) and The Wallflowers. I even bought the action figures (only the Godzilla and his offspring, forgot the human action figures).  Then I patiently waited for the VHS to be released.  That day came and I got the VHS.  It was just as good as it was in the theater.But that was then (1998) and this is now (2002).  That is four long years and believe me, a lot happened during this timeI've recently and very carefully looked back at those years (1990-1998) and I wonder, "what happened?"  You must also remember that this is coming from a DIE HARD Godzilla fan.  Ever since all the hype from this movie died, I feel so did a piece of my childhood (I'm only 16).  I've been reading some of the bad and good things about this film and I feel that I agree with some of them.  My readings have brought me to several of the following conclusions about this movie.  My first realization is how Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin have tarnished the Godzilla name.  Godzilla has been one of the best things to ever happen to western audiences during the 1950s through the 1990s.  Despite the hilariously bad dubbing and some corny story lines, somewhere inside, there was a lot of fun to be had and some serious topics to be discussed.  Since 1954, Godzilla has basically become an icon and has stood as a testament to the post-World War II era in which nuclear testing on Pacific islands was very common.  Godzilla himself, who is a product of nuclear testing, has stood as a symbol and as a constant reminder of man's tinkering with things that should not be tinkered with.  Godzilla is a menace plain and simple, but somewhere in the mayhem, we saw a truly tragic creature that was only doing what it could to survive simply because of man's carelessness.  This explains why Godzilla acted so fiercely towards newcomers such as King Ghidorah or Mechagodzilla, because he was defending his home.  This brings me to the "new" Godzilla, which in the movie is nothing more than just a big lizard who eats a lot of fish.  I heard that in an interview with Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich, that they had attempted (and with very poor results) to make this Godzilla more like "animalized". This basically means that they had tried to make Godzilla seem like the animal he is: a lizard.  This Godzilla only defended himself when he felt threatened, ran at the sight of the army instead of stomping them down, was vulnerable to attack (the original wasn't), and lastly, what the hell happened to his atomic blast?  Oh yeah, it was the fire.  The biggest difference between the two Godzillas was the whole with thing with reproduction.  The old Godzilla had only one child, while this Godzilla laid eggs.  What the hell?  I've heard a lot of people pan this, saying that the baby Godzillas look a lot like the raptors from "Jurassic Park".My second realization was the somewhat questionable casting.  Matthew Broderick is arguably an obvious choice for this film.  Even with his somewhat geeky looks, he does have the wit and charm of someone who could play a scientist.  Jean Reno plays a French mercenary who is on assignment in New York, who is there to clean up his country?s "mistakes", that being Godzilla and his offspring.  Jean Reno is good as a hit man like in the "The Professional" but not as a mercenary whose only role in this movie is to serve, as someone Matthew Broderick's character has to look to for help. Hank Azaria and Harry Shearer, who both regularly play characters on the animated show, "The Simpsons", are good as the cameraman and sleazy news anchor.  My biggest problem with the both of them is that they aren't given a lot to work with in this movie.  Hank Azaria seems only here as a little comic relief and Harry Shearer is only here as someone to laugh at when he gets told by Maria Pitillo's character."Godzilla" is really at best, failed potential.  In the hands of another action director like John Woo or someone around those lines, then maybe this movie may not have turned out to be something so bad.  I mean, I really used to like this movie, but I question the motives behind it.  Aside from all the recently discovered faults that I've found with this movie, I still give it a six out of ten for providing me with the entertainment that I found necessary to satisfy my interests in Godzilla.I still reflect on those days when Godzilla was my idol, my only escape from reality, and the only thing that primarily interested me.  I really hate to say it, but this movie unfortunately did it for me.  But, despite my newfound un-interest in Godzilla, I still have all of the information and collectibles that I gathered over the years and I occasionally look at them.

This was second movie I ever saw in Cinema, I loved it, I thought it was a lot of fun. I loved then and I still love it now, I got on DVD and seen it few times. The movie start of wit fisshing grew who get attack by sea creature and then one of people are hospital ed and only say GojiraI loved that scenes of "Godzilla coming out of water, it was really well done and a little funny as well. I found this movie also had some very dark humor and lots stuff was happens in the movie and it's not just about Godzilla. I thought the Godzilla who looked Great and found whole movie very fast paced, I never get boring at all. The acting was really good from the whole cast. it's shame about open ending, I heard this was meant 2 other movies in the series, As this got panned, axed the other 2 sequel. I hoping re-boot Dose not have the same thing happen to it! 7 out of 10

(Flash Review)Starting off relatively well, this turns into Jurassic Park as it felt like a dinosaur chase movie rather than focused on the mythical Godzilla. This new Godzilla also doesn't hold true to many of the original's traits such as what it eats and how it can be killed. Now on American soil of course Godzilla ravages Manhattan while the military try to take him down as they create a ton of (needless) damage. The media desperately looking for the inside scoop also create their own damage by stirring mass hysteria. One special scientist learns Godzilla is pregnant and warns that it's nest of eggs must be found to avoid hatching more of these beasts. As expected, this is full of explosions, destruction, roars, human ineptitude, light romance and heroics. Your typical Hollywood CGI fluff action monster movie with some notable plot holes.

This film's a bit of a paradox, on the one hand it does have its awesome moments and is frequently thrilling and entertaining, but it is also so damn dull! And some of the characters were impossibly annoying! "Not anymore Chuck, I quit!" Gah, that bitch thoroughly deserved to get her Razzi! I was never able to sit through it without fast-winding.. To me, it was stunning how badly they misjudged the material. After how terrifically Roland Emmerich staged mass destruction in Independence Day, I was really excited to see what he could do with Godzilla. But, yeah.. What a wasted opportunity. Did anyone in the audience ever walk out thinking that wait a minute, hadn't they already seen the same thing done elsewhere, like in Jurassic Park, not to mention done better? At the climactic seen where Godzilla's on top of the Brooklyn Bridge and he's hit by the missiles which knock him off the bridge and kill him - Even as a kid I thought: what, that's it? That's all it takes to kill him? It didn't take a fan to recognize that this was just plain anticlimactic, like someone pulling out a gun to shoot the bad guy in the finale of a martial arts film. I will say though that I thought the follow-up animated series that they did was not too bad at all. They kept a loose continuity with the feature film, and despite being unable to use any of Toho's famous monster characters, did a decent job of making an interesting set of stories from week to week. One time they even had him up against Quetzalcoatel! They at least had the smarts to make Godzilla a bit more powerful and aggressive, edging him closer to what the original Japanese series embodies. Sigh, I might have liked this picture a lot more if it had been called something other than Godzilla(!) At best, it's a below average monster-on-the-loose film, one that rips off a true classic I might add: Q the Winged Serpent, a film which unlike this one, is not soulless. Aside from the title of the movie, it has nothing to do with Godzilla. I mean of course they should have tried to do their own thing and in their own way, but if you are going to call it Godzilla, then you should at least retain some basis of the original character. That was their fatal flaw - they discarded *everything* except the name. Instead of a somewhat invulnerable dinosaur-like creature with dorsal fins, aggressive and destructive nature, that's equipped with his signature atomic breath and distinctive roar, and a symbol of the nuclear threat, they gave us a radiation-mutated lizard with no special ability who runs from conflict and destroys things by accident. In the end he is easily killed by a single volley of conventional weaponry. There's no discernible subtext to this turkey other than "let's make money!!!"

I am a huge fan of Godzilla since my early childhood. If read many books, played many games, collected many cards or little figures or whatever and watched many Japanese movies about this legacy...And then, I watched this American remake. They should have never touched this Japanese legend...The charm of the Japanese movies with people wearing the costumes, artificial miniature cities created brick by brick in long hours to get destroyed during one scene by a giant guy in a latex costume, the appearance of so many funny monsters, aliens or armies, the political, social, environmental or simply anti-war context of several movies... all of those things are not present in this movie. The few characters are kind of superficial, the most important scenes are entirely created on the computer and Godzilla doesn't look like the original one, but rather like a silly rip-off from the "Alien" movies. Everything that made the Japanese movies special and interesting is missing in this movie. That's why, even though most of the actors had signed for two sequels, there has not been a second American movie about Godzilla - thanks! The only thing this movie was good for was the fact that it brought the legendary Japanese monster to a larger public. And it was good to see an entertaining action movie (if we forget about the Japanese context) with some ice effects in the cinema - but nothing more.

Review title: This updated "Re-Think" doesn't follow the legendary Toho movies but this one isn't bad as some would like you to think.
Review_body: After the french nuclear testing, a lizard that mutated into a giant, fire-breathing creature. This huge monster is headed to New York City as for it's birthing place for its huge brood. An wimpy biologist Niko Tatapoulas (Matthew Broderick) is hired to tracked down the beast and has a connection with the creature. When a mystery man (Jean Reno) and his team are only ones know how to deal with the monster with the help of Tatopoulos. But an noisy ex-girlfriend of Tatopoulos (Maria Pitillo) and a cameraman (Hank Azaria) are along unexpectedly for the ride.Directed by Ronald Emmerich (The Day after Tomorrow, Independence Day, Stargate) made an extremely silly entertaining film that is loosely based on the 1956 Japanese picture. Although Emmerich's style of the film is similar to the original version of King Kong, Jurassic Park and even Q:The Winged Serpent. The story isn't first-rate and most of the characters are shallow. This was an box office disappointment in the summer of 1998. The movie goes on too long but it's fun, nonetheless. Screenplay by the director and Dead Devlin (Universal Soldier). From a story by Ted Elliott (The Mask of Zorro, Pirates of the Caribbean:The Curse of the Black Pearl, Small Soldiers), Terry Rossio (Aladdin, The Puppet Masters, Shrek), Delvin and director:Emmerich. Super 35. (*** 1/2 out of *****).

Because of the new release of Godzilla this year, and I'm looking forward to that, I watched this old blockbuster of 1998 once again. Well, it's obviously an old movie in terms of CGI and the acting is sometimes hugely annoying and childish. Compared to the new movie this year it really looks miserable sometimes . On the other hand, I can still remember the original Godzilla movies I saw when I was young in an old movie theater on a Sunday afternoon . There always was some Bruce Lee movie programmed in conjunction with a Japanese Godzilla (vs. King Kong ) or a Bud Spencer/Terence Hill movie . The Japanese Godzilla was hilarious . It looked like a plastic figure between cardboard boxes with some terribly bad special effects . By comparison, this Godzilla is state-of-the-art .Lets have a look at Godzilla first. At times the images are quite good like for instance the underwater images. In most of the movie, we only see parts of Godzilla: a leg that is put down on some stationary taxis, a swishing tail or only his head. Not exactly high technology. What bothered me the most is the fact that the thump of the drop of a foot followed with the subsequently shock wave is not properly synced with the bounce of people and cars . I thought this happens with a bit delay. The fact that New York is turned into a ruin is one thing. The fact that the army is the main cause of this instead of Godzilla is another thing. It's totally ridiculous. And sometimes I had the feeling that the decor was also made of cardboard boxes .The most irritating thing in Godzilla, are the stupid and terrible performances . I think Mathew Broderick is totally misplaced in this monster movie. I can tolerate him in a comedy like "She's having a baby", "Addicted to Love" or "Inspector Gadget ", but not in this disaster movie . Or they used him to pump up the comedy-rate. His name Tatopoulus is already a reason to make some hilarious (sarcastic) jokes. All the time he runs around through the rain with that ridiculous hat and every time he says something it sounds implausible and totally made up .Maria Pitillo looks like an angel but is corny and predictable. She's the blonde bimbo in the news department who's not allowed to bring important news. Eventually she's steals some footage on a tape and makes her own reportage. Her boss uses that for his own benefit but eventually she triumphs with a report at the end. She also appears to be an old sweetheart from Broderick. What a coincidence ! Hank Azaria was actually the best actor. A nice guy at the right time to use the camera for exclusive images. Kind of weird that every time something like that happens, the camera doesn't function properly. Then there are some more irritating people, such as: Kevin Dunn as a pedantic and clamorous Colonel, Michael Lerner as a stupid and thick mayor, Arabella Field as a friend of Animal who apparently doesn't know a cameraman sometimes experiences dangerous situations. Her reaction is almost hysterical all the time. Then there's Vicki Lewis the horny science woman who, despite the apocalyptic situation, still has time to start drooling whenever she looks at Broderick. And last but not least, Doug Savant as the most stupid soldier of the U.S. Army . The PeeWee Herman of the American army .You shouldn't assume that this movie is accurate and realistic. If you seek that in a movie, go watch "The Butler". But there are still quite a few things that look ridiculous . That Godzilla was created by radioactive radiation by nuclear tests in French Polynesia, is actually a variant of the original film . Why that animal must swim all the way to Manhattan to lay her eggs, is a mystery to me. He/she swims from the Pacific Ocean through the Panama Canal, along Florida and then straight to New York . Is he/she making a tourist trip ? The pilots who control the helicopters apparently never had to do an IQ test. They are chased by Godzilla, look over their shoulders in a panic , knowing that if they just flew that thing straight up they would be safe . I also think their index finger got stuck with super glue to the firing mechanism , because they kept spraying bullets continuously even when there was nothing in their sight. And could they ever miss Godzilla ? Such a huge animal . Dr. Tatopoulus is a renowned researcher in the field of animal mutation by radiation. At the time he presents this as proof that Godzilla might be actually a mutant lizard ,everyone declared him as a total nutcase and crazy fruitcake. Why did they call upon him in the first place ?The end was somewhat entertaining with the "Jurasic Park"-like baby Godzillas . But overall it was a disappointment. "Godzilla" had no such effect as let's say "Jaws " or "King Kong". Those movies gave you an anxious feeling. As someone suggested on IMDb : you purchase a lifelike Iguana as a pet, place it in the middle of the living room between some Lego houses , and observe how it moves and destroys everything . This can also be nerve-wracking and exciting.

So back in the days when Matthew Broderick was still cute and before CGI took over completely, they made this film which wasn't entirely done in front of a blue screen and I think it's a relative success. It's a "Type" of film that up until now I have only ever seen bits of, but enough to cobble together what was going on. That's what makes it work for me, the fact that you don't need to pay a huge amount of attention, but you are rewarded with some great scenes of a monster terrorising New York when you do look at the screen or come back from the kitchen. Would we call him a monster? I think that's a bit harsh actually and according to this film he is, what we as a people, have made him. I don't think he does it deliberately.Having now watched it all the way through, it makes even more sense and I would be happy to tune in again. It is a much more accessible 'Godzilla' than the 2014 version, even though my husband Aaron Taylor Johnson is in that one.The only thing that I think really complicates issues here is that there are so many characters involved. I think that they could have made the same film without at least the Mayor, Harry Shearer's news anchor and Hank Azaria (A severely underrated actor), the cameraman's wife and still achieved the same results.It's not that it's overly long because of it, but it does get very busy on the screen at times.The CGI and the animatronics work well together. I'm actually more of a fan of models and people in rubber masks or make up than I am of CGI anyway, but I understand how much better films are because of it now.It's not an offensive film and it doesn't raise political questions and it's not trying to get a message across, but it's fun and simple to follow.

Review title: Slow and painful form of torture
Review_body: Why was this film made? Why was Jean Reno in this movie? Was Matthew Broderick that desperate? Talk about a boatload of questions in need of an answer. This entire movie is a major stumper, making me wonder how such crap can come from the mind of a human being. Seriously, the old school Godzilla movies at least had some camp value because of the strings and miniature sets, but this proved to be a big waste of time. How the heck do you lose a 300-foot reptile in Manhattan? That's a question I still want answered. Clearly, Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin must have been getting sick of Hollywood or something because they actually thought this film was a good idea. Now the pair have to build themselves back up after making two great films in Stargate and Independence Day.
I paid $9.00 and left after twenty minutes....it was the worse thing ever, since the invention of electricity...do anything else with your time than see this staggeringly awful movie.

I remember actually liking this when I was younger. It had such great marketing too, I remember the Taco Bell dog quipping off the giant gecko, I remember getting a drink holder shaped like the lizard's claw, the toys were everywhere... It was fun!Oh how things have changed.This movie is bad. It's flirting with "so bad it's good" territory but no, it's just bad. The lizard looks ridiculous now, the performances are awful almost all around, save for Reno and Azaria. The comedy is just stupid and the movie makes no sense as it desperately claws for every bit of low hanging fruit it can get at. The movie is flat out stupid at numerous points, but it takes itself so seriously.Azaria is enjoyable and Reno is doing the best he can to turn garbage into gold. They are the only positives here beyond the occasional dumb joke that does manage to hit that "so bad it's good" spot but they are free and far between.Can't really recommend this for anyone. Fans of actual Godzilla movies seem to universally hate it. It's not a good action movie, there's no real drama, no performance worth seeing, no technical achievement. It's aged horribly in every possible way. Steer clear.

This movie is pretty bad, but compared to Emmerich's other films, I'd actually say its one of the better ones, which, again, isn't saying much (note the Two Star rating).
Emmerich is a man who loooooves his special effects. He is the poor man's Michael Bay, in my opinion. His movies pander to the lowest common denominator; the brainless masses that flock like zombies from a George Romero movie to see the latest wave of special effects-driven destruction. Look at almost all of Emmerich's films, and they all have one thing in common: the cool sequences of destruction are far more important than the characters, their motivations, or a coherent plot. There is a market for movies like this, and I was part of that market 20 years ago (no longer, thank God). This is a movie aimed at teenage and preteen boys; it never tries to rise above that intelligence level.
Side Note: I found it incredibly amusing that Emmerich decided to have the NYC Mayor be a caricature of Roger Ebert and the mayor's assistant, a caricature of Gene Siskel, a ridiculous jab that Ebert himself commented on when reviewing this film.

No croissant? No decent coffee, either. Indicative of a film that pales against the original.I know why Matthew Broderick was picked for The Producers. He played the same type that he did in this film. I didn't like him in either.But, I watched this for another chance to see Jean Reno. He was as great here as in Ronin, and funny, too. I have to admit that Michael Lerner was funny as the Mayor, as was Kevin Dunn as Colonel Hicks. Maria Pitillo (Natural Born Killers) was cute as Audrey.The special effects were OK, but those chopper pilots should get some training from Tommy Lee Jones (Fire Birds).Time would better spent watch one of the Japanese Godzilla films.

Review title: I think I'm just not a Kaiju fan
Review_body: Not a good watch, won't watch again, and can't recommend, unless you're just a Kaiju fan, which I am not.I have a noted bias for liking stories of shrinking down, or involving small people (like 6 inch people), and not liking "big" character stories (BFG, Godzilla, Pacific Rim, Cloverfield (probably the best for me, but I like found footage). Something about being too big to fit into society, not being able to hide / get away, being accidently destructive just has zero appeal to me.I do respect the genre, and in some ways....maybe more than the people that made this movie. Godzilla is supposed to be the main character, whether it's a "villain" or "hero", and America has trouble understanding that sometimes so they turned Godzilla into a force of nature that nested in.....one of the New York islands and had it make babies as additional antagonists. This allows for late 1990's CG work, with the Jurassic Park reject practical effects being one of the best things about this movie.There just isn't a lot of tension as Godzilla wrecks New York, maybe there is some with the babies, but really you're just supposed to ooh and awe at the effects for way too long until you realize you don't care, and by then they're supposed to have something else to dangle in front of you.Think of it as "shifting the goalposts", but with focus, while nothing of any real meaning happens. The most touching part of the movie was at the end, which was just confusing, because we should have felt triumphant and not sad, the movie fails to lead our emotions in that regard.No idea why Matthew Broderick touched this one, he must have always wanted it and go to live out a dream. He was, by far, the most famous person there, with Jean Reno behind him.Maybe I'm just not a fan, but there just isn't enough action / effects to make me like this one.

An overwhelming, series of brightly inflated lights takes over the skies where a nuclear bomb is being tested in French Polynesia is being examined. Moments later, the Pacific ocean is churning as a freighter is moving at a very rapid rate. Giant footprints have been spotted around the South Pacific beaches and rainforests. American coastal ships have been wrecked as they were twirling into a rolling sea with no logical explanation. The carnage then manifests all the way to Manhattan, New York (big surprise?)where the culprit centres around a giant dinosaur-like creature bigger than a Spinosaurus ruthlessly destroys the city leaving it near rubble as panic and fear comes into full effect. A scientist Dr. Nick Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick), an ambitious TV journalist Audrey Timmonds (Maria Pitillo), her cameraperson Animal Pilotti (Hank Azaria) and a French insurance investigator (Jean Reno) where an unorthodox camaraderie comes into fruition. Despite their working agendas and contrasting ways to go about it, they join forces to defeat this beast before her babies hatch before its too late. Back in 1998, everyone's favourite super-dinosaur who has terrorized audiences for over 60 years had returned to the big screen stomping on vehicles, destroying tall buildings, and breathing fire from its mouth. In this 1998 adaptation, more so than the 2014 remake, "Godzilla" was the most hyped summer blockbuster at the time. But the final product resulted in nothing more than an overdone, overrated abomination. It just lacked in excitement, thrills or even exposure to the massive beast, which was what I was expecting. Back in the 1950's when Godzilla was wrecking havoc in Japan, the stories focusing on the monster was often intense, though campy, with cheesy archaic technical effects, but did reflect a true phobia and distrust at the time when science and nuclear war was becoming a threat. However, the 1998 version, is contrary to the intentions that the Japanese versions had. Okay the technical features improved tremendously, but the fear factor was not very effective. Godzilla in the more modern day feels not well needed and has no symbolic references in our less than paranoid world than in years before. Directed by Roland Emmerich (who also directed "Independence Day") made "Godzilla" to cater towards the audience into making him a spectacle rather than to implement a significant story behind the beast and its destructive nature. The monster just plows his way across the Pacific towards New York City where all modern day giant beasts make their homes to proves themselves formidable. The main thing wrong here is that the monster's screen time seems to be at only thirty minutes long. That's quite a record low. The unleashing of the monster is to be blamed towards nuclear testing. When the opening credits come into fruition as iguanas are staring at a giant mushroom-shaped cloud is coming down. Radiation has a lasting effect on these lizards and before you know it, Godzilla materializes standing over 100 feet tall, leaving massive footprints and demolishing fishing boats.Matthew Broderick is Dr. Tatopoulos a nerdy kind scientist who was brought into the mix while his ex-girlfriend, TV journalist Audrey Timmonds who has ambitions of being promoted news anchor and coverage of Godzilla's destruction is her ticket to that position. Let's just say the apocalypse of the modern day world is just another shoe in for career opportunities. Once again Matthew Brodrick is playing the same character he's played all his career. Maria Pitillo fared better and was adorable, it's too bad she knew it herself. The real stand-out performer comes from Jean Reno was the French secret agent. With his panicked eyes and his pock-marked complexion and his harried expressions, he was the sole character other than the giant lizard that held my interest. He scoffs at awful the coffee the New Yorkers make and when impersonating Elvis in front of American soldiers. The missing ingredient that would have made "Godzilla" better was some tongue-in-cheek humour which Emmerich used in "Independence Day" that he neglected here. As it stands, "Godzilla" falls flat by simply lacking in wit. Michael Lerner can pass off as the most loudest, annoying political leader as Mayor Ebert, as he bears a stunning resemblance to film critic Roger Ebert. Oh what a coincidence, his partner is a balding man named Gene. How funny is that?The only thrilling moments often feels recycled from "Jurassic Park" and "The Lost World" only exception, those two movies executed it far better. The monster's features are only shown waist down crushing cars and demolishing cars with his powerful tail. Meanwhile at Madison Square Garden, little Godzillas wreck havoc against feared bystanders that once again steal pages from Spielberg with the velociraptors. Fifth Avenue was in rubble, Chrysler Building is crushed and the Brooklyn Bridge is now eradicated, by end the end of the destruction that may cost trillions of dollars in damages. The beast is never good or evil. He's just an animal, a gigantic, loud shallow beast with reboots, remakes and sequels in the future, his reputation's slowly becoming extinct.

There are only two good things in this film, Jean Reno as the French spy, and the editing, which keeps the film moving even when the screenplay clearly does not. For these two reasons alone, it might be worth wasting some time on this, but surely for nothing else.Here are some of the bad qualities of this mess: BAD science: it is physically impossible for this lizard to have laid 200 eggs in two days.BAD history: The French are brought in to hide the fact that it was the US that did most of the nuclear testing in the Pacific.BAD politics: In a State of Emergency military response HQ, the mayor would never be present - he has no authority in such a situation; so why do the soldiers here even tolerate him? BAD story construction: Only a couple missiles to kill off a monster, but two similarly explosive torpedoes can't do the job? And how did the lizard get from Guam to NYC without any further notice - in a single day, apparently. And why? We all know Toho's Godzilla's grudge against Japan, but it's senseless for GINO to swim thousands of miles, just to sleep in a NYC subway.BAD characters: The hero is boringly monotone, in appearance as in speech; the hero's girlfriend is a real bitch and deserved stepping on - why then bring the two of them back together? Are they sadomasochists as well? BAD special effects: The color values of the skin of the big reptiles never change, despite radical variance in tone, amount, and direction of the environmental lighting of any scene. A godzillion dollars on special effects, and they make such a serious goof?! Of course these critters are phony - they look pasted on the screen.BAD in-jokes: The Siskel and Ebert gag was amusing for precisely 10 seconds - unfortunately it was repeated through-out the film. And it is overtly insulting to two critics who deserved our respect, no matter how we disagreed with them.BAD performances: Is Matthew Broderick's face capable of more than one expression? If so, I've never seen it.BAD musical score: the main theme of the film is played over and over again, until we just want some big reptile to step on the orchestra.BAD psychology: The endlessly replayed musical theme is composed to arouse sympathy for the beast, when everything else in the film makes us dislike it. The disjunction is painful.BAD timing: This film goes on and one - the eggs are introduced for no other reason than to prolong a film that desperately needs trimming.I could go on, but what's the point. Roland Emmerich needs to find something other to do with his life, he's clearly not cut out to make movies. In an interview on a featurette in the DVD release of this film, director Roland Emmerich says that he wanted to make a "completely different" Godzilla, the original being - according to him - out of date. Does this man suffer from brain damage? Godzilla doesn't need to be different. Godzilla is the protagonist of a popular ongoing series of films made in Japan. Beginning in 1984, the producers of these films decided they would gradually update the series to take advantage of new special effects technology. They didn't need some snotty Occidental to show them how to do this. They were gracious enough to license out the series to Americans because they know our fascination with these films. I suspect they assumed that an American entry into the series would give it new energy. Instead, their series' title was ripped-off for a remake of a completely other American film.If you're going to make a pastiche of a famous adventure series, you had better find some way to fit your pastiche into the series as a whole. For instance there are many pastiche Sherlock Holmes stories written by authors other than Arthur Conan Doyle. Some of these stories attempt to fill in a gap in the original series - the years following Holmes' struggle with Professor Moriarity at the Reichenbach Falls, when Watson loses touch with Holmes for a few years. So a reader is permitted to imagine Holmes as having lived a whole life - no past Holmes episode is denied; no Holmes story to come is effected. The reader can thus ignore the question of authorship and concentrate on following the adventurous life of the great detective.While the original Godzilla series is not chronologically sequential (A few are, presumably, set in an "alternate universe"), they do share a remarkably consistent set of themes and subtexts. And while the appearance of Godzilla changes over the years, these changes are consistent with the notion that the monster somehow matures with every film.It is utterly pointless, therefore, to make a Godzilla film without any Godzilla in it. It is actually insulting - to the producers of the original series and to its audience - to discard the themes that brought the audience to the original series in the first place. And it is absolutely stupid (and racist) to presume that, because you work in Hollywood rather than Tokyo, you can get away with it.So this is not a Godzilla film - what is it really? It happens to be an over-bloated overly-rewritten remake of the Ray Harryhausen classic, "Beast From 20,000 Fanthoms". That film is also way better than this one; heck, while made in the '50s, even its special effects are better.Again, if you have two hours of spare time, and you can think of nothing else to do with your life, by all means let Emmerich give your brain a visual enema with this movie. But keep the toilet-paper handy, I guarantee watching this will leave a mess to clean-up.

This is one of the worst remakes ever. From the opening scene that virtually doomed it right from the beginning with an iguana watching before a nuclear explosion, to the fools behind the camera tossing everything the Toho told them to do, this is just one dumb movie. They actually filmed it near where I work, so I did get some nice pictures of the tank equipment. But the movie is a flop. Miscast, poorly written and just dumb, it's the worst Godzilla movie ever made. I'm glad Toho made fun of it in Godzilla final wars when the real Godzilla wipes the matt with this Jurassic Park cast off.
This film was awesome back in the day but on repeat viewing it's not that great. Let's just say Godzilla is the best actor in it lol

Directed by Roland Emmerich. Starring Matthew Broderick, Maria Pitillo, Jean Reno, Hank Azaria, Kevin Dunn, Michael Lerner, Harry Shearer, Lorry Goldman, Vicki Lewis, Arabella Field, Doug Savant. (PG-13)Japan's most famous giant lizard gets rebooted and rerouted to NYC, where it climbs out of the sea and tries to catch a Broadway show, then accidentally steps on and knocks over a bunch of stuff, which makes the mayor and military very unhappy. Spectacularly stupid and visually unspectacular, this monstrosity is the very definition of a tentpole-wannabe; even on the level of effects-driven "popcorn entertainment," it's never wise to insult the intelligence of the audience this badly. Broderick isn't exactly a prime candidate for action-junk leading man, but it's hapless Pitillo that could really use a good reptile-on-a-rampage squashing (at least Reno emerges unscathed, as expected). For anyone afraid that it might get monotonous watching ol' Gojira stomp around a city for over two hours, rest assured that there's an extended bit involving its newly-hatched babies scurrying about and looking for human-flavored snacks that shamelessly rips off the "Jurassic Park" raptor scenes. Makes Emmerich's last picture, "Independence Day," astonishingly watchable by comparison. Plus, the soundtrack desecrates Led Zeppelin's "Kashmir," so there isn't even a respite when the credits start to roll.24/100

Review title: A tale of two actors! Oh, and the special effects have their say too!
Review_body: When a ship is attacked at sea by an monster that is suspected to have a politically damaging source of origin, Matthew Broderick is called in as an expert in the effects of radiation on lifeforms.From the start Jean Reno, an insurance investigator is hot on the tail of Broderick and the creature to get some answers of his own.Now Matthew Broderick has a great knack of appearing in bad films and delivering poor performances (e.g. Inspector Gadget, The Cable Guy) where Jean Reno is pretty much the opposite (e.g. Leon, Ronin) Thank god when Reno appears in a film that is - Shall we say, less intelligent and full of cheese, he can still deliver an believable and serious performance.In Godzilla it is quite literally only Reno and the special effects team that emerge with the credit of hauling this film out from the depths it seemed so desperate to reach.Anyway, that's enough of bashing this movie - What about the good points? I hear you ask. Well beneath the cheesy dialogue and the simplistic story, there is a fun action film, crammed with great visuals and plenty of action. But seriously, that's all it is; a very expensive bit of fun, Reno's strong performance and the stunning special effects cannot make this film anything more that.6/10 I enjoyed it for what it is, and as a cheesy action flick it's OK

Review title: From the creators of "Independance Day"; that phrase alone should tell you what to expect...
Review_body: We were never gonna get thrills on a par with "Aliens".  That film had a director whose personality (and possibly ego) was big enough to sit alongside that of the franchise and not be overshadowed by it.  Godzilla has a big tradition in Japan, and sadly, with this film it has been reduced to a Saturday matinee type feature.Aliens also had a star who had been made into an icon by the success of the first film.  The closest we come to a headliner in this picture is a moonlighting Jean Reno.  Brooding and vaguely charismatic he may be, but he doesn't have the ability to anchor the audiences attention firmly to what's happening onscreen.  Despite some manful efforts from the cast, the film struggles to stay afloat without the influence of a major star.An average attempt at a big-budget crowd pleaser, which has some impressive moments but doesn't deliver the end product we perhaps had a right to expect given the source of its inspiration.

Review title: Godzilla is a shoddily crafted monster extravaganza tainted with poor acting, incompetent writing, and a misguided direction
Review_body: In the history of Hollywood's renditions of the classic titular dinosaur wrecking havoc on a metropolitan city, Roland Emmerich's re-imagining of the source material is arguably one of the worst. Emmerich, the man behind the 1996 blockbuster hit 'Independence Day' puts his heart in wrecking mass destruction in his films. Whether it involves destroying major landmarks such as the White House, the Chrysler building, and the Empire State Building, or racking up an abundant body count in an endless barrage of explosive special-effects mayhem (or both); Emmerich's fingerprints are almost always on display when his films come on screen. His extravagant style of filmmaking shows up on full blast in this big-budget monster feature, but without capturing the true spirit of its classic primitive monster that's been popping in theaters since 1954. Suffering from a sorely incompetent script co-written by Dean Devlin, poor performances, and Emmerich's misguided direction, Godzilla transpires to an unappetizing big-budget disaster flick that simply crashes and burns. Set in Manhattan, New York, this follows biologist Nick Tatopoulos (played by Matthew Broderick) who discovers the giant dinosaur as it makes it's way to the Big Apple and wrecks havoc while laying eggs in an underground nest. Teaming up with his former girlfriend Audrey (played by Maria Patillo), freelance news photographer Victor Palotti (played by Hank Azaria), and French secret service agent Phillipe Roche (played by Jean Reno); Nick must make a daunting attempt to bring the enormous creature down and save the city from utter destruction.There is very little reason to expect Roland Emmerich to make a masterpiece out of the giant prehistoric monster, but certainly no reason why not to expect him to at least capture the spirit of the classic titular monster. Unfortunately, what transpires is a bombastic monster attack extravaganza that strolls along with a brain-dead screenplay and a shortage of thrills. That is not say the film doesn't kick off on a somewhat promising start. The opening minutes of the dinosaur arriving in the city causing chaos and destruction everywhere are sort of fun to watch. After while, the thrills and excitement quickly wear off as the film bogs down on flamboyant action sequences while taking for granted any real attempts on suspense. And Roland Emmerich makes use of plenty of explosions and plenty of collateral destruction to make Michael Bay blush. It is not until the second half when the film completely throws logic out the window. This is when Emmerich takes the action in a underground in a battle against thousands of Godzilla's babies. By then, all the chaos ensues into an unintentionally funny 'Jurassic Park' rip-off, and without sense of rationality. How is Godzilla as tall as a building in the beginning, yet able to fit inside a subway station toward the end? These sequences are supposed to be fun, but fail make any sense. This definitely isn't say that Roland Emmerich doesn't pack a fair use of state-of-the-art special effects, though nothing innovative.Matthew Broderick established himself as a household name upon his charismatic portrayal in the 80s classic comedy 'Ferris Bueller's Day Off', though perhaps not on Hollywood's A-list. Here, he plays a likable biologist who becomes a heroic hand at saving the city of Manhattan from Godzilla's havoc but delivers nothing beyond a surface-level performance with a slew of cheesy dialogue. And the character himself develops to almost nothing but a punching bag of botched humor involving characters failing to pronounce his last name. Maria Patillo who plays his former girlfriend however, phones in a rather wooden performance that falls short of emotion. Jean Reno, the star of Luc Besson's 'Leon: The Professional' in 1994 plays a secret service agent who provides a little comic relief with a few good one-liners sprinkled here and there, but nothing memorable. Hank Azaria, the best known for providing the voices of various characters in Fox's animated television series 'The Simpsons' is also given his time to shine, but falls victim to a slew of unfunny jokes nearly every minute he's on screen. The film's biggest and arguably the most bizarre attempt at meta-humor comes from Michael Lerner and Lorry Goldman playing parodies of film critics Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel, even mocking Ebert's trademark "thumbs up". Is this really supposed be funny? Maybe if they were actually given something to do with the plot.Godzilla is a poorly crafted rendition of it's classic source material that suffers from a thoroughly misguided direction by Roland Emmerich, a slew of poor performances, and an overall absent-minded script that fails to capture the heart and soul of the titular creature. In short, it is a mind-numbing big-budget action spectacle that may provide some pleasing value in it's top-notch special effects, but nothing fascinating.

After bizarre attacks on a Japanese freighter, first the French then the U.S. learn of the existence of an apparent modern "dinosaur". When it's suspected that radiation from nuclear weapons testing in French Polynesia may have instead produced the monster, biological radiation specialist Dr. Nick Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) is called to the scene. While investigating the monster's path of destruction, a new sighting arrives--just off the coast of New York City! It's no secret that Godzilla has been much maligned. Even Fangoria editor Tony Timpone stated in an editorial that he thought it sucked, and he's usually willing to give movies the benefit of the doubt. The reasons why director Roland Emmerich's version of Godzilla is hated are as varied as people stating opinions. But I tend to think that there is also a strong bandwagon effect with this film that will be tempered by time. There are already signs of a number of people giving it a second look and lessening the severity of their criticism.The chief complaint seems to come from a very vocal but relatively small crowd of fanboy purists--they dislike that Godzilla is different here. In the Japanese films, made by the Toho production company, Godzilla is a guy in a rubber suit who stomps on models of buildings and such. He tends to lumber, as irrelevant military attacks on him provide pretty fireworks. Most Godzilla films feature him fighting some other monster, "professional wrestling" style, and Godzilla arbitrarily falls down and gets back up as he is attacked and attacks with various "death rays" from his mouth, eyes, etc. Now that might sound like I don't like the typical Godzilla film, but that's not true. I like them quite a bit, but a big part of the reason why is that most of them are very cheesy. I'm a fan of bizarre cheese/camp, and you get tons of that in Godzilla films.But I'm not a purist. To me, there's no good reason why Emmerich's Godzilla needs to be similar to the Toho incarnations, which in fact are often quite different from and inconsistent with each other, too. At this point, I see Godzilla more as a recurring character type--think of the various instantiations of Dracula or Frankenstein throughout the 20th Century. The Toho films can't really be seen as chapters in a single, long story. But whether their arguments are wrong or not, the fanboy purists are at least noisy and prolific, and too many people are followers.If Emmerich would have given us a guy in a rubber suit, acting just like the Toho Godzillas (not "Godzilla"), with the typical gobbledy-gook of a Toho script, this film would have bombed even worse (if we can call a 100 million dollar film that made a profit a "bomb") and the fanboys would have still found something to complain about. Even though I love the Toho Godzilla films, too, we can't deny that they do not tend to be bestsellers on video in the U.S., despite the fact that they're readily available for purchase.So what Emmerich gives us instead is an epic, expensive-looking film that spans a number of genres, features more coherent dialogue and subplots than a typical Toho Godzilla film, and showcases a redesigned, mostly cgi cast of monsters, where Godzilla looks and behaves much more like a "real" giant, mutant lizard. For those of us who are not purists, who do not care if our opinions match the majority, and who evaluate films on all or their technical and artistic levels, it's difficult to deny that Godzilla has many merits.For example, the cinematography in this film is gorgeous. The sound design is superb and the soundtrack (score and songs) works well with the film. All of the action sequences, and they comprise a large percentage of the film, are expertly staged--Emmerich doesn't resort to darkness, blur-cams and overly quick cuts like many other directors. It's always easy to follow the narrative during action scenes, it's always easy to see what's going on, and it's always coherent. That goes for the non-action scenes, too--the entire film is ingeniously designed in terms of the progression from one sequence to another. Also, the cgi is amazing--it's often difficult to tell where it stops and mechanicals/models begin.But the story is great, too. Broderick's Tatopoulos is an attractive anti-hero, a nerdish scientist who solve dilemmas with his professional knowledge. The other hero is Jean Reno as Philippe Roache, a humorously enigmatic French "insurance agent". The obligatory romantic subplot, involving Tatopoulos and Audrey Timmonds (Maria Pitillo) surprisingly avoids clichés, and Timmonds provides a launching pad for an all-too-honest satire of the media.Satire is high up on Emmerich's agenda. Godzilla not only satirizes the media, but the military, New York/New Yorkers, film critics, and even monster movies. While the film is simultaneously giving us a lot of genres--sci-fi, horror, adventure, war film, drama, etc. the most unexpected motif is the almost cartoonish, spoof-like humor. Godzilla is more frequently laugh-out-loud funny that anyone expected it to be. It's not just one-liners and overt jokes, although those are certainly present, but the amped up intentional absurdity of situations such as the final taxi cab "chase".Even if you think that Godzilla has some internal problems as an artwork (and I agree that there is a slight clunkiness in parts of the narrative flow--it caused me to subtract a point), there's no way it deserves the trashing it's received so far. This is at least a well-made film on a technical level, and if you have any taste for slightly campy sci-fi/monster flicks, you should find much to enjoy here.

Review title: The Big Guy deserved much better
Review_body: Godzilla's return to the big screen is major flop.  Cast and special effects could have made for a good movie, but the script torpedoes all that. Plot seems ripped off from Jurassic Park - The Lost World, about the last place anyone in their right mind should go.  Watch the Taco Bell ad ("here lizard, lizard, lizard"), it's much shorter and infinitely more entertaining.

Review title: One of the first movies I remember truly disliking
Review_body: I was 12 years old. Godzilla (1998) was on tv. I'd loved dinosaurs throughout my childhood, so surely I could get around a giant radioactive lizard, right?But even at that age, this film seemed bad. Something was just off. It's the first movie I remember picking apart, and finding inconsistencies and ridiculous moments within. Some people in my life say I'm too critical and analytical when it comes to movies, and this film might be responsible for kick-starting that cynical streak within me.It would have been the first Godzilla film I ever watched, and honestly, what a terrible introduction to the franchise. It's a Godzilla film in name only, really. It's too long, too sloppy, and too boring to count itself as a true Godzilla film.But we all know the purists hate it, so there's little reason for me to go on. Now 13 years later, I've finally seen every other Godzilla movie, and they all have more to offer than this one (with the possible exception of 1969's All Monster's Attack, which is essentially a clip show of scenes from previous movies, and therefore easy to forget about).I don't have any inclination to rewatch this. If I didn't like it as a child, I'd probably like it even less than an adult, and it's likely all I'd get from losing over 2 hours of my life to the movie would be the realisation that 3/10 is too generous.Where to go for a better Godzilla movie, someone may ask? Literally anywhere else. Even the two recent American Godzilla movies, if you must.If this helped the legitimate Godzilla movies get more exposure outside Japan then maybe this infamous mess did some good. And the smackdown this inclination of Godzilla receives in 2004's Final Wars is wonderful. Yet for Godzilla fans (and fans of well made movies in general), I'd advise staying away, unless you're even younger than I was when I sat through this, feeling youthful, frustrated, and utterly perplexed.

When the commercials for this film first came out, my brother commented to me that he knew what it was going to be about before it hit the screen. He said there is only so much they can do with the film.He was right.There is only so much you can do with a story like this and then what you have to hope for is that the script has some interesting characters and some good dialogue.  Well, it doesn't.  So the movie sucks.I was bored in this film, so much so that I almost fell asleep and when I saw the film unfolding exactly the way my brother prophesized it to do, I laughed.  It's too bad they couldn't have proved him wrong because I would have kept a bit more money that Darrel took from me because I lost the bet.This is an awful movie and the true champion of the summer has to go to Armageddon.  This is just trash.  Stay away from it.

The 1954 Japanese classic film Godzilla is very good as a horror film and a fun movie, which was thankfully recently given Criterion treatment. Alas, in the West the film has not always been available in its true form. In 1956 it was butchered thoroughly, massively edited and manipulated into Godzilla, King of the Monsters!, a goofy movie in badly dubbed English. If that weren't enough, in 1998 the Americans decided to butcher Godzilla again, with a movie about as bad- Godzilla, by the makers of the smash hit Independence Day (1996).Because of my love of Independence Day as a youth, when I saw Godzilla '98 in theatres I assumed I had to like it, and tried to convince myself it was a good movie, much as with Batman and Robin the year before. Time has made me realize how much of that was self-deception, however. Godzilla '98 is loud and often stupid, and the action scenes never really blew me away. Most of the damage to New York City in the film is done not by Godzilla but by the army trying to kill the creature. The moments of comic relief all fall flat (we were supposed to be rolling over laughing every time someone called Broderick "the worm guy"). The movie repeatedly pulls the same tricks, with people thinking they're clear of danger before Godzilla pops up suddenly again. The dialogue is often painful, as adult characters interact as if they were children ("You were supposed to be my friend, I trusted you.")Some parts defy logic. Why can't the military ever actually shoot Godzilla? Are we really supposed to believe Godzilla can pick up a car in his mouth and crunch on it but the car and people inside it are still functioning? The Nostalgia Critic also did a good job illustrating how the "Babyzilla" scenes imitate the raptor scenes in Jurassic Park (1993). Admittedly, I still love this movie's soundtrack. "Macy Day Parade" by Michael Penn and "Untitled" by Silverchair are beautiful songs, though unfortunately they don't seem to be in the film itself, which favours "Come With Me" by Puff Daddy which is only sort of okay because it sounds like "Kashmir." The special effects are mostly good, although we don't actually get a good look at Godzilla besides his feet. The movie also had an attractive ad campaign. One commercial showed Godzilla stepping on and destroying a tyrannosaur fossil, and that unfortunately isn't in the movie either. Ultimately, Godzilla '98 has none of the charm of the Japanese original, and is more of a cliché Hollywood disaster movie.

My Take: It's all spectacle, no thrills. The final hour is satisfying though. Rated PG-13I have to admit that back when I was a kid, I really loved watching "Godzilla", mainly because I'm a sucker for monster movies, especially dinosaur films. Another reason is that film criticism does not apply to me yet. Now that it applies, I began to see the real colors of "Godzilla", a weak and flawed film the relies too heavily on effects than plot, pacing and interest. The second half is somehow exciting, but it's the overlong and boring first half that's the problem. If you have it on DVD, you can just fast-forward it to the good parts, but trust me, the first half is darn long. So long (and boring) it almost chews up the entire running time of the film.The problem of "special-effects vs. good story" is not something new to director Roland Emmerich and co-writer/producer Dean Devlin, who made INDEPENDENCE DAY. But ID4 didn't bore me because it was fun as it is, GODZILLA on the other hand spent too much time showing us the giant lizard's feet than forming much action or human characters among them.Another thing about this film, is that it tries so hard to be another "Jurassic Park", adding, of course, the rampage of the baby Godzillas and an enjoyable final chase scene. interesting thing about the film. Obviously, it's no "Jurassic Park", and even not "The Lost World: Jurassic Park". It is, mainly, a large lizard movie that focuses more in "destroying" New York than giving audiences what they came for.I'd be lying if a say I didn't enjoy this film. It somewhat takes off on the second half, but getting there is just far too long, even for someone (or something) as big as the big "G". Rating: **1/2 out of 5.

What? How you can miss so bad?
You had a GIGANTIC LIZARD/DINOSAUR to have us on our heels!I watched this movie when I was 11, at the theater. This movie didn't need to be really good to make love it. I was 11yo average kid dumb (I might still be, but even if I am, which Im not, but let's say I am, which I'm not, I'm still not THAT dumb just by simple nature), so with a 1.40 hs movie, with a Godzilla tease every 8-15 minutes until the final act, you probably would've gotten me. The bad script, dialogue and lack of logic in the movie could've been forgotten by that kid very easily (harder now).In the end, the movie just was doomed from the start when they chose Matthew Broderick. He's just an awful "miracle" of nature. Only in the disgustingly awful 90's (post-Berlin Wall? maybe has something to do? Like, now there is no competition, why would even try to show how much better United States is?).Anyways. Once you cast such a talentless hack, you either make the movie "a joke" and go for it, with lots of humor, no realism whatsoever, little plausibility, and a more adventuristic approach.They.Did.Not.Do.That.
My God. The boredoom!Whatever. I'm still ranting 20 years later! )

I still remember this movie was among my first Hollywood movies to be seen on television. I always like the sci-fi take (here growth in size of organism due to nuclear activity) in these sorts of movies. The other movie that comes this close to the above description when it comes to me is Jurassic Park.I don't know why it is rated so less.I rate it a point less only because I disliked the ending otherwise it deserves full marks.

Godzilla: 7 out of 10: Godzilla or someone pretending to be Godzilla attacks New York and only Matthew Brodrick and the French Secret Service can save the Big Apple.This is not the worst Godzilla film ever made, not by a long shot. The lack of endless little boys in short pants put this effort ahead of much of the filmography. Overall it is an entertaining if often painfully dated film. Like Three Kings after the second Iraq war Godzilla today is a different viewing experience with today's eyes.Let us ask and answer some questions.Were special effects really that bad during the nineties? You know I am unclear on that as well. I always thought the dinosaurs in Jurassic Park looked really good and that was five years earlier than this film in 1993 and the Matrix came out only a year later than this in 1999. I recently resaw Godzilla in 4k streaming on Netflix and yikes. Should have gone with a guy in the suit.Why did they redesign Godzilla? The story is they wanted to make her more realistic. Honestly, the new one is even sillier. I mean to support that kind of weight you are going to need big thighs. It just looks all kinds of wrong and the movie doesn't help matters by having her seemingly change size throughout the film.The look is not the worse thing mind you. It is Godzillas new special... I'm going with ability. She is apparently a master at hide and seek. Yes, the 278 foot five hundred ton Godzilla plays peek a boo with the American Army. The movie really tries to sell this hard. It does not work.Wasn't it was nice of those helicopters to fly low enough for Godzilla to eat them? I know right. I mean their regular flying ceiling is twenty thousand feet but let us fly at 100 feet between buildings that btw look nothing like Manhatten.And those submarines in the Hudson seemed to have an awful time trying to find her? Yeah, I was wondering about that as well. I mean the Hudson and the east river are about 40 feet deep in most place. I have no idea where they were. Even Long Island Sound at its deepest wouldn't hide Godzilla. Facts and logic were not this films friend.Overall I enjoyed my revisit with this Godzilla. The nostalgia was nice and I liked the fact Broderick's love interest, the very cute Maria Pitillo, was probably one the evilest femme fatale in the history of movies and still takes her back at the end.It has been common recently to revisit this film and declare it not that bad. I tend to agree it is not that bad. Not that good as well mind you but at least some form of Godzilla shows up in this one.

I don't mind some Roland Emmerich films. I tend to be more interested though in the ones that don't focus on disasters and monsters. Godzilla has both. It's a big budget sci-fi action film full of so-called spectacle, but at its heart it's terribly empty and lacking in any genuine dramatic content.There's no sense of mystery nor surprise. Godzilla is rolled out in the first minute of the movie, after which we get this confusing global whip around, where we find characters such as Dr. Niko "Nick" Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) an NRC scientist, who is in the Ukraine researching the effects of radiation on wildlife. Within a couple of minutes, he's summoned to Tahiti, then Panama, then Jamaica. All I could think was that he must be experiencing a hell of a jet lag. But no, this is the way Emmerich unfurls the little narrative that we get. I don't think it was ever actually confirmed in the movie, but I think we're expected to believe that Godzilla is a mutated marine iguana, who has been affected by French (LOL!) atomic testing (rather than American).Anyway the big guy finds his way to New York, where unsurprisingly again, he/she (don't ask) causes a hell of a lot of trouble around the Manhattan area and we later find that he/she is capable of giving birth to 200 (what looked to me like) tyrannosaurus rexes. Yep! All of a sudden there are all these dinosaurs running around. Shades of Jurassic Park! The story is just weird, but one can easily see that Emmerich was clearly intent on moving into Steven Spielberg's dinosaur domain under any illogical circumstances.This movie is all about visual effects, borrowed ideas from better films (especially those from Spielberg) clichéd dialogue, flimsy and formulaic narratives, illogical plot developments, and lack of character depth. Broderick is a nerdy Sam Neill without the required gravitas, but with a ridiculous beret for goodness sake. He has a love interest played by someone by the name of Maria Pitillo, of whom I've never heard anything about, before or since. She's cute but ... ! Jean Reno turns up looking guilty ... for turning up in a movie like this.Interesting things: 1 Why is it raining in so many scenes? Is rain a Godzilla thing? It gets seriously tiresome. In Blade Runner there was a reason, but Godzilla? 2 Godzilla seems to change in size depending on the circumstances required of a given "action" scene. Is it possible for instance, that the US forces with all their advanced technology are incapable of finding a 120 m creature hiding in the Hudson River? 3 How many times in movies now has Roland Emmerich supervised the destruction of New York? Does he ever get sick of it?I've given this movie a 3/10. It's not really worth that, but I figure that with a production this big, at least a lot of people got a lot of work out of it and that's got to be surely worth something.

Review title: The Only Best Godzilla Film Ever Made
