Review_body: Godzilla is a Japanese franchise but Hollywood made it look cool there are so many out there before this & after this including the new 2014 release is a no match for this because this is really a good film for anyone to enjoy.came out in 1998 & in those times VHS was high there was a free gift promotion launched by a biscuit company in Pakistan my cousin won a VHS of Godzilla and he showed me around 2001 i guess those days i was not into movies as i was 11 years old but again i saw it recently with the new 2014 Godzilla of Elizabeth Olsen this film surpasses any version ever made.The plot:after the test of atomic bombs in south pacific the result is a large lizard is born called Godzilla the lizard runs around new york city destroying anything in its path.The cast:there is not much acting scope here but Jean Reno did good acting as always.The direction was great by Roland Emmerich there is one funny scene that is my most favorite when Godzilla destroys a car & the wheel just pops out of it & goes far away the camera keeps filming it.Just please don't listen to critics & haters do give this a try you will get some entertainment & info about what Godzilla is.Overall its a one time watch good film my rating for Godzilla 1998 is 5/10.

I blame the kids for making me sit through this film of pathetic dialogue and comic book acting. Yeah, I know, it's not meant to be taken seriously. But what a waste of my time. I could have been watching at least two Ed Wood classics and get more thrills. The other bloody problem is that damn continuous rain, it had me running to the toilet on a few occasions. By the way, the effects are worth a couple of points.

Godzilla is a very disappointing film, the plot if run of the mill and every character is forgettable and wooden. The special effects are brilliant though, especially for the time and it's a shame such a large budget was wasted on such a poor film, some scenes are actually quite good and this reflects the larger picture of what the film could be. But alas, it wasn't to be3/10: Poor

This was an odd film, just odd. They create all this build-up and drop the ball with the human characters. There is lots of action and poorly attempted humour to fill this bloated storyline. Unsure why the filmmakers attempted to make this version. The biggest issue is the one note script which is flat, really flat. No character chemistry and odd acting choices. The filmmakers were just wrong and this failed to deliver on the hype surrounding this film at the time of release. This was successfully rebooted.

Review title: One way to describe a summer blockbuster: ALL SHOW AND NO GO!!!
Review_body: We're at the boiling point of classic movie / TV series remakes, folks! Combined as a rip-off of JURASSIC PARK by modern standards, GODZILLA is another in recent attempts to win over new generations of young moviegoers. It's one of the few that fail to dupe their original counterparts, all because of big budget visuals and lackluster writing. That pretty much explains why Sony wanted another blockbuster franchise since MEN IN BLACK to gain control of the movie industry, and I'm sorry to say that their luck has run out. An aged and weakling plot isn't the only disease it suffers from. Godzilla's character design is a terrible pity and so does its politically incorrect New York setting. For DVD owners, the best use of your new disc is a doorstop for expensive graphics, and that's it! If you think it's a waste of money, consider these important facts: $50 million on promotional theatrical advertising! 8 1/2 minutes of end credits! A soundtrack album featuring The Wallflowers! Need I say more? We can expect better movies in the future, but not like this! I'll stick to those classic Japanese monster movies, thank you!

This review contains spoilers.Godzilla is a monster movie that premiered in 1998. The movie is directed by Roland Emmerich. It is based on the character Godzilla by Toho. The movie stars Matthew Broderick, Jean Reno, Maria Pitillo. A mutated lizard attacks New York City to create a nest for its young.Godzilla 1998 is a bad movie. From the beginning of the movie, the script is not taking the original story into account. This origin of Godzilla does not feature anything related to extensive United States nuclear weapon testing. The origin simply has Godzilla appearing from mutated lizards found on Earth. It is not at all similar to the creatures created by Toho where they feed on radiation.The writing in this movie meanders trying to get the audience to care. It is hard to care when the characters are unlikable and are not even focused in this movie. The script wanted to make the movie about Godzilla and the destruction rather than about human characters. This would have been possible if Godzilla had more character. It is a creature for the humans in this movie to overcome rather than a separate entity with character.The action in this movie is tame. There could have been grander moments but the movie squanders these opportunities. The writing is to be blamed here for focusing too much on the bland human characters rather than on developing Godzilla through the human characters. The action goes from ridiculous set piece to ridiculous set piece that is not engaging to watch at all. There is not any tension in the scenes.I would not recommend Godzilla.Grade: D

Review title: Now to the Several Bad Points.....
Review_body: The only so far American directed and produced Godzilla film. Dean Delvin (producer) and Roland Emmerich (director) were the idiots behind this film and this movie is a sheer disappointment to me on several levels. With such a big budget, of course being an American film, they were so many possibilities crushed by these two 'geniuses'. To begin this review I'll mention a few positive notes. A very few. First off, obviously, the special effects and budget is bigger than any Godzilla film before or after it. The CGI is put to good use and GINO (Godzilla In Name Only) does look decent. There were some all right action scenes, but nothing to get too excited about. And that's about it...Now to the bad points. For starters, this shouldn't even been called a Godzilla movie. GINO looks nothing like Godzilla! Instead of seeing the imposing reptilian, original, looking-monster we get a mutant iguana who is now an asexual T-Rex with no heat ray with NO HEAT RAY!!! Who also is from time to time actually running away from the military! Also, none of the other G-films exist in this film's timeline, not even "Gojira"! Not a single reference or at least a cameo is made to any G-film or Japanese monster cinema in general! How crappy is that?! Secondly, I didn't like the cast, some who were bad actors. They only added to the non Godzillaness of the movie. Thirdly, the mood of the film is horrible. Godzilla was a victim of the H-bomb test. An invincible incarnation and physical manifestation of the Atomic Bomb. Even in the kiddy and campy days, Godzilla wasn't the giant mutant tarantula or grasshopper of the American 60s and 70s monster films. He was a different type of monster who broke the formula, something original. GINO is just the modern CGI version of those American crap monsters, a giant animal who was killed by jets pathetically. Which brings me to my next point- GINO is too weak and cowardly. Godzilla was invulnerable to tank shells and missiles and did not fear them. He in fact crushed them like bugs. Most of the actual city action/destruction was thanks to the military's bad aim, not GINO. Who, as mentioned before, runs away!! WTF? He wasn't even a threat really. Just a misunderstood giant asexual lizard who's only danger to society is comparable to that of multiplying locust and rabbits.I see Dean Delvin and Rolland Emmerich's whole scheme: Make a modern day giant monster film and to ensure its success they needed to use the name of the most popular monster on Earth: Godzilla. That's all they did, use his name. Those two had no respect for Godzilla, or the Japanese sci-fi genre at all. If they had, it certainly wouldn't have came out like this. That's one reason why I like "Godzilla: Final Wars". We finally see the real Godzilla blast GINO off the face of the Earth in a brisk 30 seconds!

The acting in this movie lets just say simply is atrocious. Matthew Broderick looked like he was just reading off of a teleprompter. Who's brilliant idea was it to cast Matthew Broderick of all people as an action hero? There's a reason that you haven't seen Maria Pitillo in any big movies since this. Kevin Dunn plays one of the most moronic military commanders ever.Since when does Godzilla run and hide? Or lay eggs for that matter? Godzilla is supposed to run through and knock over buildings not around them or climb them.All the baby Godzillas was something too much out of a Jurassic Park movie.Honestly I don't think that Roland Emmerich or Dean Devlin had ever seen a Godzilla movie prior to making this movie since this movie clearly doesn't deliver as a Godzilla movie at all.

I'm a big fan of Godzilla, and I was very excited for this movie. I remember getting Godzilla on video, and I use to watch it several times. I also remember watching it on television, and it was just as enjoyable. The movie was not poor as many people claim it to be, and I think it may be underrated. The plot was interesting. The only thing I didn't like about this movie was that there wasn't enough of Godzilla which was a surprise considering the name of this movie is: Godzilla. The movie would've been more better if we seen more of Godzilla. I can't believe the size of Godzilla. How did it get this large? Godzilla is a threat to everyone. The events takes place in New York City. A group of heroes/people team up to save their city. What I don't understand is why this movie gets a lot of hate. Yes, it does have a few problems, but so do a lot of movies out there. Maybe a lot of people were expecting this movie to be like previous Godzilla movies, but that's obviously not going to happen in Hollywood for now. Unlike other Godzilla movies, this Godzilla movie has a good story for audiences to follow. The movie is very long though, but I feel that's a good thing because Godzilla is entertaining for the most part. I could watch this again if I wanted to since it was enjoyable. It looks better with repeated viewings. Godzilla is an action, science-fiction and thriller movie. I'm astonished to the amount of reviews Godzilla has received on here. I assume a lot of people have something to say on this movie. You either like or dislike the movie. Well, I like Godzilla. There was enough action for everyone to enjoy. If you're a fan of Godzilla, you'd like it otherwise you won't. Godzilla is a very good movie. I think it deserves a high rating.

Review title: All special effects and little else.
Review_body: The new version of Godzilla is a total disaster of a movie. As far as the special effects are concerned, they were magnificent. The story was stupid and the acting was terrible. There are some great actors in this film and they are completely wasted. Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich like to say that they make "popcorn movies." This is really just a term they use to show that they didn't know how to be creative with a new Godzilla movie. This film is overlong and the scenes with the baby Godzilla's are a blatant rip-off of Jurassic Park. If you're only interested in the special effects, then check it out. If you like a good movie, watch something else.

Another good work by Roland Emmerich, but the film has some problems. The cast has strengths and weaknesses. Jean Reno is fine as are the other supporting actors, but the protagonists are not quite on the scene. Broderick is often naive and does not give credibility to the viewer, hindering the involvement with his character. Pitillo is terrible making the same face and expressions in practically all his scenes. Her character relationship with Broderick's is mentioned but at no time did we hope for the two of them to be together due to the lack of chemistry between the characters. The story explains how the originally Japanese monster ends up in New York. However, in action, the film gets a little lost by not defining itself in a single genre. In my opinion the film should be treated as a great suspense / terror, with the intention of showing in fact the horror caused by the lizard in the city, through the perspective of ordinary citizens, authorities and specialists. The big problem, perhaps, was to have given little emphasis to the monster that ends up appearing in less scenes than it should and when it appears, no expectations are created in the viewer. The action scenes and effects of the film are great, especially at night, but perhaps they have been used too much, and everything that is too much harms the end result of anything, especially on the big screen. Regarding visual effects, makeup and the action scenes themselves, we can't say anything since they become even more grandiose in the hands of the competent blockbuster director Roland Emmerich, although in most of them it's all a bit surreal, especially the escape of protagonists of Madison Square Garden when they are surrounded by dozens of monster pups. It is an authentic popcorn film by Emmerich, where the viewer knows what he will find: fantastic effects, even more fantastic action scenes, with a typical script for this type of film. It certainly amuses and always deserves to be seen. But your biggest problem may be just having more fun than scaring. The action scenes without exaggeration with a greater atmosphere of suspense would be perfect, more or less in the Alien style of Ridley Scott. But be sure to watch this great movie success at least once!Film seen on February 22, 2021.

Most Americans have only been exposed to heavily edited, badly dubbed versions of the old Godzilla films, and they judge these films to be poor based on incomplete information.  In the original Japanese, with more serious acting, the oft-derided Toho movies are actually quite good, if you can tolerate foreign special effects that are more imaginative than convincing.  This movie, on the other hand, is a dog in any language. 
The first Japanese Godzilla film is an exploration of the atomic threat; Godzilla is not so much a monster as he is a walking symbol of the nuclear bomb.  In this film, radiation does play a part in mutating Godzilla into a giant, stooped-over and ludicrous-looking iguana, but the "cautionary tale" aspect of the original concept is lost.  Godzilla is supposed to be a condemnation of America's use of the bomb, but in this film, we pawn off the blame for Godzilla's creation on the French - how lame is that?Ridiculous attempts have been made to make the creature more "realistic." It reproduces (just so we can have a "Jurassic Park" ripoff sequence involving raptor-like babies), it doesn't breathe radioactive fire (arguably the coolest thing about the old Godzilla - why change a thing like that?), and it's not indestructible (again, another cool trait of the original creature is lost).  The old Godzilla waded through buildings, fire, missiles, lasers, EVERYTHING, on a mission of total destruction; the American Godzilla runs around New York, squawking and burrowing underground like a camera-shy mole.  Pathetic.Godzilla is one of the greatest science fiction icons out there, despite the negative (and poorly informed) opinions of his American viewers.  This movie, however, is a poor tribute to the big G, and an astounding waste of money as well.  The original films are full of great imagery, ranging from poetic to just downright funky.  There are no compelling visuals here to equal the sight of Mothra hatching and spreading its wings in "GMK," or Godzilla squaring off against a three-headed gold dragon in the "Ghidorah" films, etc.  With all of the imaginative imagery removed, along with the Japanese culture, social commentary, and mysticism, the Godzilla concept is stale and ludicrous.As the closing credits for this movie began to roll, I groaned.  Audibly. That's the only time I've ever done something like that in a movie.  I mean, how hard is it to get this concept right?  All I wanted was a radiation-shooting, indestructible dinosaur smashing through a city.  I didn't even expect the subtexts to survive.  But my modest expectations were not met.  Godzilla is not only an inaccurate adaptation, it's also boring, and that's just plain unforgivable.

As opposed to most people, I thought this movie was excellent.  You can't watch the movie and expect Shakespeare...it's Godzilla.  You have to appreciate the work that went into making this creature look so lifelike. This movie had spectacular special effects and a pretty decent story line. I thought this movie was great.  I didn't find the acting to be all that bad.  I would recommend watching this movie before you come to any conclusions.

Review title: Has Roland Emmerich ever made an excellent movie??
Review_body: No, I don't think Roland Emmerich has ever made an excellent movie. Independence Day was good but that was his only good film. Godzilla was not good. Matthew Broderick was good in it but not as good as he was in Glory and The Lion King. What was Roland Emmerich thinking? I mean come on it's not the next Jurassic Park. I don't think Roland is a good director. I do want to see The Day After Tomorrow but I'm just worried if it's going to be terrible and I'd waste 6 dollars. I thought Godzilla was pretty entertaining and I did like some of the actors but that's all that's good about the movie. I also liked the songs and I bought the soundtrack but ignored seeing the movie the second time.5/10

I don't usually start like this, but...Come on guys, to all of you that thought this was a crummy movie, all I can say is...I loved it for several reasons.First off, it held tightly to the original 1950's movie concept, a mutated lizard from all the atomic bomb tests...Two, the movie let Godzilla be what he was, a frightening BIIG lizard, terrorizing New York City this time...And three, they inserted some fun, sometimes clever, humor into this outing, heh heh...Yes, it was fun watching this movie...not because of the humor involved, but because the movie actually has a soul, if you watch it closely...And yes, everytime I see this one, I remember that cute little Chiuahua in the Taco Bell commercials, going "Heere Zilli Zilla"...

Review title: Another good and well made Godzilla movie 6/10
Review_body:
As much as I'm surprised from how good the movie turned out to be, I got to admit it was really fun and enjoyable. The visual effects were good and better than I thought they would be, but they were still old, you can definitely tell the visual effects were from the late 90's and so it looks silly. Not like the visual effects in later years of Godzilla movies: (2014) and (2018). Even the character of Godzilla seemed a little funny and ridiculous. The updated version of him in the newer films looks better. Though I think the plot was more interesting than the plot we had in other of Godzilla's movies. Let's make a comparison: the movies of Godzilla today have a lot of green screen and CGI which is necessary but on the other hand takes control over the film. Which means the movie is left with characters screaming left and right and doing nothing.
Now with this version there is CGI and green screen but there is a bigger plot more interesting, with characters who do a lot and a bigger film set. Like it's not only green screen but real film locations. Overall an enjoyable film and it doesn't matter much which film of Godzilla you prefer, they'll likely be the same.

Review title: not as bad as the critics may presume
Review_body: Although i'm not a fan of Roland Emmerich, he's been able to surprise me with Anonymous (2011). However, i'm amused that Godzilla gets such low notes, especially since it is much better than his mind numbing efforts: Independence Day (1994), The Day After Tomorrow (2004), and 2012 (2009).Godzilla fulfills its purpose, especially since it used to be a fun flick to watch in the year of its release. Not a masterpiece, it is the one you go to see, have fun and forget when you get out of the theater. There are a lot of movies that tried very hard but failed to achieve this, among them the three aforementioned titles by the same author.There might be something we're missing in comparison with Japanese original, yet the transfer to Hollywood seemed successful to me.

Review title: Worst Movie Experience in my Life!
Review_body: If you want to know what the best movie experience of my life, it's Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire. It felt like I was in a grind-house theater where people from all sides had been cheering back and forth from the trailers to the beginning of the Warner Bros. logo. Girls were howling at Rupert Grint's arms, audiences of all ages were laughing at certain scenes and gasping at the special effects.Let me tell you the worst movie experience...I saw Godzilla on a Saturday in late May of 1998, the day of my middle school graduation. Sure the reviews weren't hot with the exception of Joel Siegel from Good Morning America saying how much fun it was; plus the film itself was marketing from commercials, action figures, trailers and interviewing the actors in all magazine publications from Disney Adventures to Nickelodeon.The plot of Godzilla involves the famous creature going from Japan to New York City where the monster wreaks havoc in town, causing panic on all sides. With the military involved, they hire field specialist Dr. Niko Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) to see where Godzilla is hiding and ask how to lure the beast into their tricks to kill him.Other characters include a French patriot (Jean Reno) who talks to witnesses from around the globe and tracks down Niko in New York to find any information leading towards Godzilla's hideout so him and his army could kill him before the marines. Maria Pitillo is Niko's ex-girlfriend who has dreams of being a reporter despite going out with the arrogant reporter (Harry Shearer) and being his little assistant.Not only is Godzilla too much of a long movie to be a blockbuster, but with many characters. I dealt with many things in the movie theater from hearing people booing at Godzilla because he wasn't the same as the earlier versions. Plus there was too many endings to think when the movie was going to be over along with the fact that somebody spilled soda on me.What a bad experience!

I was gutted after watching this, as I expected something excellent after the hype before it's release. I went to see it on it's opening weekend and switched off quarter the way through. The special effects were good for 1998 but it was boring. The characters were dull and it was too predictable.I don't recommend at all.

Review title: An enjoyable monster movie. But bad Godzilla movie
Review_body: Before the critically acclaimed GODZILLA 2014, Hollywood had attempted an Americanized remake of the classic Japanese monster back in 1998. They turned to Roland Emmerich, the man responsible for turning old B movie genres (alien invasion, otherworldly adventures and genetically enhanced soldiers) into big blockbuster hits. Hoping that he would do the same for the giant monster movie. To that end, Hollywood gave him Godzilla, the much beloved Japanese giant monster, to remake to his vision.Americanized, neutered and changed beyond recognition, GODZILLA came out as a decent monster movie, but a disappointing Godzilla movie. That issue lies in the portrayal of the titular Titan. Gone is the thought provoking nuclear disaster allegory, replaced by a feeble "man is the real monster" Aesop. Nuclear tests in the 1960s gave rise to a giant mutant bisexual lizard. This creature makes a beeline for Manhattan where his arrival is met with mass hysteria and chaos. Named "Godzilla" by the media (thanks to a misinterpreted comment from a dying Japanese sailor), America sends wave after wave of military hardware against the beast, causing more destruction than ever but failing to bring it down. Into this chaos comes dr Nick Tatopolus, an expert on radiation mutations. As the military tracks the monster through new york's concrete jungle, nick discovers that the creature may not be the only one of its kind for much longer. The hunt is on with French secret agents, a budding romance with a wannabe reporter and a parody of some well known movie critics all thrown in. The first thing that stood out for me in this movie was how enjoyable the scenes with the human characters were. Like INDEPENDENCE DAY, Roland Emmerich peppers this movie with a healthy dose of humor. This makes the one dimensional characters less of a pain to sit through. Hank Azaria, Kevin Dunn, Henry Shearer, all renown comedians, shine in their respective roles, delivering appropriate drama and laughs. Even Jean Reno does well as the offensively stereotyped French agent Philippe. Their scenes are fun, making an overall cliché ridden story more enjoyable than it is. Only the lead characters turn out a tad flat. Dr Nick, played by baby faced Matthew Broderick, brings his best "wide eyed" expressions to play as a man child caught up in the wonder of this giant beast yet running for his very life so he does not become dinner. Wide eyed shock, wide eyed awe, wide eyed terror, that seems to be his only expression. And the redundancy of Maria Pitillo's character Audrey cannot be understated.Of course, the true star of any Godzilla movie is Godzilla himself. This leaner, faster, velociraptor inspired look by designer Patrick Tatopolus is a terrific looking beast brought to life by cutting edge special effects. For a 1998 production, the effects still hold up well till today. The creature is elegant yet menacing, grand yet grim, with twin rows of fierce spikes on it's back, unbelievable agility and that trademark big chin that is common in Patrick Tatopolus' designs (eg: underworld's Lycans, pitch black's creatures, outlander's moorwen). However, it just isn't Godzilla, the unstoppable force of nature. It shows none of Godzilla's powers, nor his intelligence, nor his durability. Where the original Godzilla would be unfazed by missiles, smash tanks and planes out of his way, and carry on, this remade Godzilla squeals, runs and hides! Perhaps it would not have gotten that much hate had it been billed as a remake of THE BEAST FROM 20,000 FATHOMS, rather than a Godzilla movie. The basic plot of a lost giant creature drawn to New York and ultimately taken down by sheer luck and superior military firepower already mimics the broad strokes of that stop motion classic. Godzilla can easily pass off as a redesigned Rhedrosaur. But alas, here it is billed as a Godzilla movie. As a Godzilla movie, Roland Emmerich's multi million dollar blockbuster would rank in the lower thirds. Better than the likes of GODZILLA VS MEGALON, GODZILLA's REVENGE, GODZILLA FINAL WAR and GIGANTIS THE FIRE MONSTER. But compared to the rest of the Heisei era Godzilla movies, the early millennium era, and especially the original 1954 classic, this American remake is a disappointment. So disappointing in fact that the titular Titan of a lizard has been officially renamed "Zilla" by the original creators of the Godzilla franchise. I for one enjoyed this purely as a modern monster movie. It entertains, it has cool special effects, and it is good fun. Nothing much else though.

Godzilla 1998 is a re imagining of the original Godzilla rather than a continuation. In this version, Godzilla is a far more realistic beast. He is an iguana vastly mutated by atomic bomb testing in French Polynisia rather than a prehistoric monster coming out of hiding. Godzilla migrates to New York where he makes a home for himself in the sewage and subway systems, occasionally coming above ground to wreak havoc. While Godzilla is not a great movie, it is highly entertaining. In fact, it's more entertaining than the original films.I'll start with the good. First off, Roland Emmerich is like Irwin Allen for the new generation. He makes some really good sci-fi/action/disaster movies, even though they don't have great acting or writing, the plots and action scenes are entertaining. Roland Emmerich puts his style into the new Godzilla and it makes for some great action sequences including a couple of scenes of Godzilla tearing through New York. Every scene involving Godzilla is about as entertaining as you can get. This movie even shows what I would believe to be an accurate view of how far the U.S. Army will go to end a threat by showing the army blowing up buildings and streets in an attempt to stop Godzilla.Now with the bad. The actors cast in this movie aren't great. Matthew Broderick is really weak is Nick Tatopolous, the scientist trying to learn from Godzilla. Maria Pitillo absolutely sucks as Nick's love interest. Jean Reno is always pretty good, but he's just playing his average french action hero in this. Hank Azaria isn't a great actor, but he's okay in this due to his comic relief. Oh, and what's with the Simpsons alumni in this film? Harry Shearer (Mr. Burns, Smithers) plays Charles Caiman, Hank Azaria (Moe, Apu) plays Animal, and Nancy Cartwright (Bart) plays Caiman's secretary. The dialogue in this film isn't anything special. All of the touchy love scenes that they threw in for dramatic effect fall flat.Overall, an entertaining film, but not an accomplishment.6.5/10

Review title: This movie is bashed, way to much
Review_body: I never saw the original Japanese Godzilla, none of them. I've seen clips, and I basically know what it's about, but I have not seen them. Now that may be the reason I like this movie more than others. Believe me, if you are a fan of the Japanese Godzilla movies, I can totally understand why you would hate this movie. And even if you don't, it has flaws, I can see hating it even if you don't like the original. But despite it's flaws, it's many, many flaws, I do enjoy this movie.The CGI on Godzilla did not age well, at all. I mean at night he looks OK, at times. But whenever he appears during the day, and even at certain parts at night he just looks so fake. Maria Pitillo, the actress who played Audrey is horrible. I haven't seen her in anything else so I won't say she is a bad actress, but she certainly couldn't act in this movie. The Pacing is a little off, it doesn't get interesting until Godzilla hits New York. Before that it's very boring. And yes it has quite a few plot holes and errors in logic and continuity, and even geography.Yet despite all those flaws, it's a pretty fun movie to watch. Sure the CG on Godzilla isn't good, but the rest of the effects aren't bad. A lot of practical effects for the destruction of New York city. I actually really like Matthew Broderick in this movie, he's a likable enough protagonist. It does have enough action to keep you interested. From helicopter chases to running through Madison Square Garden while being chased by dinosaurs. There are some fun characters and it can be pretty funny at times.Is it a pretty bad remake, yes it is. Is it a rip off of Jurassic Park, yes it is. Does it have flaws, oh it sure as hell does. But is it fun to watch. For me it was. Yes I can totally see people not liking this movie, I understand. But I enjoy it. Take it for what it is, and it's a fun movie to watch.

Review title: We sure didn't get what we were longing for
Review_body: I sure was disappointed. I had expected a brainless film, yes, but on this level - no. After "ID4" I kinda expected more from these fellows, I wanted this big monster to trash the entire city, wreck EVERYTHING! Instead, it hides for the major part of the movie, and scenes from "Jurassic Park" are cut in instead (I'm referring to the Madison Square Garden sequences).Hammerich and Devlin didn't deliver this time. And all that built-up destructive state of mind that I had built up! Squandered! Wasted! Oh my, let's hope the obligatory sequels will offer some more destruction!

I really liked this since it didn't turn the creature into a monster. In the original the creature is a monster that wants to kill all the Japanese ... for some reason or another.In this remake Godzilla isn't a monster any more than the shark in Jaws. Yes it is dangerous and yes it is trying to survive but it has no intention like in the original.Besides the de-monsterization of the creature the discovery and realization of the creatures existence was done based on a scientific foundation - which is rare in the movies.So I liked this remake quite a bit except... for the blonde. The blonde utterly ruined the movie for me. #1 our hero is smart, hard-working, dedicated and focused. He's got his life together after being coldly dumped by none other than ... yep you guessed it - the blonde.So he's doing well when all of a sudden the news puts him on TV about some creature no one has seen but everyone is talking about. All of a sudden the blonde (whose career is taking a nosedive) sees him on TV and decides she loves him. (Remember she dumped him for her career... how convenient that now she chooses him.) If it wasn't for the forced and incredibly superficial needless worthless and pointless role of the blonde, this would have been a great movie... so I controlled by dissatisfaction for this detestable ingredient and decided the movie is better than all that ... yet no one agrees. :/ 9/10-LD______________________________________________my faith: http://www.angelfire.com/ny5/jbc33/

GodzillaStarring: Matthew Broderick, Jean Reno, Maria Pitillo, Kevin Dunn, Hank Azaria, Vicki Lewis, Harry Shearer and Malcolm DenareGenre: Action/Sci-Fi/ThrillerRated: PG-13This is another movie that a lot of people and critics have bashed on but once again I disagree. The movie is about Nick Tatopolous (Matthew Broderick) who mainly studies earthworms until the government reassigns him to an even bigger (and I do mean bigger) assignment than earthworms and that is the footprints of a giant lizard that attacked some Japanese ships. Of course the lizard turns out to be not other than Godzilla which ends up running out and causing havoc in New York. So now it's up to Nick Tatopolous, The Government, Philippe Roache (Jean Reno) and his French organization to stop Godzilla. Now I have never seen any of the original Godzilla movies (the ones that were made from Japan) but from looking at the original Godzilla, this one doesn't have the same characteristics as the original, the original Godzilla breathes fire and is invincible and this one in the movie doesn't breathe fire and is weaker since he gets shot down by missiles when the only thing that can defeat him is another monster. But I most say that I take the design of Godzilla in this movie more serious than the original Godzilla because this Godzilla looks cool and the original Godzilla to me looks funny looking. I didn't like the fact that they made this Godzilla lay eggs because male lizards cannot lay eggs and the whole egg bit was just an excuse for Roland Emmerich to copy off of Jurassic Park instead of staying true to the character. I did think it was funny that this movie spoofed Siskel & Ebert (even though I like Siskel & Ebert) which Roland Emmerich did because they have never gave thumbs up to any of his movies, but Roland didn't even take advantage of this joke and even Gene Siskel mentioned that Roland Emmerich should've taken advantage of putting the critics in this movie. I also thought some of the dialogue in this movie could have been way better but other than that everything else is alright. The movie even had a surviving egg at the end that was going to set it up for a sequel but it never happened due to all the negative reviews. I would've liked to see a sequel to this movie but at least I'm glad that they continued this movie in a cartoon series which was good. Overall just decent popcorn entertainment.
I actually enjoyed this movie but having watched it again 2019 I have to say the years have not been kind to this movie it's just a silly movie

Review title: Only bearable at the time for the special effects
Review_body: Starts with a good opening credits sequence that explains the origins of Godzilla, but then unfortunately the movie begins. We begin with the familiar formula of jumping around from one setup scene to the next, with the location identified on the bottom of the screen (using computer type font in a neon color with this strange typing sound effect). But these setup scenes serve no purpose though, as the opening credit sequence already explained Godzilla's origins sufficiently. This was the first sign that the writing is just terrible and there are many more. Admittedly trying to tell a believable story featuring 200 foot tall lizard is going to have its challenges, but this script bungles everything from character motivation to logistics and there are plot holes big enough for the aforementioned 200 foot tall lizard to walk through.The setup scenes also serve to introduce the human characters (another big mistake) for the audience. These include the brilliant scientist (Mathew Broderick), the mysterious French Insurance Investigator (Jean Reno), the ambitious young news room assistant who wants to be a reporter (Maria Pitillo) and the cameraman who just wants to help (Hanks Azaria). Both Broderick and Reno deserve some credit for trying and Reno actually manages to pull off most of his scenes, but you really have to wonder why he would want this on his resume. On the other hand Azaria looks lost along with most of the supporting players and Pitillo is just awful, though perhaps the aforementioned script can be at least partially to blame.To its credit the Special Effects are quite good if derivative of Jurassic Park and its sequel Lost World, the fact that the big effects sequences all happen at night in the rain allows the Effects artists ample opportunity to cover up any rough edges and make the combination of the background and effects all but seamless.There are a few laughs to be found, but they are far outweighed by the groans at the inane plot and some of the ill-advised attempts at humor (the Siskel and Ebert references are particularly cringe worthy).The filmmakers seem to have been trying to appeal to broad an audience and the result is that they don't satisfy any expectations. It's not scary enough (almost no excitement) for those looking for a thrill ride. It's not campy enough for those that enjoyed that element of the earlier Godzilla films. Also there is very little dram in any of the early scenes involving human characters, and the attempt at a love story between Broderick and Pitillo's characters is unnecessary, unconvincing and suffers every time Pitillo tries to express an emotion (she would win a Razzie for her performance).At the time of release it was only bearable for the special effects, and 20 years later those no longer stand up.

Review title: Great creature, but an ill-conceived mess with a glut of extraneous characters
Review_body: Certainly falls under the category of: What were they thinking? At the time that this went into production and was released, this seemed to be a sure thing as a popcorn summer hit. The duo behind the successful Independence Day would resurrect the Toho legend Godzilla from yesteryear to unleash a wave of destruction on New York. The film had massive awareness and was coming on the heels of the mega-hit Jurassic Park – so dinosaurs and their similars were definitely riding a wave of popularity.The film opens with depictions of nuclear testing by the French in the Pacific Ocean while indigenous lizards look on. Years later, this results in the gigantic mutation that is to become known as Godzilla. For some nonsensical reason, Godzilla starts swimming its way to New York City leaving a trail of underwhelming destruction in its wake. A group of disparate characters pool resources to locate the creature and end its rampage.Unfortunately, what should have been a sure thing here ends in a complete botch. The film is a haphazard mess hanging together by fraying threads.The visual effects are fairly strong, but the film keeps the creature off stage for practically the entire first half and then depicts most of its appearances in rainy darkness. Truthfully, has New York City ever been the victim of such an endless spate of torrential storms as is depicted in this film? The story is fairly asinine. It concocts a barely logical reason for Godzilla's sudden swim to NYC, but the destruction that the creature leaves in its path is so minimal that one wonders why so much military and scientific effort is put into the search for the creature. Indeed, NYC survives largely unscathed from Godzilla's wrath and few people seem in any genuine danger from the creature. A good deal of the destruction, in fact, comes from the blunders of the military in trying to detain the creature. Additionally, we are told that the creature is able to hide within the underground subway system, but given the enormous size of the creature that seems highly unlikely.Additionally, the film is absent of nearly any tension. Director Roland Emmerich imbues everything with such a strangely light-hearted tone that there is no urgency to this material or the ho-hum action scenes that he creates. In fact, the film only truly comes to life in the final 20 minutes and at that point it is simply too late and altogether too brief to salvage this sinking ship. Additionally, once we have the back story, it is hard to feel threatened by or root for the death of the title creature. In fact, some degree of kudos must go to the effects team and screenplay for drumming up sympathy for the creature's plight, particularly in its final moments on screen.By contrast, the people populating this foolishness should be so sympathetic. There are so many useless extraneous characters introduced into the action that one about needs a score card to keep trackand none of them are killed by the creature. We get Matthew Broderick's dorky scientist, French agent Jean Reno, reporter Maria Pitillo, cameraman Hank Azaria and his blowzy wife Arabella Field, Vicki Lewis' scientist and her assistant Malcolm Danare, military colonel Kevin Dunn, ineffectual mayor Michael Lerner and his assistant Lonny Goldman. The ideas on character development revolve around making Lerner and Goldman an idiotic riff on Siskel and Ebert and Reno a coffee fancier always on the hunt for a great cup of java. The film would not have suffered in the least by cutting or combining any number of these roles. For instance, the Pitillo and Lewis role could easily have been combined into one (preferably Lewis since Pitillo is a nightmare).Acting-wise, the film is equally lamentable. Broderick is all wrong to carry an action film and often comes across as a double holding the stage until the real leading man shows up. Azaria seems game, but Reno looks justifiably bored. The worst performance, hands down, comes from Pitillo, who spends the film whining, crying, pouting and delivering her lines in a voice that reminds one of a low-rent Betty Boop. Simply excruciating.

Roland Emmerich's Godzilla failed with geek-boys who were mad the film didn't feature a man in a rubber suit.  It angered elitists because they couldn't imagine themselves enjoying a film about a giant lizard in a city. However, I found myself pleasantly surprised with this picture, and that is why I am coming to the defense of my friend Godzilla.  The Japanese can keep their guy in the rubber suit, I like this Godzilla, because he's mean and ugly and he has cravings for fish.  I like the way he storms through New York City like he owns the place and decides to give a little hell to Matthew Broderick, Hank Azaria, and Jean Reno.I found Godzilla had exactly what I expected out this type of picture: havoc!  I walked out of Spider-Man yesterday very disappointed.  I felt disappointed because it wasn't able to have fun with itself like most summer pictures do.  I walked into a store, and their I saw my old buddy Godzilla sitting on the used DVD rack.  I picked the little guy up, took him home, and enjoyed the hell out of him.  Just like a summer popcorn film should be: BIG, DUMB, AND FUN.  This movie is a hoot!

Review title: A Bad Goji Film, But A Good Gino One IMHO
Review_body:
Gino (Godzilla In Name Only) gets his time to shine in this fairly entertaining American Kaiju flick.
This is a rather lackluster effort as a Godzilla film, but Gino is a pretty cool monster in his/her own right and this is passable entertainment.All-in-all a solid American monster flick that is disappointing if viewed as part of the Godzilla series.
Really good film with some great characters. Picture is really good for a 98 film and the film on a whole was really well done.

Review title: i dont care if it sucks
Review_body: This is an entertaining movie, so i like it anyway, and if you don't agree then fight me

Review title: Godzilla A Good Remake But Overlong
Review_body: Godzilla is a good remake but overlong from director Roland Emmerich whose admirable in making this movie but a slow pacing at times and a predictable ending is what weighed it down but it's still not that bad it just could've been better. The cast for the most part are solid in their roles including Matthew Broderick, Jean Reno, Maria Pittillo, Hank Azaria, and Kevin Dunn. The rest of the cast are good in their roles as well but don't have much to do. The special effects are impressive especially for that time and it does off some suspense. The Godzilla creature is cool but you can tell it's CG most of the time and seemed to resemble a giant version of the raptors in Jurassica Park movies. Godzilla looked terrific none the less showing audiences glimpses of it first before revealing what looks like in full view. The action sequences are well executed and there is some comic relief mostly because of Azaria. The pacing of the movie was a little slow at times but once the action kicks into high gear things seemed to movie at a steady pace from there. The surprise at the end I saw coming and does sort of leave it open for a possible sequel but if they had changed the conclusion the film would've been a little better. Overall despite its flaws, Godzilla is for the most part an entertaining film with enough action, cool special effects, some suspense, thrills, humor, a little romance, and decent performances by the cast who make it worthing watching at least once.

Review title: only 5.3 / 10 stars do not do it justice
Review_body:
Amazing (!!) special effects and great movie for it's time.
It isn't quite Godzilla since they changed the creature quite a bit, but I still think it's an approach worth being made and looked at.
There's build-up to the story with the science etc., first time Godzilla appears is epic.
Give it a chance. I think a lot of ratings here are way too low and this movie definitely deserves more than 5.3. Maybe my 10* are too high and it should be more like a 7, but I need to see a higher score for it in total.

I am a huge Godzilla fan. So when I first heard an American Godzilla was going to be made I thought that was pretty cool. However I was thoroughly disappointed.Nuclear bombs alter an iguana or something and it turns super big and becomes "Godzilla".,...............thats it for story pretty much.I really hated this movie because this is nothing like how Godzilla is in the great Japanese movies. He is not a dinosaur in this one, just a big lizard and his character in this has no heart it feels. Hes also got no personality. Also he does not really attack the city, he just runs around and when the army attacks him he runs away. Finally he cant even breathe radioactive fire. What were they thinking? You can alter certain things about a character if they aren't important, but these are all well established and important character traits of Godzilla that were all not done well at all.Also this movie is a downer cause it rains the whole movie. I just think it makes you get a bad feeling when watching it.The human cast was OK, I actually like Matthew Broderick. Hank Azaria is cool, but other than that nothing special.Basically this is not the Godzilla I grew up to love as a kid. I do not recommend this horrible film.
Better then Godzilla vs Kong. Yup i said it and I'm right.

Review title: It's big, it's scary, it's loud it's Godzilla!
Review_body: Yep, Hollywood did it again. They took yet another Japanese star and turn it into a movie, this time under the direction of Roland Emmerich. Now I will never, ever deny that I enjoy this film, I really do. I always wanted it in my collection, I was amazed by the trailer and I was blown away by the film but in all that shock and awe alas the movie is one large, noisy turd as most of the Emmerich films. But, I got to admit, Emmerich can make some highly entertaining turd films. And I think this is one of my favorite of all Emmerich films ever I still have it in my DVD collection. Now, if you have watched the original Gojira (1954), then you realize that you are expecting a totally different story. First the movie opens with atomic bomb footage, in French Polynesia, something big emerged from the depths and attacked a Japanese fishing ship. Yep, that's one of those "slap in the face" scenes, where the writer, or director wants to say to the original Japanese film – our monster is better! Well talking about ego. And after that, another accident occurred, this time with US fishing boats. Now that's entirely different from Japanese movies. In their movies we saw Godzilla fights numerous monsters, aliens and even King Kong but the Americans are the one who increased the plot with the Godzilla's plans to make a nest in New York where else? But, the idea of nesting? Hmmm well, I guess that we needed a new idea for a big lizard. And it's not male, or female, it breeds asexual. Although I thought that there are two big lizards, but fortunately I was wrong, and good thing I was wrong. So, the story is simply American in a simple American way. It's bearable.Time for actors: Matthew Broderick as Dr. Tatopoulos. Matthew was definitively very well payed for this film, so he looked all the time without any emotions, he was just staring at people and stuff and a big lizard and talk in his usual youngster voice and the guy never seems to get old. But, what I like about his performance that he constantly looked funny, especially in Madison Square Garden scenes, he entertained me pretty enough. Jean Reno plays Philippe Roache the French intelligence agent who came to "clean up his sh*t". What do I mean by that? Now this is not a big spoiler the French atomic testing were done by French people and that's why Roache (his last name was there to make ridicule of him) is here. Reno was good, in his own French guy in US element. He was the badass of the film. We have Maria Pitillo as Audrey Timmonds, a former girlfriend of Nick's. Pitillo was so funny, so bad in her performance, no wonder you didn't saw her anywhere else in other films, this film remains the best known in her career. Hank Azaria? Oh, that's not all. Harry Shearer and Nancy Cartwright are also in the film. Moe the Bartender , Mr. Burns and Bart Simpson are in the film? What was that for? You expect for American audience to recognize them? To recognize their voices? Well, maybe some of them maybe know but that does not helping! Hank and Harry were funny well it was their job to be funny in the film. We also have Kevin Dunn and Doug Savant, they were good but somehow aw f**ck it, they were all funny in their performances, it's like you are watching a film based upon a world where everyone is comedian except Japanese and the monster itself. To also mention Michael Lerner's appearance in the film as Mayor Ebert yep, you are right another slap in the face to the two famous, respected and hated critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert, who obviously didn't like Roland's previous films.When it comes to the monster design, I won't lie to you I kinda liked it. It was an idea that Godzilla mutated from ordinary Iguana, but when you look at it, It doesn't even look nearly as Iguana. This Godzilla is more lean, to make him more faster and more well built for swimming. So it's not that bad. Overall, this is one large, imposing turd of a film. It's your opinion you like it, or you don't. And I do, because I think that the movie is very entertaining. But I do not include the humor in the film not all the time. I mean the script is just ridiculous, CGI is not bad, it's very good at some scenes, visuals are good, camera work – not bad, I like the underwater scenes, sound effects are brilliant, but I think the best thing is the music score by David Arnold, it's powerful and it presents monster pretty good. So no matter how amused I were it's still that's a lot of turdAnd one more thing Hollywood stop touching Japanese things

I don't know if I can find a single redeeming quality about this movie.It starts with a bunch of stock footage of lizards...? And, I'll get this out of the way fast, this thing is way too long, from the starts, the credits seem to be on the screen for like 5 minutes, is insane. It's just a bad way to start your movie.I didn't give a damn about any of the characters. The romance between Matthew Broderick and Maria Pitillo is just so poorly written. Why are we supposed to feel for her? We were told she dumped the guy, when he asked her to marry him, then in their first interaction in 8 YEARS she stoles from him and gets him fired! Wtf? How are we supposed to give a damn? And root for her? For them? I hated her character, I hated her camera friend, the only reason I didn't have Niko is because is Matthew Broderick, but I didn't like him either. And we have so much screen time to this whole subplot of Audrey wanting to be a reporter... my god, I hated this movie.Finally, Godzilla. Let's get another thing out of the way. He... gets bigger and smaller throughout the film, for some reason. Look, I get the bad CGI, sort of, it was 1998 (The Phantom Menace and The Matrix came out just a year after, but ok), the CGI is trash, the movie does not holds up, but man, how can't you not do the thing with a consistent size? I have to assume it is not that hard, since you are already doing a CGI monster. And again, so many weird things that go unexplained, where did he come from at the end? Was it another one? Did he come from the tunnels? How didn't anyone notice the body was missing from the bay? Since they specifically say they were going to get the body out of the water? What happened to that?Look, idk what else to say, but truly, the biggest flaw here is that this thing is so damn long (why having them basically kill it three times?) and also takes itself too seriously. And I mean, the mini Godzilla are eating popcorn at some point. C'mon!Almost forgot: It might be a nitpick, but in the first hour or so, they put place's name in the screen a lot! Like, some scenes character are somewhere, and you get a introduction, then you cut to another place (that's also introduced), and then again, you come back to the first place, that's introduced again!!! Why?! Are we that dumb?Anyways, the movie is bad, I wouldn't recommend it, it isn't even those movies that are so bad they are good. This one is just bad.

I am AMAZED at how people constantly dump on Emmerich's Godzilla - probably his best-crafted film, overall, and a really sharp piece of entertainment by any standard.What more could you *expect* of a film by this title? This Godzilla is both a reverent remake and a very welcome technical upgrade of those silly Japanese films. Humor perfectly balanced against thrills. Better characters than usual for an Emmerich flick. Great action sequences, credibly embedded in real-world locations. Even a bit of sympathy for the big green lizard. What the $&%#@ else do people want???Oh, sure... this ain't yer Papa-san's Gojira. So what? Aside from the very first black-and-white film (and then only in its original Japanese version), that series was a joke almost before it started. Emmerich's Godzilla is a more athletic beast, but it's actually believable enough to be frightening, and it's got a personality that actually works. (Could it really hide down in the subways? Hm, let me get my tape measure... Oh, wait a minute: who cares??)I could have done without the Siskel-and-Ebert in-joke, but hey, Emmerich deserves a chance to have a little fun like the rest of us. And it balances out, anyway, against his hilarious use of the French secret service. (Why the French? Why *not*? In all those James Bond movies, why do the British always have to solve the world's problems?)I've enjoyed all of Emmerich's films enormously... though I do find Independence Day a bit hard to take. (Just a smidgen too much humor in that one.) Even 10,000 BC surprised me, improving a great deal on a second viewing. (A question of expectations; I was looking for a semi-remake of One Million Years BC.)These pure-entertainment, CGI-heavy films may seem trivial, but not a lot of directors can crank them out as reliably as Emmerich. He'll never be mistaken for another Fellini, but so what - the opposite is equally true. While I certainly do like to pull out La Strada or 8-1/2 every decade or so, I've watched my DVD of Godzilla at least a half-dozen times... it's an E-ticket carnival ride I'll never get tired of.

In 1998, Godzilla got an American make-over by "Independence Day" director Roland Emmerich and audiences haven't stopped complaining since. Rather than make the atypical Godzilla film, Emmerich and his co-conspirator Dean Devlin took the "Jurassic Park" approach and turned the mega-monster into a really, really big T-Rex and instead of using aliens, bad weather or the apocalypse as an excuse to destroy a city, decided it would be best to watch the beast all but devour Manhattan. In the rain.The first thing that will likely hit you upon your first viewing of "Godzilla" is "well, that wasn't so bad," but then you come to the ultimate conclusion that, well, it wasn't as good as it could have been, either. Emmerich, who surely knows how to turn out an entertaining popcorn flick (often at the expense of logic and character development) puts on a good show here, with solid special effects, fun chase scenes and lots of lots of destruction. Matthew Broderick takes the lead as a scientist brought in by the military to try and tame the savage beast. For the most part, the film works, but where it really falls apart is in some of its atrocious acting (Maria Patillo, I'm looking at you) drawn-out plot and it's seemingy endless series of endings. Seriously, the movie feels like it's over once it hits the hour and fifty minute mark, but intead overstays its welcome by becoming more ridiculous by the moment and not knowing when to stop.Perhaps a better editor could have tightened up the film and made it more enjoyable to the end. Hell, one can't imagine why Columbia Tri-Star didn't step in and take it down a notch, when most other studios are all too eager to trim big and bloated block-busters. Given the time and the patience, and with the right mindset (more specifically -- the mindset that is earned by checking your brain at the door) "Godzilla" is an overall entertaining film with its redeeming moments, but is perhaps one that could never live up to all the hype.On a side note, the film's famous ad-campaign featured the tagline: "Size Does Matter." Well, in spite of the innuendo, the film certainly supports that theory by proving that a film too big and too long simply doesn't cut it.

Review title: It wasn't the worst, but it was a huge ripoff.
Review_body: I'll never forget the time when I was 13 and there were trailers of a new Godzilla movie and I was so looking forward to it because it looked so cool! I was crushingly disappointed because of how fake the creature looked and how he looked so dark and unidentifiable in some shots, then bright orange in other shots.

Review title: Not Much Fun Like Independence Day
Review_body: This is a really stupid movie, but I guess one could try to enjoy it if they think of it simply as a "popcorn" movie. sold tickets, but it lacks in quality. Why couldn't this live up to the fun provided in Independence Day?The first thing this film lacks is a solid cast. The only actor I really liked in this film was Jean Reno, and I guess since his character was quirky Matthew Broderick did an okay job. I cannot stand the actress who played Audrey, nor the character itself. Her character has no depth whatsoever, and seems to be placed into this movie simply as a love interest to Nick (Broderick). She is a really stupid character, asking bluntly if Nick is still mad for her leaving him, crying like a baby (seriously, it is so childish) when Nick leaves after she steals his tape, and offering the least sincere apology I have ever seen. And why are there 3 or 4 Simpsons voice actors in the cast? Hank Azaria's character can be funny at moments, but he definitely does not belong in this action flick.The CGI looks really bad, which is disappointing since Independence Day's effects didn't look too bad. That's all I have to say on that aspect.As for the pace of the film, while this movie brings Godzilla into play sooner than the more recent version, this movie is overly long for a monster movie. It takes forever for the movie to get to the second BIG fight with Godzilla where they fight him in the waters of Manhattan. This could have happened 30 minutes earlier and the film would have been on a good pace, but this movie insisted on playing things slow between each action sequence, though the action sequences can be long (especially when they get to Madison Square Garden) and somewhat fun to watch. However, if you examine the sequence with the babies hatching and attacking Nick and crew, it rips off a lot of shots of the velociraptors in Jurassic Park. The only difference is that these dinosaur-like creatures are taller.This movie had potential but fell very flat compared to that potential. I wish I could laugh at this movie like other bad movies, but to me this movie was just plain bad.

First of all, I don't consider this a Godzilla movie at all. No wonder Godzilla-fans call this Godzilla "GINO" ("Godzilla In Name Only"). This is because the Godzilla here doesn't look like the real Godzilla at all, but more like a Tyrannosaurus Rex. I just don't get why Hollywood so often have to make own versions that tend to be worse than the originals. Anyway, if you forget all the Godzilla-stuff, then this is an OK disaster movie. Taking place mostly in Manhattan, New York, I guess everyone can figure out what happens. The movie is entertaining and has some good special effects, but I think they should have ended it much earlier. The last 20-25 minutes was really too much, as it had been more than enough action in the movie before that.

I love this film, it's really fun and inventive! Great way to spend a couple of hours.I am pretty unhappy with the amount of hate the film gets; it's good! Too much CGI for my tastes generally but because I can remember being a little kid in the cinema watching it I've got a soft spot for it.Performances are good, casting is good, plot is good, music is good, it's all fine! Watch this film! And enjoy it!

I remember the days of being a young child, Godzilla was everything to me back then. Of course I had to order all the films off of ebay or be lucky enough to find one at the video store, but this was easy to have seen. As a child I was completely thrilled by this film and even cried at the ending when I was young, but have since turned my back on to it after I read all these reviews hating it, what were they looking for, the meaning of life? Get real it's a monster movie. I finally picked up the Blu-ray and I must say it was still a blast, I recommend the Blu-ray, it enhances the action scenes very well. Sure the characters were mediocre and the dialogue is a hit or a miss, but I can look past that. The visual's still look decent and the special effects are cool to see. This film is not a Godzilla film, he is very different from the original, mainly he can be injured from missiles. I kind of like his design here, it's not bad. The ending was a set up to a sequel that never happened. But of course there was the animated series. I would have loved a sequel were he fought another monster. Comparing the two Godzilla's is a no brain'er, the Japanese one is superior in every way. I could go on for a few more paragraphs of talking about this, but instead I'm going to cut it short. It's a fun movie and is very entertaining. Give it a watch, but keep in mind it's just a monster movie and should not be viewed as anything else.

There are so many flaws in this movie it's terrific. You actually lose count. Noise level is constantly high. Nearly the whole movie was shot in the dark at night. The army blows up more buildings than Godzilla destroys, etc. I don't want say more.

Review title: Who's worse? Ed Wood or Roland Emmerich?
Review_body: It's hard to say.  It's pretty tough to top Ed Wood.  However, this has got to be the s**ttiest movie I have ever laid eyes on!  It's badly acted and has a dumb plot(Oops, I forgot.  There is no plot.).  Not to mention the fact that the old Godzilla in a rubber suit has gone to hell to make room for this loser.  The only good that came out of making this was that it bombed in theaters.  For once, audiences fought back, reminding the idiots that made this thing that people won't stand for s**tty movies, even if they do have special effects.  I've seen effects movies that actually have plots. The special effects in this movie serve as junk food for the brains, and are the only saving grace for the entire movie.  And even the effects don't please the eye!  This movie does injustice to the big fella, as well as audiences who thought they were coming to a good movie.  I don't even know why I'm wasting my time writing about this!  I guess it's meant to warn you to save your money and your time for something better.

Review title: Not Godzilla, but not bad either.
Review_body: As a genuine fan of the original Japanese Godzilla films, I have heard millions of negative comments about this film. The problem here is the fact that the creature is given then name Godzilla, but in the beginning, it is clear that it's not ACTUALLY Godzilla. A survivor of a Japanese fishing crew was asked, what did he see, and he knew only to answer "Godzilla" because that's probably what he thought it was, but this survivor only saw a claw or a foot. It's clear this monster is not meant to actually be Godzilla, so the main mistake this movie made was naming the creature Godzilla. I saw it when it came out in Theaters back in 1998. It's not a bad movie, it's watchable, it's not horrific and terrible in my opinion. I would watch it again, but I wouldn't call it Godzilla.

Some people may not like this movie, and some people may like it like me. I thought it was great I saw it twice in theaters. The only thing I didn't like was the weakness of Godzilla. I think they should of a least added another monster.
I give it 8 out of 10

This was really the early stages of when Hollywood poured all the CGI to create its effects. It all began in the 90's and Godzilla 1998 was one of the first blockbuster Science Fiction monster movies to start the trend. In an age where remakes are told in a newer and updated version there are those who still yearn for the prototypical creations that began yesteryear.This Godzilla is sort of a culmination of a giant monster action film and Jurassic Park. The characters are all familiar and likable. Throw in a love interest subplot along a plot involving scientific experiments gone haywire and civic corruption and you have Godzilla 1998. The special effects are good and there are some laughs. Godzilla the creature looks different than the earlier creations played by men in rubber suits. This Godzilla is actually a much prettier, sleek and elusive reptilian. He doesn't breathe gas or fire, but just simply leaps and swims in a lithe and sexy way. He doesn't even cause much destruction or human death. He just runs around in a leering and menacing way. He's actually rather pathetic since he doesn't cause much havoc, but rather gets enough abuse from gunfire and explosive rockets from the U.S. National Guard. The old Godzilla was a much more formidable villain as he destroyed many lives and buildings. The new Godzilla leaves mass destruction in his wake, but doesn't assume as many victims. I guess if he did they would have to ratchet up the rating to R.

Review title: One of the first "scary" movies I saw; a cherished childhood memory, actually
Review_body: I really do, genuinely enjoy Godzilla. I have watched it on numerous occasions for a long time now and I always think it is an incredibly fun and entertaining movie. The first time I watched it though was when I was around four years young. It was one of the first, as I called it then, scary movies I watched.I actually will never find the strength to call this film horrible, even though my opinions on it have of course lowered a lot over time, because I watched it when I was so little, and I thought it was the best movie ever. This film is still really enjoyable, because it's value doesn't decrease as much as the person who watches it entertainment does, but it still sickens me to know it has such a low rating and many look down on it, while really it should receive more appreciation.I might have lowered my opinions on this film, but it is still a pleasing film that does not deserve the rating it has. I didn't see much of anything wrong with it, even now, and I just thought it was suspenseful and exciting, somewhat more suspenseful than a lot of other movies that have been made, with a lot of fun performances and excellent CGI. Godzilla, yet classified as a horror\suspense, was actually a touching film and was sad in some parts, as well. I will never understand how someone could hate a film that's just meant to be all around fun and enjoyment. It is still my favorite out of the original and newest remake.Two thumbs up for Godzilla.

Review title: He still looks like a man in a rubber suit
Review_body: The special effects are amazing, and the action scenes of the monster thud-thudding through the streets of Manhattan chasing or being chased by humans are extremely well put together.  Matthew Broderick has just the right tone of amused irony. It drags whenever the monsters are off-camera, however, and that unfortunately includes one long section in the middle I wouldn't sit through again if you paid me.  The thing I liked best about the movie was the way the whole thing is shrouded in darkness and rain.  I don't expect many to agree with that, but it made it bearable for me. In fact, as the movie went on and I realized it was never going to clear up, my respect for the makers of this movie went up.  They probably did it to avoid having to show the monsters in broad daylight, and saved themselves a ton of editing thereby, but the effect when you watch it is of someone pulling off a deliberate stunt just for the sheer artistic fun of it.  The other thing I liked about it is the way the big monster still looks a little bit like a man in a rubber suit despite being a state-of-the-art computer animation.  A nice touch, which we can always hope was deliberate.

I know I say by first say "where was Godzilla?" This update done by the same people who gave us the big alien invasion "ID4" a few years screwed up!!The movie had more humans talking endlessly and very little of Godzilla!!I might as well watch all the old Toho videos at the video store!!plus it rip-offed one of my favorite summer movies"Jurassic Park" at the end in the staduim!!!On the good side it has some great special effects!!!Otherwise watch only if you like the movies stars and the movie's biggest star "Godzilla" who's hardly ever on screen!!!

Review title: It's not meant to be a triumph, just meant to entertain, and that's what it did.
Review_body: This was a good, not great, but good movie. I thought the special effects were terrific, and the humor, action, and sound was great. All-in-all, an entertaining popcorn movie, that's big, loud, and fun. 7 out of 10.

I'm a Godzilla fan. So you can imagine my anguish at seeing Godzilla for the first time. Part of Godzilla's magic is that his movies are corny. A guy in a rubber suit fights other guys in rubber suits. Bad dubbing, bad music, and fun for all. Godzilla shouldn't have been made because what kills Godzilla, besides the fact that he looks like no Godzilla before him, is special effects. State of the art CGI is unwelcome in a Godzilla movie, and the production team of Devlin and Emmerich deserved a bomb after the undeserved success of Independence Day. The cast is disposable just like real Godzilla movies. New York takes a little beating and the army gets humiliated. Everything is in place except for the Godzilla that isn't. Bottom Line: This is a movie that should never have been made. That said, you shouldn't be seeing it.

Review title: A large pile of stinking fish sums this up perfectly
Review_body: OK, despite all the money that this movie somehow made, this is pure garbage from start to finish. The story is as non existent as much as the acting. In retrospect almost everyone ever involved with this now regrets the final product. There's no point in me summarising the plot as it's been done and there isn't much of a plot anyway but I wanted to at least weigh in on why this is so abysmal. I've watched this several times and each time I'm left scratching my head over what the hell is everybody doing. It struggles to be funny with several running gags throughout the movie but they all come off as being lame attempts at cheap laughs. Like bad dad jokes they just get more and more annoying as the movie digs its own grave while trying to generate a laugh. I was never sure which was worse, the various cast constantly mispronouncing the name Tatopoulos or the head of the French secret service trying and failing to get a decent cup of coffee. There was just so much in this that never made any sense and the whole thing seems to be an exposition in how not to make a movie. I could never work out why the U.S ground forces in and around New York were all controlled by a bungling and inept Sergeant of all things; I'd expect a Lieutenant or Captain at least. Why would a worm scientist be the go-to guy for a reptile? Why not a reptile specialist? If you're in a helicopter and Godzila is chasing you, why fly straight? Why not go up? Why can't the French secret service speak English properly? Why do an Elvis impersonation under the guise that all Americans speak that way? And why would that fool anyone? How does a giant lizard manage to make it all the way to Manhattan, creating mass devastation along the way and not have the story leaked to any number of media outlets? If the tape of the first sighting was so security sensitive why was it left unsecured and in the hands of a civilian so anyone could get at it? Why would an animal as large as Godzilla assume that NYC, one of the most densely populated islands, is the best place to spawn after it's been relentlessly attacked since it got there and it's an unnatural environment? How would a lizard, regardless of size, know what a submarine is or how to destroy one using their own torpedoes? When the baby Godzillas are roaming around, why are they seen eating popcorn when their diet is mostly fish? The French guy is the one who's driving the taxi during a crisis and knows how to get to the Brooklyn Bridge! What's worse is that Godzilla also somehow knows where the Brooklyn Bridge is, manages to get there first and pops up in the right spot in order to cut them off! And it goes on and on like this and it never redeems itself until the credits start to roll. I can accept a big dumb monster movie but I'd still prefer it to showcase some kind of logic and have a plot worth following. I think everyone in this was miscast and for me that made the movie even more painful to watch. The combination of Godzilla destroying every building it touched or grazed against coupled with the whiz-bang U.S military gleefully destroying everything else, makes for good special effects but does little for common sense. This didn't have any of the essence of what gave Godzilla such a dedicated fan base in the first place and highlights that Hollywood directors should leave well enough alone if they're not going to be bothered with doing justice to an iconic character. It's little wonder they never ended up doing a sequel, it would've been like trying to remove glue from hair after this colossal debacle.

Review title: Excellent special effects, but that's about all
Review_body: Some people hate this adaptation of the classic movie. While the film is tolerable, it certainly is a disappointment. The screenplay is the biggest problem. It's very derivative and predictable, yet has dumb characters and some poor dialogue. Parts of it obviously copy "The Lost World" and the scenes in the nest of hatch-lings are obviously copied from the raptor attack scenes from "Jurassic Park." Since the monster on the loose story has been done so many times, they should have had a few original ideas. In spite of all the shortcomings, the film has its good points. It makes good use of the New York City locations and has excellent visual effects that provide for a few good scares and chase scenes. It wasn't the worst movie in the world.

The reference to a possible rebellion of nature is certainly right. The danger of a revenge of animals against man is around the corner! The nature against technology. This is one of the best movies about Godzilla! Good, really Good. It has an origin mostly comic but has good special effects. It was inevitable to see negative comments here, is the norm. Cmq a good movie, the environments are good actors suited to the type of film. He certainly part ironic, comic, the environments are very well linked to those of fantascientific and the result can be considered as satisfactory. It is a shame that here there are elements that bring more than 7 film ridiculous as the army of darkness and films such as van helsing a miserable 5. Shame! I disagree with the standards is happening here, I am not convinced. In some cases there are good reviews, in other see that there are some 'too many prejudices against certain films! The reference to a possible rebellion of nature is certainly right. The danger of a revenge of animals against man is around the corner!

I haven't seen this since it played in theaters in 1998, but if memory serves me right, the title sequence was low-key and evocative, very well-done. But after that, the picture goes way down. Matthew Broderick is miscast horrendously as a heroic type, and Maria Pitillo is a terrible actress, playing an absurd character. As in "Independence Day", the producers start off with the attack, so that there's nothing really to climax. The Japanese Godzilla and his ilk and all those wonderful 1950s monster mashes always had the delirious rampages in the final acts. The film has an annoying rainstorm in New York City during most of the proceedings, and is almost always at night. Is this to cover up inadequate CGI effects?
