The trailer seen months before had the famous Godzilla roar, but here he looks or sounds NOTHING like the Japanese classic dragon/tyrannosaurus/stegosaurus. The creature breathes no fire, makes little sounds or even tramples buildings. He even disappears half-way through the film! The climax is assinine since a taxi can not outrun a 200-foot animal. Dreadful.

I will admit that while this film isn't that great, in fact it is bad, it's a lot better than people make it out to be. I mean I can see why people hated the Godzilla in it, I mean he looks sort of silly. I can also see why people would hate the fact that there is next to no character development in it. But in some cases, not many though, I thought there was a sort of clever moment. Or something funny like the line 'that's a lot of fish'. I also thought the effects were sort of decent. Far better than some other effects of movies that I have seen recently. So that deserves some points. The film is more boring than bad in my eyes. I never really saw it as bad but I was pretty bored throughout most of it. I will admit and I feel like I will be one of the few to say this but I thought that Matthew Brodreick (sorry if I misspell the last name) actually put up a decent enough performance. Enough to where I can feel some moments were he did a good job. Overall, still a bad movie but some parts and things that I liked. So I will give this a three out of ten

Review title: Roland Emmerich is a blithering incompetent
Review_body: Oh sure, he can put purty pitchers on the screen, but he has not the slightest idea of how to actually make those images into a movie (just for that asinine in-joke about "Ebert" and "Gene," Emmerich should be forbidden ever to get near a film camera again).Listening to the moronic and implausible dialogue in GODZILLA, one wonders if Emmerich or his collaborators have ever spent five minutes talking to actual human beings. They are clearly far more interested in big CGI lizards and things going boom, and they can't even get those things right (the CGI, though technically impressive, does not look at all real).Think of all the films Wes Anderson could have made with this one crappy movie's budget, and weep.

In many parts, Godzilla is nothing else but a cheap rip-off from Jurassic Park. The characters, the monster, even the sound effects all cause nothing but Deja Vue. Matthew Broderick saves the world again - it's been a long time since Wargames - and the US military causes more damage than the monster itself. Nothing new. Nothing special. Watch the original.

"Who is this Godzilla?"
"Where do he come from? Why is he here?"
"And it's Gojira, you moron!"Personal Anecdote:
Back in 2018 I visited Hawaii and went to Kauloa Ranch where they've filmed a bunch of movies like Kong Skull Island, Jurassic Park, Jurassic World and 50 First Dates.During our tour we stopped by a massive footprint in the ground. That footprint was from the beginning of this film when Dr. Tatopoulos was standing in the footprint.It was still dug out, just filled with water and was pretty weathered down.Review:
This iteration of Godzilla was trying so hard to be a Jurassic Park film. Honestly if you got rid of the title "Godzilla" and a few scenes with the iconic roar - I would have no idea this is a Godzilla film.Godzilla isn't even Godzilla. He's a T-Rex with a lavish title of the legendary Toho Kaiju. Nothing about him or his design is redeeming at all.The characters are poorly acted, they weren't even memorable.The dialogue is cheesy and bland and most of it was either militarily jargon or blatant exposition.The story was boring and dragged on for way too long. It kept getting more eye roll inducing as the story progressed. Also why were the French even in this? Only one person from that group ended up meaning anything and he didn't even get closure at the end?This film is just so uninspired and doesn't even pay the slightest respects to the source material in my opinion.

I REALLY hate this movie. Not just because it's a bad movie, though it most CERTAINLY is, but because of the mindset behind it. I love monster movies, but what I DON'T love is when somebody makes a monster movie SOLELY as an excuse to watch high octane action, explosions and apocalyptic destruction. "Godzilla '98" is a movie completely devoid of a single speck of intelligence or an ounce of heart. A movie with nothing to say, no deep themes to examine, no characters that compel you or grab your attention. Nothing but a 2 hour 19 minute destruction derby complete with bad jokes and bad acting.Matthew Broderick is UNBELIEVABLY lifeless and wooden as the film's lead Niko Tatapulous. I can't even say that I hated his character because he's just so devoid of any personality or identity that I can't bring myself to feel ANY emotional connection to him, positive or negative. The rest of the cast are pretty much a bunch of tokens; the token girlfriend without a personality, the token mysterious foreign guy (In this case French) without a personality, the token slimy boss without a personality, the token stereotypical New Yorker without a personality and so on. Apart from Michael Lerner as Mayor Ebert and Lorry Goldman as his assistant Gene, (Who to be perfectly honest were the ONLY source of entertainment, comedy or joy to be found in this giant Kaiju turd) all of the performances in this movie are just devoid of care, interest or emotion. Even Hank Azaria, Harry Shearer (In perhaps the only role of his career where I would genuinely consider him to be not only annoying but ungodly so) and Jean Reno can't bring an ounce of life to this garbage. I honestly feel a little sorry for them.The script is one of the most paint-by-numbers, clichéd, lifeless scripts I have EVER seen. You can predict every single plot point and every single forgettable character's uninteresting arc from beginning to end. Gee, will Niko end up getting back together with his ex? Will the military save the city from Godzilla without any major casualties? Will token ex-girlfriend quit her job after getting fed up with her slimy boss? Will Mayor Ebert end up getting fired? Will the token French guy complete his quest to find the perfect cup of coffee? If you didn't answer a groaned "Yes" to all of those questions then please...Seek help.Speaking of the script, this movie is FILLED with plot holes. There are too many to count, and it's folly to go through every single one, but here is the big one; nobody can seem to find Godzilla in New York...How?! He's a giant lizard who leaves a pretty damn obvious trail of destruction EVERYWHERE he goes. Surely you'd be getting reports of his location like crazy wherever he was.But the worst thing about this movie, the absolute WORST thing that brings this movie down to a truly special level of awful is the King of the Monsters himself, Godzilla. I don't mean his design, which I actually think looked downright awesome, or even the CGI, which I also thought was really, really impressive. I mean Godzilla as a character. In a GOOD Godzilla movie, Godzilla always has some kind of deeper meaning or social commentary behind him. Whether he represents the destructive nature of mankind with their nuclear programs, or vengeful Mother Nature reigning down on mankind after their destruction of the natural world, or even as something of a guardian angel that brings hope in times of fear. Godzilla in this movie has no deeper meaning. None whatsoever. All Godzilla is in this movie is a giant CGI abomination that merely exists to blow stuff up and cause as much destruction as possible. If Michael Bay's action scenes were a character, they would be the Emmerich's Godzilla.And finally, we have the ending. Many people have commented on how ridiculous it is that Godzilla was killed by the military, and how either he'd have to escape, or be killed by another monster. Those people are 100% right. Godzilla's death is anticlimactic, unemotional, forced and the King of the Monsters ends up going out like a pansy. "Godzilla '98" can't even get the SIMPLEST things right.I don't think I've seen such a clichéd, unoriginal mess take THIS little chances in years. There is nothing to remember, nothing to entertain you and nothing to compel or grab your attention. It may not be one of the worst movies of all time, but it is certainly one of the most soulless and unintelligent. The fact that somebody who didn't even like Godzilla was hired to direct the character's very first American movie downright disgusts me. Hollywood; stop making monster movies just to show monsters and destruction. Either have a point, have a story and have characters or leave the monsters we know and love alone.

Being a major Godzilla fan, I thought this movie was cute.  But it could have and should have been much better.  It seems to me that the Directors or Producers did not look at any of the original Godzilla movies.  This Godzilla didn't even blow out atomic fire, just bad breath.  This Godzilla was too much of a lizard.  Otherwise, I enjoyed the movie.

Review title: It's not Citizen Kane, but it's cool!
Review_body: The movie called Godzilla, so don't expect it to be like STAR WARS or INDIANA JONES. It's about a big lizard running around NY, and I think they did a good movie based on that premise. The special effects are cool, lots of destruction and mayhem and a great climax at the second half of the movie. The characters and sub plots are quite average, BUT WHO CARES?

Review title: The Monster Summer Event of the 90s
Review_body: A slick, Hollywood-ized version of a beloved Japanese monster, made to sell to a dumb American audience. Roland Emmerich's 1998 Godzilla serves as a specimen of 90s Hollywood excess. Big, loud, and brain dead. But Zilla (the nickname for this reimagined monster) also represents the fun, excitement, and spectacle of the summer blockbuster events of the pre-superhero era. I wouldn't call it smart, or even good, but Godzilla '98 is a great big ball of cheesy entertainment, and I kind of love it.Godzilla preserves the 1954 original Godzilla's nuclear backstory, but introduces a mostly original story and characters. Chief among the newcomers is Matthew Broderick as a scientist called on to investigate the strange threat from the sea. Also hanging around are Jean Reno, Maria Pitillo, and Hank Azaria. All are enthusiastically up to the task of running with the mountains of special effects thrown around them. Now calling this story original is generous. At best it plays like a cheap rehash of Jurassic Park. At worst, it's just another monster movie. The kind of set-em-up knock-em-down script by machine that requires no thought and little engagement.And yet, I was engaged by Godzilla. Not by its ideas (of which there are none), but by its spectacle and its eagerness to thrill. What the "all effects, no story" complaints miss is the impact of truly exciting special effects. Godzilla has those. Emmerich and his technicians conjure some real awesome displays of scale, as well as complex CGI that still makes it point. The action scenes are carefully considered. Storyboarded, framed, and shot to be spectacular. It's an approach to action that is closer to that of the masters like Spielberg or Cameron than to the modern hacks who ship action off to the VFX team. There is a degree of showmanship found here that is nowhere to be seen in something like Kong: Skull Island or Pacific Rim: Uprising.Emmerich, along with Independence Day writer Dean Devlin, thankfully understand their audience (if not the OG Godzilla fans, then at least me). What I want from Godzilla is not heady sociopolitical philosophy. Nor is it half-assed attempts at human drama at the expense of the main show. What I want from Roland Emmerich's Godzilla is a roller coaster ride. A slam-bang fireworks show of hearty monster destruction. And this is what Emmerich has given us. The characters work. They are likable, sturdy human interests among the chaos. The effects work. The monster has a palpable presence onscreen. The action works. It's staged thoughtfully, and it's variety of locations and scenarios keep it from going stale (shout out to the Madison Square Garden section of the film. Running through the labyrinth of a basketball stadium while being chased by mini-Godzillas is one of the more exciting extended sequences of verisimilitude I can remember). All in all, the thing works as intended. It screams summer, popcorn, blockbuster, and all of the other words we associate with fun at the movies. I'm not supposed to like the American Godzilla, but damn-it-all, I do. I like the rainy, steamy New York atmosphere, I like Broderick's nerdy charm, I like the earnestness of its ultimate message, and I like watching a bunch of buildings get blown up real good. So sue me.75/100

Review title: Run for your lives! This flick sucks!
Review_body: Here's the story of this movie:One day Mr. Devlin came to the studio CEOs and told them he has this great idea for a couple of trailers. They made the trailers and they did really well, then, one CEO said: "So where's the movie? We spent all that cash in the trailers, we need a movie to fill them up damn it!".So Mr. Devlin needed to do a script quick to fill up the trailers with some movie. He ran to the video store and returned the copies of Star Wars, Alien, and V he used for Independence Day. Unfortunately the late charges only left him money for Jurassic Park. The rest is history.

Review title: It's not Godzilla...but it really ain't that bad
Review_body: Let's face it...this is NOT the Godzilla we grew up with. Put that sentiment out of your mind and then watch the movie.It is really not that bad a film...for a semi-starstruck, expensive b-movie (not unlike ID4 or Jurassic Park). It's got a big dinosaur that chomps things...things get blown up and crushed...and it almost has a plot. What more are you looking for with $3.95 clutched in your hand at the rental counter?This movie is more closely a remake of The Beast from 20,000 Fathoms (1954), the movie which in most eyes actually started the Giant Monster genre (not counting the original King Kong of course).I'm a diehard Godzilla fan...and because of all the negative press, I didn't go see it in the theatre. But I have it on video and DVD and I think it is a good movie. You just have to look at it in the proper prospective. High art this is not...nor is it Godzilla. But it is a fun movie to watch.

Gojirah, or Godzilla as he is known in the west, has always been a bit of an embarrassment to the rest of us Lizards. He likes to brag about how popular and well-loved he is in Japan but the evidence in the west is far from conclusive. Let's face it, Godzilla films are what you watch after 14 pints of lager and a chicken vindaloo, late on a Friday night on channel 4. If you hadn't drunk 14 pints of lager there wouldn't be any conceivable reason for watching a Godzilla film. Ever since I heard that Roland Emmerich was going to remake Godzilla my question has been – why? Now I've seen the film and I still want my question answered – why make a new, very expensive film about some has-been reptilian for whom we lost all respect many years ago? We'll probably never know.The plot, such as it is, finds Godzilla munching his way through Manhattan whilst Matthew Broderick, Jean Reno and assorted military types try to hunt him down and kill him. There are two types of military involved – the usual Americans and the French secret service (guess who). Broderick is pretty good and Reno is too, though he only seems to ever play variations on his Leon character these days. Broderick's love interest, played by Maria Pitillo, (don't ask me, never heard of her) is very very irritating and sets back the cause of women's liberation by several decades. It's noticeable in this film that the women are all idiots. Mind you, so are all the men. A couple of the military guys are quite well portrayed but in general the characterisation is abysmal throughout.The film, like many these days, is too long. The first half hour in particular is so dreadful that I really thought about leaving. But then it picks up, at least in terms of action. The effects are pretty good though not the best I've ever seen. Godzilla being pursued by choppers through the Manhattan skyscrapers works well though when you stop to think about it you can see that they really are models and not skyscrapers. Godzilla chasing various folks through Manhattan is also good, especially the final chase. But I have to concur with the chap I overheard talking to his mate in the Gents after the film – "I liked the bits with the little 'uns in best." Yes, not content with one Godzilla, Emmerich also serves us up with several hundred freshly hatched Godzillaettes for our brave heroes to battle it out with.The egg scenes are pinched from the first Alien film, no question. (Godzilla's head is surprisingly like the Alien head too.) The flashlights used in these scenes even simulate the strobe effects in Alien. The little Godzillas are basically Spielberg's raptors but lots of them. Actually I think Emmerich does it better than Spielberg and the raptors, sorry small Godzillas, are the highlight of the film. As you might expect, Reno, Broderick and co walk unscathed through the raptors whilst minor French secret service types get eaten, even though they are not wearing red jerseys.Anyway, it was nice to see uncle Godzilla back on form. Don't bother turning up until the film has been running for 30 minutes, don't expect too much but enjoy the effects and the mini-Godzillas. Oh, and I bet you 50p that you can guess what the very last scene in the film is before it ever arrives.PS Please resist drinking Pepsi, buying a Swatch watch or renting a video from Blockbuster on your way home from the cinema. This film has the most blatant product placements I have ever seen and they really intrude in several key scenes.

Review title: Stupid, Slow, and Not Godzilla At All
Review_body: I watched this kind of hoping to see a new and improved version of Godzilla. I should realize by now that remakes are rarely improvements over the original. While Godzilla is wreaking havoc in New York City (?!!!!), a news reporter is saying, "Ladies and gentlemen, we have a dinosaur in New York City." Was that supposed to be funny? I laughed my ass off when I heard that. And then the, "Oh, man, you've got to be kidding! We are in his mouth! WE ARE IN...HIS...MOUTH!" I don't know whether to laugh at this movie or throw something at the TV set. I tried to watch it tonight and fell asleep.Now, what is this crap? Godzilla, a male, is born pregnant. BORN PREGNANT! A MALE! BORN PREGNANT! I've heard of equal rights before, but this is ridiculous. I know the whole premise behind Godzilla is straining credibility, but this is just a little bit too much of a stretch.This is not the same Godzilla I came to know and love as a kid. This thing is a monstrous joke. Back to the drawing board, guys. 1 out of 10. Not even worth that. Okay, I'll give it one for that kicker at the end where the egg hatched and a baby Godzilla came out screeching. That actually made me jump a little bit.

Alright, Matt Broderick looks like he's daydreaming throughout the film, Godzilla is ridiculously fast for his size, and the script could've been written by Mothra (i.e. why did Godzilla head to New York City anyway, at least King Kong came by boat), but in its essence Godzilla is still good summer escapist fare. Vastly superior to Independence Day anyways.

Review title: So bad that it took the God out of Godzilla
Review_body: With the new Godzilla film being released in cinemas now, I couldn't help but think back to this 90's version of Godzilla. A film so poor that it is often called Zilla because people do not consider this film to be deserving of the name. But what made this film so bad? Well, everything. From the weak writing to the poor CGI there was nothing that made this film worth watching.But the bigger question is, how do you screw up such an easy premise? The concept of Godzilla is easy, a monster who causes havoc and destroys cities, often choosing to fight other monsters also. In this film however, the destruction that Zilla causes is minimal at best, as more damage is done to the city by the army. And this is probably the main reason people hate this film. If you can't understand the basic concept that the monster is supposed to destroy the city then don't make a monster movie.You can also go at great lengths talking about why none of the characters work at all. Broderick being bland and generic. Mario Pitillo being weak love interest who we never see any reason as to why the pair were interested in one another. And then there is the dreadful Siskel and Ebert parody which was a very weak poke at two of the greatest critics just for putting down Emmerich's films (which Ebert actually commented on stating that if Emmerich was trying to put them down on film they could at least have them be killed by the monster). But far more than anything else in this film we again think of how they screwed up the monster. He is a bland monster who lacks any character whatsoever. In the old Godzilla films the monster did have a personality with various fighting and death scenes having an emotional impact. The only way this one can have an impact is how we feel about it killing are beloved real Godzilla from the classic movies.Then there's the action itself. The destruction that Godzilla does cause is often off-screen with the film only showing us the aftermath such as badly designed destroyed building. Then when it does get to showing us the action (in those rare scenes) the effects are weak. In contrast to a film like Jurassic Park which came 5 years earlier using ground breaking special effects and making us believe those dinosaurs are there, Godzilla seems to do the opposite and do everything possible to show that it wasn't there. It would be difficult for anyone to believe that he wasn't computer rendered for a single frame with a weak design and incredibly unnatural movements.The worst crime this film commits is that it lacks a single moment to make this film worthwhile. It had no good action sequences. It lacked any funny moments. And it failed to create the monster Godzilla instead creating a bland generic monster who seemed to be coming off from the Jurassic Park hype, trying to rip of the film in every way possible with its monster. I can only hope that when I see Godzilla (2014) next week it's a better film than this and at least bares some resemblance to the character of Godzilla.

This is an intense and solid movie that was eclipsed by Jurassic Park and national news stories when it was released. It deserved more credit than it received and had it been released at a different time, it would have been a much bigger hit on the silver screen. This movie has awesome effects that are still good on a TV screen but are no comparison to how you would have felt in the movie theater with a huge screen. Even so, the movie kept us at the edge of our seats even on a little computer screen. The plot isn't like the Godzilla movies of old but actually makes sense in a scientific way as presented in this movie. It's a cliff hanger of a movie with characters you will like and characters you will want to smack. That, by the way, is a sign of a good movie when the acting is good enough to arouse emotions both good and bad. So grab the popcorn but go to the bathroom first because once this rocket ship of a movie takes off, you will hate to break the tension by hitting the pause button.

Roland Emmerich, the director of Independence Day, directs the special effects blockbuster Godzilla, which grossed $379,014,294 in worldwide alone. It was the third highest grossing movie of 1998. Also Godzilla isn't good at all. At the start of the film, the monstrous Godzilla was created when nuclear fallout caused the lizard to grow enormous huge. After it grows as big as an house, the rampaging attacks an Japanese tanker and three fishing boats. Then, an scientist played by Matthew Broderick, come to investigated the tanker that was attacked. Aftrer that tanker, it heads to the Big Apple to wreck more havoc. Godzilla, then destroys most of New York City and its locals and residents are forced to evacuate. The problem with the script of this movie is that the characters don't reveal their background or their personality. Instead, the dialog is either screaming for help or commanding someone to let's go. Another problem is that this Godzilla doesn't even look like the original. This one looks like an giant lizard rather the title character. Godzilla is loaded with dumb special effects and stupid dialog that doesn't go anywhere other than making it. I would more impressed if this movie was more smarter for the screenplay of this mess. ★★ 2 stars.

I admit it, I used to be a fan. When this first came out in 1998 and I saw it on the big screen I had a blast. Sure, there were some flaws, but none of those kept me from having a monstrous good time while I was watching it that first time. But of course, I didn't have much experience with Godzilla, or Gojira, back then. Basically I had seen the animated series on Saturday mornings back in the 70s and a few excerpts of the Japanese films, and so I didn't really have much of a basis for comparison.But then the movie came out on home video and of course I bought it. Upon repeated viewings, some of those aforementioned flaws really became hard to ignore, so much so that I found myself wondering why I had such a high opinion of the film before. Then I actually saw some of the original Godzilla films, and I realized that in context, the 1998 American film is really just a poor man's version of the real Gojira.The filmmakers essentially throw out everything about Godzilla except the idea of a giant lizard. Unfortunately, there's more to Godzilla than that and the result is a pretty weak monster. Sure, this film's monster is still really big, but he's apparently not that powerful. He's not even bulletproof, which means that instead of wading through bullets and artillery shells like they are just so many gnats, he has to outrun them. Okay, let's think about that...we have a giant lizard as big as a skyscraper who manages to avoid taking any kind of direct hit from an entire army equipped with assault rifles, rockets, and big guns. Even helicopters can't get a clean look at him. Seriously? The idea that something so big can go most of a two-hour movie without being hit by more than a glancing shot is far more ridiculous than the concept of a nearly invulnerable monster. Moreover, once the new wears off, this Godzilla isn't really even all that spectacular from a visual standpoint. Yes, he's huge and reptilian, but he's also kind of spindly and he sort of hops around like an ostrich. And does he even breathe fire? No, of course not. That would mean he has to be something a bit more malevolent than an overgrown iguana. And that's really all this Godzilla is...just a mutant lizard like the ones living under my deck. Awesome? Not so much. And to think, all it takes to make Godzilla happy is a peace offering of fish. If only the Japanese had known this decades ago, imagine how much money they could have cut from the defense budget! At least Godzilla's mammalian rival, King Kong, had the good sense to demand a blonde.But the movie has problems even bigger than the eponymous monster. Some like to criticize the Japanese films for being too campy and cheesy, and some of them definitely are. But they've got nothing on this one. The characters we have to put up with in this film are, frankly, a set of losers. Not only do none of them engender the least bit of viewer sympathy at any time, but they are all about as likable as the stomach flu. Matthew Broderick is a poor choice for a lead in this type of film, but none of the other protagonists come off any better. The script forces all of them to say the stupidest things over and over again, and despite the fact that many of them are supposedly talented professionals in high-profile jobs they all come across like idiots from beginning to end. And really, what's up with all those major New York accents? The Yankee dialect is so thick that combined with the insipid dialog this film makes even the most badly dubbed of the Japanese movies seem like Shakespearean drama by comparison.I could keep going, but what's the point? If you've ever seen it you already know how lame the little raptor--er, I mean Godzilla clone--subplot is, how poorly the film's attempt at satire comes off (putting a caricature of critic Roger Ebert in the movie is a horrible misfire that says more about the filmmakers than it does Ebert, and I don't even like Ebert), and how weak the eventual climax is. The only thing this movie has going for it is scale and production value, both of which are indeed quite impressive. Some have said this wouldn't be such a bad movie if it didn't try to market itself as something it's not--a Godzilla movie!--but I think even that is an overly kind assessment. Even if the title monster were renamed "Giant Fish Eater" or something, it wouldn't help. The monster is weak, the dialog is laughable, and the characters are grating. This is just a bad movie, and changing the name wouldn't have solved it's manifold problems.

Review title: One of the worst movies I ever watched
Review_body: Let's be honest. It didn't help that Matthew Broderick got the main role here.Continuing with the truth, no one could have helped this abomination of a film. I watched this movie back in the day while being underage, and I already thought that it was terrible. If it couldn't appeal to a non-adult, I can't image how anybody except for the brain dead can find this interesting.I hope the 2014 movie of the same name goes as far away as possible as what they made here.

Review title: Cool, fun and entertaining movie; good screenplay/script, casting, CGI, cinematography, action, plot, ending; has some comedy too!; Don't believe the haters
Review_body:
100% spoiler-free.16% on RT.
5.4 on IMDB.
32% on Metacritic.
76% of google users liked this movie.
Budget $130-150M; box office $379M.I do not understand why "the critics" are so dumb. Why do they like to hate so much? They must be very miserable people. This movie was awesome. Overall this was a cool, fun, and entertaining movie. I enjoyed it from start to finish. The plot was simple, straight-forward, and had a nice twist. The ending was good, although it felt sort of bittersweet. The French subplot was a bit odd and might have hurt the film a bit. The CGI/cinematography was great, and I loved the design and movement of Godzilla "and the others", except for a couple of very poorly animated CGI scenes (water splash and exploding building on fire). The screenplay/script was great and had some cleverly funny lines. The plot had a couple of cleverly funny scenes too.The protagonist (Matthew Broderick) started out weak but delivered better performance as the film progressed. I still cannot believe how he got away with never showing fear of Godzilla without hurting the film, or did he?. The soldiers showed the most fear, but the main cast did not show real fear (why didn't they?). I was confused about this but somehow this did not hurt the film for me. Maybe because this was not supposed to be a horror film?The orchestra music was fine and appropriate for the scenes and the ending song "Come with me" by Puff Daddy ft. Jimmy Page sounded good.Conclusion: everything about the film was good actually: the screenplay/script, cinematography, CGI, cast, orchestra, plot, slight comedy, ending, editing, directing, sound, etc. It was a great movie overall and I am glad I watched it again 20+ years after I first watched it. Do not believe the haters; this is a fun movie to watch.10/10.
-Below are some of my favorite lines from the script:32nd minute: "There is footage we have that indicates a dinosaur is loose in Manhattan."38th minute: "Do you believe this? I don't know what's going on. You never know what's going on. Thank you."53rd minute: "What the hel* is the matter with you people? You've caused more damage than that godd*** thing did. Calm down sir, have some candy. Arrgg, I don't want any candy. Leave me alone!"75th minute: "What's with the chewing? It makes us look more American."
CGI/cinematography - loved it all throughout; except for two scenes: when Godzilla jumped into the water, the water made a tiny boring splash. And also, when a building is bombed the explosion was tiny and underwhelming.Plot complaints: 3 million people were evacuated instantly, which felt unrealistic. The real population at the time in that borough was about 1.5 million as a matter of fact. That real number would have been more believable to the audience and the critics. But even then, there should have been absolute mayhem and it was not shown in the film at all which was a huge missed opportunity to make the plot more believable and realistic. Also, the subplot of the French - I personally did not agree with that or thought it made sense because it was too unrealistic for a foreign agency to have bombs and military equipment in U.S. soil.Actors:
Matthew Broderick - (protagonist) - acting was poor at first but it got better and more acceptable as the movie progressed.Maria Pitillo - (the reporter) - acting was good enough; super beautiful too.Jean Reno - (the French) - decent performance, but I wish he had done better.Michael Lerner - (the Mayor) - excellent; funny character and great performance.Hank Azaria - (cameraman) - good enough.The supporting cast did decent.The end.

This was the typical "all flash, no substance" 90's flick.While Godzilla looked and sounded great, the visuals of mayhem in NYC tickled the senses, the plot had holes bigger than those Godzilla himself was digging.As usual, the moviemakers ignored physics more times than one could count and set up the most fanciful scenarios.  Have you ever wondered what was holding up that suspension bridge when the cables snapped and were tangled around Godzilla?  How the car wasn't crushed in his mouth?  How that high voltage cable happened to be in reach and remain there long enough to be grabbed?That aside, I also hated the 'heroine'.  There was this attractive, interesting redheaded scientist available but the hero winds up with a woman whose only gutsy action was to selfishly and foolishly steal a tape? Argh!A last criticism would have to be that HELLISH music playing while the end credits rolled.  It had nothing to do with the movie and was nothing but low brow street rap.  What were they trying to do - clear the theatre as fast as possible?Oddly, the effects make this movie somehow enhoyable to watch, problems aside.  I just wish the creators didn't have to give us such dumbed down trash to go along with all that eye candy.

First and foremost, any reboot of this Japanese sci fi classic that would even THINK of hiring Matthew Broderick to play the male lead is going to be a rampant disaster. And this pile of junk certainly doesn't fail to fail. I've never seen so much bad acting in a major motion picture in a long, long time, and even a porno movie is more engaging, not to mention the "pay off" at the end! When I saw this overgrown lizard destroy a nuclear submarine because it apparently knew more about nuclear weapons and tactics with it's pea-brained Jurassic brain, I couldn't stop laughing. And when I saw 100's of it's 10' tall babies taking over Madison Square Garden, this piece of horse pucky REALLY got stupid. If you want to waste your time and your money, watch this turkey. If not, STEER CLEAR. If the original Godzilla could watch this monumental garbage, he'd turn over in his grave.

Now I saw the original classic 1954 movie "Godzilla;" "Godzilla: Final Wars;" the 2014 "Godzilla" reboot; and now I have to see this. How was it? It was not the Godzilla that everyone remembers. This is not Godzilla. Today, many people that talk about this movie will refer to the monster as "Zilla" instead of Godzilla. The monster does appears in "Godzilla: Final Wars," which it is now being part of the Godzilla universe. With that said, the movie was produced and co-written by Dean Devlin along side co-writer and director Roland Emmerich who has directed movies such as "Universal Soldiers;" "Stargate;" "The Patriot;" "The Day After Tomorrow;" "10,000 B.C.;" "2012;" and the classic popcorn entertainment "Independence Day." Emmerich has done a horrible job and he should never had directed this movie because he was not fan of any the Godzilla movies. Also, the look of the Godzilla looks nothing like the King of the Monsters that everyone loves and remembers. Oh, the CGI of God...oh, I'm sorry "Zilla" looks pretty much awful because it looks like that you would see on the Syfy channel. Although, there may be some practical effects but the CGI looks by far the worst. The story itself is horribly written, and some of the jokes don't work for example where Matthew Broderick's character looks at all fishes being putted together in a big pile, and turns to one of the soldiers and said "That's a lot of fish." How is that funny? Its not! Oh, even most of the cast that I feel sorry for are very much given a bunch of bad dialogues which makes most of the characters look stupid. I am not counting Matthew Broderick and Jean Reno because they are like the only two characters that I like, but at times might be given a bad direction. Same goes to Maria Pitillo, who is not only given a bad direction but a bad performance. However, I do feel bad for the actress, and I don't think she was that bad. Despite on what I say about giving most of the cast a bunch of bad dialogues and making characters look stupid I do say that the acting in this movie is not bad. I also don't mind the song that played during the movie's end credits "Come with Me" sung by Puff Daddy featuring Led Zeppelin's Jimmy Page. Oh, I also thought spoofing Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert was very unnecessary because Emmerich did that intentionally because Siskel and Ebert never gave their movies a positive review. I know that many directors don't make movies for the critics, but they could at least just respect their opinion on a movie that they criticize on. Also, maybe just deal with criticism that whether he or she accepts it or not. I wish I can go on more about this movie, but everything else that many fans of Godzilla had already pointed out this movie on why this movie sucks. Overall, this is not Godzilla and it is not a fun popcorn entertainment as "Independence Day" was; but it is not the absolute worst movie of 1998 because I think the "Psycho" remake is the absolute worst movie of 1998, which I will review it for another time. For right now, stick with the original classic 1954 movie, and some of the other "Godzilla" movies. Even the 2014 reboot. I give this movie a 2 out of 10. Oh, and by the way, how dare they rip things off from an awesome classic Steven Spielberg movie of the 90s "Jurassic Park."

I saw this back when it was released and again a few days ago.The film is entertaining, well made, and the CGI holds up well. There's some memorable scenes, and I don't understand the negative rating.I watched some of the new one, and sure the graphics are better but this movie has more soul.

Review title: Pseudo-Godzilla is Still a Fairly Engaging Guilty Pleasure
Review_body: If only the creature had only been named something else and not touted as the "Godzilla successor", the movie would have done much better.I saw the movie in a theater almost as soon as it came out in 1998 and I own a VHS copy. It's been about five years since I've seen "Godzilla [1998]" (hereafter G98), but I generally have favorable memories of it. No, G98 is not a masterpiece; it has its flaws, but it is far from being an abomination. The movie's major strength and flaw simultaneously is Pseudo-Godzilla himself(or is it herself-oh androgyny!). As a mythic force of nature, it falls short; it is vulnerable to heavier artillery, it is not wantonly destructive, and it deigns to stoop to Tatopoulos's (Matthew Broderick's) level (like a man wishing to communicate with an ant). As a super-beast, Pseudo-Godzilla is more impressive; it is extremely powerful, lithe, agile, clever, and tenacious in self-defence and of its raptor-like brood. I think the decision to cast Pseudo-Godzilla as a plausible animal with plausible animal behaviors, instead of, well, as a "God Lizard" was G98's major fatal flaw.When Pseudo-Godzilla is striding across New York, one feels a frisson of awe; he's so tall all you see are his muscular legs trampling across the street. But, the problem is, this Pseudo-Godzilla is apparently agoraphobic; he prefers to burrow and live in subterranean passages (although as an irradiated iguana, instead of say, a Gila monster, it's not really built for digging). Instead of terrorizing the world, all this titan wants to do is eat fish (again, not part of a herbivorous iguana's diet) and raise its young. Like a zookeeper using a steak to rouse a sleeping lion so the visitors aren't disappointed, Tatopoulos and the military employ fish mounds to entice the lizard to the surface. In short, Pseudo-Godzilla is not the supernatural monster summer audiences anticipated, but a simple creature that is monstrous only by accident.Therefore, in my opinion, I believe that to get the most out of this guilty pleasure of a movie, pretend that the creature is not Godzilla, but instead, say, the more prosaic Beast from 20,000 fathoms. Then one can appreciate the thrilling set-pieces more thoroughly. Also, to compensate for Pseudo-Godzilla's relatively scanty screen time, take the banalities the human cast utters with a block of salt, block any comparisons to "Jurassic Park" in savoring the infant Godzilla sequence, and commend Tatopoulos for his ruse in leading Pseudo-Godzilla to his Waterloo. I am aware this involves some "intelligence dampening", but again G98 was always intended as a roller coaster sensation machine, which it succeeds in being to some degree, certainly more so than the outlandish dubbed Toho schlockfests of the last four decades or so.In conclusion, to paraphrase a former acquaintance who saw G98 in the theater with me, it's not Godzilla, but it's fairly good.

Godzilla (1998) is an entertaining monster movie as long as you treat it as a film on its own and not relate it back to the other Godzilla movies. I saw Godzilla when I was a kid and was not familiar with the original films. I just saw this film by itself and had a good time. It has some good effects and good action. I did like some of the characters too. Matthew Broderick I think does a good job. He gets a lot of hate, but I did not mind him. I also like Jean Reno who plays the French soldier named Philippe. There are several problems, but I did ultimately enjoy the film.The plot is quite simple. Due to nuclear testing from the French one lizard mutated into a giant creature that comes to be known as Godzilla and is wreaking havoc across the globe until it finally reaches New York. The military enlist a scientist named Dr. Niko (Matthew Broderick) to help them stop the monster. Meanwhile the French military work under the radar to stop the creature in an attempt to make-up for their mistake.I already stated the things I really like about the film. I like the effects including the design of Godzilla. Many people hate the design but I like it. I like the action scenes, especially the ones in the nest. I also like Matthew Broderick and Jean Reno's characters. However, the film also has things I do not like. Firstly, I do not like Audrey, who is Niko's love interest. She comes off as annoying and unnecessary. The same can be said for her fiends Victor the camera man and his wife Lucy. They also come off as annoying and useless to the overall story. They are just the comic relief that was not that funny.Secondly I do not like how seemingly incompetent the military seems to be here. They attempt to take on Godzilla in the middle of the city which they can easily kill countless people and cause much collateral damage, which is exactly what they do. In fact, the military causes more destruction than Godzilla half the time. They cannot seem to land a hit on Godzilla with all their firepower even though he is the size of a skyscraper. Not-to-mention Godzilla gives them the slip on multiple occasions despite his size. A lizard the size of a skyscraper should not be that hard to spot.Overall, Godzilla is a fun action/monster popcorn movie. It has good effects for the time, great action scenes, and a couple decent characters. There are several moments that require you to suspend your disbelief. But if you can you should be fine. If you do not compare this to the original Godzilla films you should have a good time.

When I watched it for the first time . I absolutely loved it . When I saw Godzilla in New York City Im just like wow a big dinosaur roaming New York City. And the rest of the cast was absolutely brilliant. Ronald emmerich did a fantastic job directing this movie for lots of people who saw in 23 years ago. Now that I was introduced to it thanks to my dad who got me the dvd I get like I was seeing a newer movie that I never knew in my days . But I'll always say 1998 Godzilla rocks and he will be no different than before . I hope they do a zilla 2 since that got scrapped years ago but maybe there's hope .

How on Earth can anyone take Godzilla seriously? Thankfully this movie doesn't and it's all the better for it. If you're not too busy trying to take yourself seriously as a movie critic, Godzilla is a superb fun ride from beginning to end.Some of the CGI maybe on the clunky side, but the characters, the humour and the story telling are spot on.

The combination mentioned above includes excellent CGI and cheesy acting. Also known as "Godzilla". When I first saw this movie in theaters I didn't really understand some of it and I was kind of uninterested in movies at the time, so I could have cared less in thinking about the movie. But I recently watched the movie again and realized just what happened. The special effects of this movie are astounding.  Godzilla fits in perfectly with his surroundings and interacts with the buildings and helicopters really well. What threw this movie into a terminal velocity speed fall was the horrible acting.  Maria Pitillo can't even cry correctly--she sounded like a dog being beaten instead of a distressed woman (I don't mean to sound insulting).  Doug Savant's character, Sergeant O'Neal, was nervous no matter the situation.  He never once spoke clearly, and acted like a frightened schoolboy rather than an enlisted man.  Hank Azaria tended to sound childish in some of his remarks.  Arabella Field overstressed the New York accent and sounded more like a cross between Olive Oil and Madonna. There are some exceptions to the horrible acting.  Matthew Broderick fit the part of Nick Tatopoulos perfectly and did an excellent job, as always. Jean Reno played well as Philippe Roache, and seldom a moronic word came from Vicki Lewis' mouth. You can tell most of the actors are just that--actors, nothing more.  It was as if half the military personnel had no idea what they were doing or how things worked or how military personnel were supposed to act. All in all, this movie isn't a complete waste of time, thanks to the great action and CGI effects involved.  It was a really well put together movie if the corny actors are discarded from further thought. And it's much better than seeing a psychotic man in a cheap monster suit thrashing at little model buildings.  This American version is worth more than, say, Godzilla 2000.  The creators of the movie took an overseas idea and made it so much better, but somehow forgot to take out the dense acting. Let's hope that the casting will be a little more thought out if there are any more Godzilla movies.

Watched this and I must say I wasn't impressed.It appeared to be lacking in just about every department excluding sfx of course.  I was only watching it on a 14inch tv so that didn't do this flick much justice, but it was still...disappointing!!Odd storyline, sort of non-storyline but then with flicks like this you dont really watch em for plot content, do ya??I did find the holes in the plot as big as the Empire State Building, although I DID my best to ignore them! Stuff like this:1) submarines in rivers shooting torpedos 2)helicoptors that fly forward not up to get away 3)huge 1000metre lizard hiding in subways 4)huge lizard laying hundreds of eggs in a building and going totally unnoticed 5)lizard travelling (i mean swimming) all the way to New York U. S. of A to lay its eggs...the cliche list is endless!!There was also a lot of Jurassic Park, Lost World etc so there went all sense of originality. From the makers of ID4, I am not surprised!

It's been almost 7 years since this film came out back in 1998. I can remember the very first TV Spot on television around New Years. As a HUGE Godzilla fan I was excited to say the least. And I must tell you, when I saw it when it finally came out I wasn't disappointed, and to this day I still feel the same way.It's a darn shame that this film gets blasted like it does. It shows me that the majority of the people (and Godzilla fans) that take the time to write reviews for films probably don't know what they are talking about when they talk of America's "Godzilla".There are a couple of main issues critics and Godzilla fans have with the film. The story and the monster itself, 'Godzilla'.If you look back at all of the original Japanese Godzilla flicks, you aren't going to find a great (not to mention BELIEVABLE) story or plot. I realize this, even being a fan of all things Godzilla. Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich's 'Godzilla' at least, in my opinion, had the audience believing what was going on up on the screen. And if the story was slightly dull to some of you, you should let it pass. Remember what 'Godzilla' is about, after all.And what was wrong with the monster itself, Godzilla? Nothing. If you get two action figures, one being a model of the original Godzilla from the Japanese series and a model of the new American Godzilla you will find differences but both are remarkably alike in a lot of ways. They both have the spikes, gigantic size, and famous roar. The major differences being the skin color, face, and longer legs. I loath it when people bring up how they shouldn't have changed Godzilla's looks. I mean, I love the old Godzilla look, it may be silly to some, but to me it's still cool. But it would NOT have worked for this film at ALL. If they had made the American version with a creature that had big 'googily' eyes and flying around on his tail kicking monsters, it would have ended up being a laugh-fest at the theaters.What the American 'Godzilla' brings us is a believable monster that has the spirit and characteristics of the original, that satisfies the audience. It was just more realistic. Shouldn't we have expected that? Devlin and Emmerich came up with a monster that was realistic. Something the creators of the original attempted at doing but were limited to rubber suits. Something the Japanese audience accepts, but the American audience will not. It's sad that most Godzilla fans and critics do not understand this.I personally believe that the majority of the general audience ENJOYED this film. It's just the critical blasting from G Fans and Critics that got a lot of attention, unfortunately, and therefore this gets labeled as a 'bad' film. It's sad really that people can't enjoy it for what it is.This is one of my favorite DVD's to plug in. It's Big, Loud, and Fun. And although we've had lots of great films with tons of Special Effects, there's nothing quite like it.So take a look at it, be open and I'm sure you will enjoy the fantastic pop-corn entertainment known as "GODZILLA".

Review title: Watched it when it was released years.
Review_body: Though seem unreal and less impressive special effects, I liked it. It is enjoyable and fun to watch. The movie is not just about a gigantic beast roaming around, but it also shows various personalities amidst it. Their respective interests and their collaboration makes the characters going forward. Then Godzilla, the terrifying but interesting beast in the world is in the scenario. There is an emotional but thought provoking side in annihilating Godzilla. But ultimately the world is safe now.I saw it today with a total gap of almost 20 years. But Godzilla still entertains !

Godzilla is much better from memory. As a kid this movie was incredible but now watching it on the eve of 2014 reboot this movie is just okay. Still it provides the excitement you recall from growing up and the CGI was ground breaking then but is still good 16 years on. With Roland Emmerich you know your going to get a decent disaster movie which will be explosive, witty and be a complete popcorn flick. Godzilla is no different. Theres a great quantity of action, and screen time of this truly impressive creature is the star of the show. What certainly does let Godzilla down is the obvious lack in talented acting. However even now I cannot deny Godzilla is a fun watch.

Review title: Well, ... it's Godzilla, for heaven's sake ... what did you expect?
Review_body: Not great, but far superior to ANY of the Japanese made Godzilla movies. But not nearly as fun to watch, either. The King of the Lizards deserved so much better a film treatment.Rent with popcorn and lot's of salt -- but only when bored stiff.

I vaguely remember watching this movie in 1998 when I was still in high school, and even as a kid back then I thought it was awful. It came on two nights ago so I figured 16 years has passed so why not watch it with a more critical eye. From the very beginning when Broderick was approached by the identified men in the helicopter and transported to the Philippines, I lost interest. The men in the helicopter were supposed to be mysterious and authoritative and coercive, instead they looked like 2 badly dressed Hench men. Broderick is shown the initial footprint made by Godzilla and it looks like a colossal lizard foot print, then they fly over a trail of other footprints that look like they were made by a chicken? 0_0 All the characters sounded and acted the same; like a bunch of bumbling idiots. I felt like I was watching an episode of the Three Stooges. Maria Pitillo was the worst offender; she was the dumb, vapid blond who always had this look on her face like she was constipated. Behold Godzilla reveals himself and he is a T Rex? Wait a sec now I'm watching Jurassic Park? You're telling whoever is responsible for the CGI could not come up with a more original looking creature? This mess of a movie is not even suitable for TV. It was unoriginal, uninteresting and uninspired.

Review title: Deffinately better than the new one
Review_body: When I was little, it was quite popular in my country. This is a typical family movie from twenty years ago - it still brings us together unlike the new nonsense Godzilla vs I dont really care who. Its deffinately not that bad.

While watching Godzilla, I felt that the director had fun with the material. I know a lot of people, namely Godzilla fans, always daydreamed or imagined Godzilla chasing a cab around the Big Apple, and that's what we got, in a very satisfying way.  I felt Godzilla did everything I would have wanted him to do.  The movie was a bit more satisfying than "The Lost World: Jurassic Park".  Although the movie does have it's faults: the characters aren't interesting, and the cab chase, although very enjoyable, seems out of place.  When Godzilla first arrives in New York, it's interesting how Emmerich uses the camera to film his arrival. Only showing his legs.  It's a great touch.  In the end, I was satisfied with the action and the special effects (way better than Independence Day's, although ID4 was a bit more enjoyable), but not with the characters.  *** out of ****.

Review title: America takes on Japan, and fails
Review_body: Matthew Broderick is in this, yeah you heard me, the guy who was in Ferris Buller's big day off. I think he was a bit tipsy when he accepted the role for this film! Dear Lord, it's horrible! It's not really like the original one because guess what? Godzilla's in America! Yes, shocking, America. Well, honestly, leave it to Roland Emmerich to make another terrible big-budgeted film. Yes, the guy that made Independence Day, and although it is hard to believe it earned a LOT of money in the box office. This movie is totally overrated and they just made a fool out of Godzilla. This was a failed project and although many fanboys love this movie, they don't realize how stupid the writing is, the plot is just as stinky. Even pure-bred Godzilla fans will hate this movie.

Review title: You Can Simulate A Mess with CGI, But You Can't Use It To Cover it Up
Review_body: What on Earth to say about this dud that hasn't been said already?If anything can be said about this movie, it's that special effects do not a movie make.  The giant lizard has been transformed from a man inside a bad lizard costume trampling model buildings, into a menacing modern-day beast literally causing NYC sidewalks to buckle under his feet.  This is all fine and good, but who cares?The performances are stale and ridiculous and the script is the kind of simple stuff you'd find written in a children's book.  Not one person can save this multi-million dollar floppola. There are no surprises, no twists, and certainly no characters that make you care whether or not they live or die.  It's a mess, and boy, does it show.And what is with Matthew Broderick constantly playing his characters like such wimps and pushovers?2 out of 10

Review title: Just like all the other recent big monster movies, this stinks.
Review_body: Do producers really think that monster fans will watch any old twaddle just because it has a giant beast in it?  And what's the point of watching something that's a virtual clone copy of thousands of other atomic-bred-monster-rampage films you've already seen?  There are ideas lifted straight out of other films such as 'The Lost World' and the whole thing reeks of commercialization with its digs at Disney and other such companies.  The wafer-thin plot is down there with the worst of the Japanese Godzilla films and the film is very over-length.  The monsters here are computer-graphics, and it shows - they're just so bereft of character or realism.  The big creature is barely visible through the grey skies and rain and its face, complete with Desperate Dan chin, makes it look comedic rather than frightening.  The babies are just laughable and are quite obviously CGI graphics.A wasted opportunity.  Even the badly-dubbed, atrociously-edited Godzilla '85 was better than this.

Review title: This is all about money. The name's just been tacked on.
Review_body: The chance to introduce a Godzilla for the next generation is completely wasted in this over-length and under-developed film.  The plot, such as it is, involves an iguana mutated by French nuclear testing.  The giant lizard instantly makes for the heart of a city to lay its eggs.  Slightly odd behavior.  The 'storyline' is down there with the worst of the Japanese series, the characters are all just cardboard cutouts of the kind usually found in bottom-of-movie-barrel Friday the 13th-type slasher films, the plot is ridden with holes and there is a stunning lack of originality, the producers having lifted ideas out of everything from Jurassic Park to Aliens.  The big monster itself is hardly visible through the rain and grey skies, but maybe that's for the best seeing as it looks so ridiculous with its gangly arms and legs and Desperate Dan chin.  The baby monsters are just laughable, obvious CGI creations.  There's no sense of awe or danger in the film, it's all just one long vehicle for CGI effects which often fail to seem real.  Tedious, uninspiring and forgettable.  Commercialism at its most sickeningly blatant.Size does matter?  Strange statement from a film which requires the viewer to have an IQ of less than 10 to capable of fully appreciating it.

Ha, ha, ha, ha.  Revenge at last.  Godzilla fans helped American money-mad directors stab Willis O'Brien in the back and then turn his creation into a joke and at last they have paid for it.Oh, a review of this new Godzilla film?  Well, I'm not entirely certain it is a film.  It seems more like a 2 and a half-hour long advert for a whole load of tacky merchandising rubbish.  Actually, that's being unkind to adverts - most of them have more plot, character and long-term appeal than this non-entity of a film.  Two sequals?  Why?  Who with an IQ containing more than one digit is going to waste money just to go and see another thrill-less, imagination-less, pointless plodder?Mind you, this is no different from any other recent film of this type. It's about money, not entertainment.  It's all just a lot of computer graphics, and you can see those by watching somebody playing a video game, and you don't have to pay to do that.

Review title: Boring re-hash of every monster movie cliche
Review_body: This is one of the most derivative films the movie industry has ever turned out.  The plot - a giant mutated lizard which makes its way to the city - is like 'Beast From 20,000 Fathoms' re-lived, the bursting of the babies from eggs is like 'Aliens', the monsters are obviously inspired by 'Jurassic Park' T-Rex and Raptors and the climax atop a landmark is copied from RKO's 1933 'King Kong'.Though monster movies are not known for their multi-layered plots or their in-depth characters, this is just a sham.  The characters are all cardboard cut-outs, the monster has no character at all and its offspring are quite obviously CGI creations.  The humour is also pathetic.  A fat man who is constantly eating and has to often be stopped from doing so?  A dated concept which belongs in uninspired cartoon strips.  The contempt for Godzilla fans and the audience in general is obvious.  This film is more of an advert than entertainment, all the tacky merchandise having been prepared in advance.  It's dull, plodding and the monster itself is hardly visible through the rain.Do yourself a favour - find the original 1950s version instead and throw this piece of CGI dross in the trash compactor where it belongs.

Review title: Oh my! what has this world come to?
Review_body: There are back alley muggings and then there's Godzilla. The biggest rip off from a movie this decade. Highly hyped and highly anticipated, this movie was an absolute disgrace to movie making. The best way to describe this one is that Godzilla shows up and then a bunch of stuff happens. Nothing in this movie made any logical sense. I think this is the second movie that I felt like getting up in the middle of and leaving (the first was Mortal Kombat 2). At no point in this movie did it look like Godzilla was in the city of New York, all the buildings that Godzilla was running by or through look the same. The computer effects were horrible and Godzilla himself looked horrible. Half way through it it turns into Jurasic Park's raptor scence. This is another movie thrown together for the sake of making a movie. They hype the movie, made a good trailor for it and throw in a half decent sound track and a load of merchandise to take advantage of all the naive, less eduacated citizens of this country that work hard for their money. If there is such thing as education than this has to be the opposite. This movie kills brain cells and there should be a health warning on it. Absolute idiocy.

There oughtta be a law that says, if you purchase the rights to a recognized entertainment franchise for your own use, you are required to USE THE REAL PRODUCT, OR AT LEAST TRY TO REPRESENT IT. This is TriStar buying a famous monster's name and then trying to use it to sell a totally different monster.Not that this is necessarily a bad monster. Heck, I actually LIKED the monster, even if they are just animating the Jurassic Park 'raptor' model on a macro scale, especially for the baby monsters.The point is, this is obviously not Godzilla, not by any stretch of the imagination. They don't even take the time to explain WHY the beast is CALLED 'Godzilla' (or actually, 'Gojira', as they take enough time to make a lame joke about). The solution: don't call the movie 'Godzilla'. Give your new monster a new name and put the movie out.Still, even if they HAD done this, it would have been a pathetic movie nonetheless. The monster, interesting though it was, is a big part of this problem.GINO (Godzilla In Name Only), as the monster will hereafter be referred to, simply doesn't seem to exist. Yes, the rubber-suit Godzilla was hokey and campy, but he had some stage presence, for crying out loud. GINO is nothing but a special effect. Since it can't actually be filmed against a real background, even a campy miniature of downtown Osaka, it never gets the chance to truly interact with its environment. When your audience can't believe in your title character, your movie fails.Another little suggestion for future filmmaking: either DO, or DON'T. I'm referring here to the tacked on 'fire-breathing' scenes that appeared twice in the version I saw. Being a longtime Godzilla fan (the real one), I was involved in several discussion groups and online lists while this movie was in production. One of the questions that kept recurring was, 'Does the new Godzilla breathe fire?' The answer we finally got from the source was 'No, it does not,' but they didn't have the guts to stick by that. In a pathetic attempt to win the true Godzilla fans over, they spliced in two post-production scenes of Gino bending low over burning debris and apparently just exhaling forcefully enough to LOOK like it was breathing fire. Bad, bad choice.Speaking of bad, bad, how about that dialogue? How hard IS it to pronounce 'Tatopoulis', anyway? It's a FOUR-SYLLABLE-NAME. It's not even a remotely challenging Greek surname, so the attempt to make a running gag out of it falls as flat as the acting itself.This movie can't be fairly compared to the Toho Godzilla series, because the two are totally different. Apples and oranges, as the saying goes. However, taken on its own merits, TriStar's 'Godzilla' is still pathetic.

Review title: Should have called it Jurassic Park
Review_body: I heard many bad reviews about this film.. considering it was the first American adaptation of Godzilla. Everybody is getting geared up for the show..but it just a f..King disaster movies from the start till the end. I gave it two star because of two reason one of them is imdb don't have a zero star rating and another star is because of the only song I finds it entertaining come with me by Puff Daddy and Jimmy Page.

Lord, what an awful movie.I tried.  I really, really, really tried to like "Godzilla."  I went into it telling myself, "It's just a summer blockbuster.  Don't expect it to be something it's not.  Just accept it on its own terms and enjoy it."  And as the previews started rolling, I honestly thought I could at least not hate it.But lord, what an awful movie.In a movie like this, the special effects are supposed to be the driving force.  Let's just say that we've seen the same effects, and better, elsewhere ("Jurassic Park" comes to mind pretty fast).  Once you lose those, there isn't all that much else.  The dialogue is laughable, the performances are tremendously wooden, and the cutesie cameos and bits elicit more groans than grins.Forget "wait-for-video", this movie is "wait-for-it-to-be-two-for-a-buck-at-Wal-Mart."

I know I've already commented on this movie, but I'd like to respond to some of the indignant defenses I've seen since.  I didn't go in looking for "Gone With the Wind," "The Sound of Music" (ugh!), or "American Beauty".  I went in looking for a summer blockbuster in the "ID4" & "Jurassic Park" tradition.  What I got was a summer blockbuster in the "ID4" and "Jurassic Park" tradition THAT WASN'T AS GOOD AS EITHER.Special effect movies are like a drug, anyway--the next high has to be better than the one before.  In this case, said high didn't even come close. "Jurassic Park" had my pulse pounding a lot harder than "Godzilla" did, or could.  When you have worthless effects in a special effects movie, you're in trouble.The plot was not only derivative of movies, it was derivative of BOOKS.  The whole find-the-hidden-nest thing is straight out of the end of the novel version of "Jurassic Park" (the sequence didn't make it into the movie). The numerous rip-offs from other films would be fine IF the creators were trying to do a spoof, as Wes Craven did in "Scream."  As it is, they're just betraying their creative bankruptcy and hoping we won't notice.  I go to movies to be entertained, not insulted.That leaves the acting, and I'm sorry, but even in effects movies it should be less pathetic than they are here.  Take Laura Dern in "Jurassic Park" and Maria Pitillo here--is there even remotely a comparison?  The "Star Wars" scripts were equally clunky, but Harrison Ford never phoned in a performance the way Matthew Broderick does here.  Jean Reno is tolerable, but only just.All in all, "Godzilla" has very little to recommend it.  If you like it, fine, but if you're really honest with yourself, you'll see that it takes a distant second place to almost every other movie in its class.

The movie would vastly improved if they don't name this movie Godzilla. They can call the movie Mutations, or some other names. So the name really hurt the movie. As a movie goer, you will expect certain fidelity of the original Godzilla.This is true whether you talk of the movie Superman, Spiderman, Batman, or any other movie that is a remake. The movie is remake from a popular series because there was something people like about the character which absolutely had nothing to do with the name. The big name will buy you box office in the first couple of days, after a week it is downhill. If the director and producer would get the idea that a remake is not reinvent. Also Dean Devlin completely forgot people watch the movies not for special effects, they come for the movie because of their strong identification with the character of the movie.For original Godzilla, people love the stupid dumb bumbling beasts who are indestructible from man's own sins and he is punished. That is basically the psychological attachment we have with the character. The feeling of pity we have for the monster, much like Hunchback of Notre Dame, or the Beauty and the Beast, well, you get the idea. The concept and character of this beast is within the bounds of a classic story while the movie Godzilla (1998) had none of those classic story identification. It is very close to a cheap copy of other movies from George Pal's movies and other similar American made movie without any character identification. As a professional screenwriter the most important factor in a successful writing is the strong identification of character where the audiences strongly identifies with his thinking, philosophy or other things. If there is none, then it is just nothing but a fantastic mindless SFX movie without any cult following.Cult following needs a certain element of identification, Star Trek (utopia), Time Tunnel (be part of an important events), Matrix (choice of reality), Casablanca (personal bitterness versus greater good), Dr. Strangelove (the inevitably of destruction), and Godzilla (man's sin will be punished). All these hidden meanings not mentioned in the movie is what gives movie its magic. Take for example Godfather, there was absolutely no mention of the word mafia, and the writer and the director made sure of that fact. Because these concepts lurks in our darkest corners, the psyche is very powerful.If you WANT to enjoy the film rename this movie or put in a new label and call it "Jurassic Park 6" and you will find it tolerable to watch, and enjoy the movie. If you have not watched original godzilla before, then this is good news, because this is a blockbuster movie. Don't make any references to original movie though, it is an American monster movie, has absolutely nothing to do with Japanese monster movie.

Review title: If you want a bad godzilla movie watch the latest one
Review_body: I always like this movie I thought the special effects were very good for the time having come out same time as fellowship of the ring. The story was fine I mean..really what kinda plot line do you expect when your talking a giant lizard attacking NYC. I think the acting all around was fine. I watched the newest godzilla movie and I really don't even remember most of it I think I was ignoring it mostly after the first 15 minutes.. If you held me at gun point and told me to pick which movie between original jap godzilla, this movie, and the 2014 release I would pick this movie every time. I never was that big with the rubber suit and the last ones environmental spiel irritated me to no end

The story line might not be the best but the action was good.An Iguana lays its eggs on an island where the French are doing tests with nuclear power. The eggs become contaminated and then Godzilla is created. Godzilla then travels to New York to nest.The action is brilliant pity the same thing can't be said about Maria Pitillo's acting. 8 out of 10.

Review title: Awful is too nice for this one...
Review_body:
Godzilla is so bad you will cry and ask anyone near you to kill you before the end of this movie! This horror will make you want to make voodoo dolls from the director of this insult to everything the word movie stands for! Is the message clear? If it isn't, I can explain to you why it is so bad... First of all, this was to be a movie you could watch just for fun. Believe me, it is NOT fun. In fact, it's even boring. The action scenes are inspired(I am nice) by the Jurassic Park movies. This movie could have at least been impressive in terms of special effects... IT IS NOT! They are barely okay! The characters are not important in this movie, but they sure are bad! Maria Pitillo should get an award for worst AND most annoying performance in an easy role to play. She has crossed the line that separates bad from awfully bad! Jean Reno is a very good actor, but he has such a boring character he can't make him believable! It goes in my rating than such bad movies as Twister, Batman and Robin and the second Jurassic Park!!!
1 out of 10!!! It's a long,boring and almost actionless action movie!

In 1954, the new film "Godzilla" hit the theaters in Japan and made an impact that nobody foresaw or thought would have happened. Sure, in 1933 the famous King Kong was released but Godzilla was still an inspiration for many monster films to follow. These movies include the classic 1954 movie, "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea" and even more recent films including the 2006 South Korean film, "The Host" and "Cloverfield" from 2008. So many monster movies world-wide have been inspired by the original Godzilla movie.In my mind, around the 1990's, we were long overdue for an American Godzilla film for many years. It is true that in 1956, there was an American production of Godzilla, King of the Monsters! but it had mostly the same footage from the original Godzilla to introduce the monster Godzilla to an American audience. It would seem that a new American version would surely find an audience in the States and create a new audience so to generate sequels.In 1998, an American version of Godzilla was indeed released. It came with a risk because of the past history of Godzilla movies and it also needed a big budget to properly depict this large monster. In the end, this movie version of Godzilla is mostly hated but I was able to look past this.After a sudden and mysterious attack on a Japanese vessel and also some big footprints found in the Panamanian forests, Dr. Nick Tatopoulos (Matthew Broderick) is contacted by the U.S. State Department who discovered a giant mystery which a monster we later called Godzilla and who's main target for attack is the Big Apple, New York City. This is an attack that later turns into much more.At the time of the movies release, director Roland Emmerich was coming off the huge success of Independence Day and there was much hype surround this film because of that. He brought Matthew Broderick in for the lead role but I believe Broderick is a questionable lead because he has never been the action film actor and his inexperience in this genre shows in this movie. Emmerich also casts popular television actor Hank Azaria as Victor Palotti as a funny guy but he mostly meanders around and is not very funny. Maria Pitillo is the love interest of Dr. Tatopoulos but her acting here is a mess and she gives some clear reasons as to why she's not around in films any more.At first glance, it seems like this is a simple plot but the plot does have some substance. Even though New York City comes off as a simple setting, the film does give us many interesting shots of the city during it's action scenes. The action scenes don't really stand out and the ending is tiresome but the action here is enough to get by. Popular actor Jean Reno plays an very interesting French secret agent which adds a foreign spy angle to this new Godzilla.What's becomes even more interesting about this American remake is the Godzilla creature itself. Godzilla sure looks like a dinosaur and that maybe is understandable considering this film was made during the heights of the popularity of Jurassic Park. The special effects here are hit or miss. The film does sets itself up perfectly for sequels but these were late canceled due to the poor audience reaction to this movie. There is also a baby element which later turns into a type of biology lesson that involves asexual reproduction. As you can see, the substance of this movie is kind of all over the place but it sure does add some elements to a film that could have easily been too simple.In the end, this is a somewhat standard Roland Emmerich film. The movie is very dumb at times and has many problems but in the end Godzilla works in a cheesy kind of way. This was a silly action film from the 90's that I wish had found it's audience. This is "guilty pleasure" fun indeed.

Review title: By the time it picks up pace, it's hard to care.
Review_body: If you were just to watch the last hour of this film, you might be able to convince yourself that it's a tolerable whole.  But there are simply too many flaws to make the entire experience enjoyable.The biggest problem is that it's simply too dull at the start.  Revealing the creature bit by bit is a classic device; unfortunately, the massive hype, endless trailers and ubiquitous merchandise utterly ruined the attempt.  Nobody watching this film is in any doubt about what Godzilla is going to look like, so holding out just seems like a mean spirited way to save on the FX budget.While the main Godzilla FX are superb, the Godzuki raptors are inconsistent and a little blue-screenish.  They also seem to be suffering from a strange disease where they can easily smash their heads through windows and steel doors, but seem unable to drag the rest of their bodies through.
