The remake uses a similar choice to the 1986 The Fly, with the same basic plot as the original but with a brand new develop and execution. Both films are different from what they come from, but are still two fresh and innovating films. This is in fact the reason on which true remakes are made: have a different take on the subject and see how it turns out. Films like Quarantine (remake of REC) are useless because they bring nothing new to the Cinematography Mythos. Besides this, Godzilla died 2 times during his career, and bitching about him dying by 12 missiles that in a such smaller quantity blew up nothing less than the Madison Square Garden is pointless if you ask me. Regarding the origin, it's practically the same, and the anti-nuclear message is still here. In particular, Jean Reno signed on this film properly because it had an ecologist metaphor. The success of the film at the box-office, despite the tremendous fan backlash was a good thing for TOHO, since it produced a new film the year right after, called Godzilla 2000. It should be noted that in this film, Godzilla is much more reptilian and there are a lot of scenes that remind of the 1998 remake. This ain't a case I bet. Anyway, in Godzilla Final Wars, there appears a monster similar to the American Godzilla - called Zilla, because according to director Ryuhei Kitamura, the American remake "Took the God out of Godzilla" (?). This new monster however should not be confused with the American Godzilla because there are some substantial differences - it is a reference, more like a spoof, but not the same creature.I feel this movie is truly underrated. It really isn't bad - it is a classic story infused into a modern film, and because of this I feel it should be respected more. It got a lot of new fans into the franchise and made TOHO spawn yet another series of its films, not to mention the sweet Animated Series that acted as a sequel. Just see it with an open mind, and you'll enjoy it more.

Review title: My first favorite movie, actually. I was seven.
Review_body: In between the post-Hiroshima anxiety of Gojira (1954) and the retributive-Gaia wonder of Godzilla (2014) there lies this Roland Emmerich disaster film, appropriately adapted to his action/comedy intensive priorities. Now let's talk about Zilla or GITO (Godzilla in Name Only). Creature designer Patrick Tatopolous (sound familiar?) was aware that Jan de Bont's cancelled Godzilla film had been rejected in-part because of disagreements with Toho concerning the character concepts. Tatopolous distanced his design from Toho's and De Bont's mostly out of his respect for the original Japanese monster. This distance pays off, visually. A problem I'd long had with Tsuburaya's monster was (relative realism considered) just how bottom-heavy he is. GITO is much more mobile than old Thunder-Thighs, which properly matched Emmerich's vision of a high-speed chase with a titanic reptile. Any Emmerich fan can at least appreciate the ways that this film avoids simply trying to one-up an already established cinematic mold.

Finlly we got godzilla out of that fat looking costume! We got an actual movie instead of those childish movies. But then again. Godzilla in this movie flees the most of the time and lacks the bad ass thing. It also doesn't look bad ass when we look at the face. But the rest of the body is spectacular! It actually looks like a living creature! The godzilla in this movie is agile and intelligent which also is pretty awesome. If we added some nukes and more power and aggression to this godzilla, this would be the best godzilla film ever made. Being killed by 6 rockets was a bit of a letdown.The storyline is also a bit thin but it is something to live with. all in all, not a bad movie (Y)

Godzilla (1998) was not great, but it wasn't terrible. I am a major G- Man fan, and this movie monster gives me and us a different perspective on the radioactive icon. Now, as a monster overall, it was decent, but as Godzilla, now that's pretty hard to accept. His trademark characteristics shown in all of the Toho movies kind of disappeared with this monster (let's just call it Zilla): its size was drastically altered and shrunk, its atomic breath was...just fire, and you really couldn't see it coming from the mouth, so it's really to tell if it is atomic (fire) breath. Oh, and also, its immunity to being killed by the army has vanished. Anyway, back to the actual movie. Like I said, it overall isn't a TERRIBLE movie. However, I feel there are some acting problems, such as line delivery. And the movie really focused on the relationship troubles of two people, and a little less on Zilla. On the brighter side, there was a good amount of action, and the computer graphics weren't too shabby. All in all, this was a mediocre-ly OK movie.

I gave this 10/10. Why? I'm not a Godzilla fan, so I lack the background. Maybe therefore I could enjoy this movie for its own entertaining value, without having or wanting to compare it to other movies. And enjoy it I did, every single minute. The criticism I read about poor acting (Jean Reno for example: "Jean Reno was obviously repaying a favor" - fourque2 - I find totally based on wishful prejudice) seems to me trivial. In the given situation and genre, I think it fits in quite admirably.Of course I respect the verdict of the Godzilla fans, that's their prerogative. Mine is to enjoy.So as far as what I expected, entertainment and good effects, this rates first class for me :) My 2 eurocents.

This film gets a lot of hate from hardcore Gojira fans, but I was nothing less than blown away by this movie. I grew up with the Japanese Gojira movies and was very fond of the character and concept by the time this movie came out, and when I saw Godzilla (1998), I was instantly in love. The use of CGI allowed Godzilla to come to life in ways that had never been used before. I LOVED the redesign, and still do. We were presented with a creature that resembled therapod dinosaurs, a much more believable design than Gojira, who had to be designed around the ability to fit a person in a costume. The creature also arguably had more believable behavior; most animals will either flee or retaliate when attacked, and Godzilla does both, rather than walking through a barrage of military weaponry unscathed as Gojira is so infamous for. While that image does create an intimidatingly powerful monster, it never struck me as believable and I preferred Godzilla's reaction to Gojira's for that reason. While Gojira was indestructible (other than in a few Japanese films, including the first) Godzilla was not, and was killed by twelve missiles. Mutated and radioactive or not, surely a giant lizard/dinosaur has to have blood vessels and other vital bodily systems that can be damaged by such powerful weaponry, and if you take away Gojira's ability of rapid-healing, that could easily result in fatal wounds. It was a more realistic end result. I understand that judging a monster movie on realism and believability might seem ridiculous, but it all comes down to personal opinion, and I definitely prefer a sprinkling of realism in my monsters. Godzilla provided that. Monster movies are taken with a grain of salt, since they ARE monster movies, but in my personal opinion, the more realistic the monster is portrayed, the more impact the movie will have on me and the more I will like it. I like to watch movies like this and be able to think "this probably wont happen in real life, but if it did, it would probably go something like this" and that is exactly what happened with Godzilla (1998). Another aspect of the film that bothered people was the sub-plot with the offspring of Godzilla. I always viewed them as a way of making the situation feel more hopeless for the human characters, in place of Godzilla not being an indestructible force of nature as in Gojira films. The babies worked for me, in that respect. They finally killed Godzilla, or so they thought, only to uncover two hundred offspring hatching and ready to begin rampages of their own, and it became a race to contact the military so that they could destroy the babies before they escaped into the city, all the while having to dodge the hungry mouths of the little Godzillas. Realistically, would the human characters have escaped and completed their mission without a single baby escaping the building before it was blown up? Probably not, but that wouldn't have made for a very satisfying ending, so I can excuse that. It could also be argued that its unlikely that an egg survived the explosion, and while I was initially not happy with that result since I wasn't aware of the fact that they were setting up for a sequel that would be scrapped, it spawned my favorite childhood cartoon series, so I can excuse that too. The story of Godzilla (1998) was paced well, in my opinion, and it worked - it might have worked with some tweaks if the sub-plot with the baby Godzillas was left out, but it did work with it as well, and I don't think it brought down the quality of the movie at all. It had just the right balance of monster action and focus on human characters to keep me happy. I watch monster movies to see the monsters, and Godzilla (1998) showed enough of Godzilla to leave me satisfied, even enough to create enough of a connection to make me feel genuine emotion for the creature when it died at the end. In short, no, this is not the same Godzilla everybody had been used to. He looks different and behaves differently and is not indestructible. But don't let that deter you from giving this film a try if you haven't already; a lot of the hate honestly feels unwarranted and a little too severe, and you may find that your opinion of the film might not quite match up with the more vocal Gojira fans. In the eyes of this particular Gojira/Godzilla fan, everything just worked, and it made for an entertaining movie about a monster finding itself among civilization, people reacting to the monster, and the monster reacting to the humans' reactions towards its presence. Godzilla (1998) doesn't get the credit I believe it deserves, and outside of the vicious Gojira fans on the internet, everybody I know has loved this version of Godzilla. Give it a try, and you may not be disappointed. Even if you aren't happy with it, at least you watched the film and made up your own mind.

This is probably the worst movie ever made. The story line is horrendous, the dialog is awful, and the effects are...the're so bad I don't even have words for them. This movie shouldn't have the "Godzilla" name attached to it, its not worthy. Okay giving it a one star is a little extreme, but I am i huge "Godzilla" fan, I focus on quality of the film from the design to the plot and even the characters personality (because no movie is good unless at least some of the characters are likable). And it doesn't even contain the creature having its iconic atomic breath. This movie made me loose my last bit of respect for Roland Emmerich. Sorry if this sounds biased, but everyone has their own opinion.

When i have seen the 2014 film titled Godzilla which i called it as my most favorite films ever when until that the IMAX sign said "100% less Matthew Broderick" which i never known why so i have to check the 1998 film and my thoughts... It's awful, no questions it's just awful with to many reasons:1. The Godzilla design's is nothing look like the original version and it make me mad that this version was a female, but TOHO themselves said that original Godzilla was a MALE and also mocking 1998 Godzilla known as Zilla.2. Idiotic characters like Dr. Niko, Audrey and even the US Army.3. It also parody and mocking at Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel as the Major and Assistant, which i find it offensive for against only critics.4. This US Army is destroys every building than Zilla.5. Poorly acting.6. Both Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich is used to disliked the original Godzilla franchise which it make fans of Godzilla angry.I'm sorry everyone this movie is give an 1 out of 10.

Review title: The fact I watched this as a 10 year old and thought it was bad means everything.
Review_body:
*Bad acting? Yes.
*Unneeded dialogues in supposed-to-be serious scenes? Yes.
*Beautiful cgi? Sub-par. Good for the time.
*Horrible storyline? Yes.
*Was it Godzilla? I think we all wish it wasnt...fourtonately 2014 came out and relieved us all.

Okay, first off Godzilla films, the original and all the remakes, are not very good movies. generally boring, little entertainment and a bit of back story which just doesn't hold up for an hour and a half. Now, I get that the original realized the concept and is a classic; but honestly were you entertained or bored for most of the movie?This movie on the other hand "is" entertaining. Now, it's not a serious action movie, that's probably the reason for all the negative responses. That and the fact that it was Americanized. I guess the fans were not pleased by that. This is as much comedy as it is action. It actually makes fun of all the previous Godzilla movies and in my opinion it does a decent job. It has a certain sense of humor and to enjoy it you've got to like similar films such as independence day. I really liked that movie, so I like this one also. With lines such as "mayor Ebert" with the guy who looks like Roger Ebert, it's just too much fun.Back in the 90's, we had many original good films; so this was weak in comparison. It almost copies films such as independence day or Jurassic park. Two decades later with so many bad films being made this actually looks like a strong film. In my opinion, it's much more entertaining compared to the original 1954 film, and I give it higher points just for that.There's a limit to how much an original film with boring plot, bad effects can hold up after 60 years.6.5 out of 10

Review title: And you thought Garfield Gets Real was bad
Review_body: Don't smug me, but Garfield Gets Real which is in the 4's on IMDb is actually pretty good. But this movie is absolutely terrible! So bad in fact, that it makes you wonder why this movie was messed up.The plot of the movie was terrible. After meaningless atomic bomb test on the South Pacific, a creature attacks a ship in the Panama Canal, I think. After being hired to investigate the matter, scientist Nick Tatopolous jumps to conclusion that it must of been a giant lizard created from those pointless explosions, and we know who he is. Godzilla makes his way to New York City and causes mahatma there, so he has to be defeated. Now it sounds simple, but they over-dumbed it by putting in stupid news reporter story stuff. We have an issue about news reporting with characters we're not fully introduce to. It seems like a strange complaint but the news issue was too long. It tended to drag on from 20 to 30 minutes, while I was waiting for another scene with Godzilla which is a little short and not really exciting.All the characters were laughable and unlikable. A example is Mayor Ebert and his aide, Gene (which is really insulting to Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel). The effects will not blow you away and the action scenes are not fun at all. So what could director Roland Emmerich do to make this movie even worse then putting stupid characters, lumpy effects, and boring action scenes? How about messing up Godzilla's design which ends up not looking like Godzilla at all. I couldn't believe how badly they screw up Godzilla's look in the movie. The producers put in the laziest opening sequence I have ever seen. I think they knew they were making a bad movie so they didn't care. All I saw were lizards and explosions which is kind of hard to figure out.The last and big complaint I have is the movie contains no references to the original Godzilla movies, aside from the name and roar, and doesn't have the Godzilla spirit. This could've been a great movie, if the script and Godzilla's design were faithful to the original Godzilla movies.The bottom line is Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin made the Godzilla movie all a disaster! The movie will bore and disappoint Godzilla fans.Do not buy this movie, do not watch this movie, do not even look at this movie. It's a sin that this movie was even made.

It is quite difficult, despite the apparent universal ease of its audience, to view Roland Emmerich's very well-made and neat B-movie 'Godzilla' in a negative light. From the opening titles, which clearly explain the origin of the title antagonist with a series of smoothly juxtaposed archive images of radioactivity tests and nuclear-bomb detonations with the French national anthem fading to nothing in the background being replaced by David Arnold's incredibly underrated score (and talent), is to me, a signal that this film is going to be of a very high quality and a riveting two-hour ride of escapism. And I turned out to be quite accurate in my title-sequence-induced hypothesis. The film does seem to me to be a successful homage to the original 'Godzilla' movies (for example, representatives of the nation that created the franchise are allowed to be the first of the monster's victims, Gojira is mentioned; something that apparently was part of the 'Godzilla' franchise and references to the original movies are made with shots of TV screens showing one of the movies) or if not that, a successful modern-take on a highly-dated franchise. However, I do not know how valid my opinion will be to actual fans of the original movies as I have not actually watched any of the original movies, but am evidence of the fact that this film stands alone as an original Hollywood blockbuster rather than an homage or remake of its Japanese counterparts.The film's story was pretty standard for a B-movie; an illegal scientific incident from the past has scientifically devastating effects in the future, in this case, French scientists having nuclear tests decades ago inadvertently fused the DNA of a number of reptile species that grew with its mutation to an extraordinary height and proceeded to attack a human-inhabited location, New York. Consequently, scientists and the military become involved to resolve the situation as well a cool French Secret Service agent who wants to cover up the evidence (that being Godzilla) of the French nuclear tests years ago. With appealing stars (a number of whom seemed to be from the cast of 'The Simpsons' for some reason) that played their roles well and inspired a sufficient amount of sympathy for me to want them to survive, rather than Emmerich's latest disaster flick, 'The Day After Tomorrow', in which in my opinion, the ice age was the hero.Running for approximately two hours and twenty minutes, the film was a highly watchable epic of a film that absorbed me completely with the first half or three-quarters of the film given to the monster, and the other quarter to its terrifying offsrping. It is this latter portion of the film that displays Roland Emmerich's talent for creating suspense that verges on being Spielbergian as it is very similar to the scene in 'Jurassic Park' where the velociraptors are hunting the children. But despite the detachment of narratives, the film does not seem misjointed regarding this split, it is similar to the split narratives of 'Jaws' where the first half was on the shore and the second was out at sea. The continuation of events was flowing with its icing-on-the-cake-like accompaniment of David Arnold's always enjoyable orchestral genius that rivals the likes of John Williams'.With gripping tongue-in-cheek action sequences, which are usually chase-sequences and a believable romance made appealing by an attractive female lead and Matthew Broderick's pleasant easy-going on-screen persona, the film is one that can be watched again and again despite pedantic responses from fans of the (highly dated) original movies.Ultimately, the question has to be asked; how can people like Peter Jackson's messy and over-long 'King Kong' and not like this tight, lean actioner?

This film blows.But more lines are needed to be approved for reading which shows the inherent problem of this review page.People are encouraged to continue writing for length when a short concise reading would suffice. Good Lord....I said it blows and it truly does blow.....how many times do I have to say that it blows for it to be accepted as blowing. Matt Broderick looks like a little kid looking at a kitten when Godzilla puts his enormous face up to his.......what director would possibly accept this crap. The one who did this movie I guess. He blows as well........what was the point. Have I said that it blows enough yet. How many of you have been helped by this comment.period

I so looked forward to seeing this movie.  I was on edge for weeks before it came out...  And then, afterwards, I wanted to drown myself in my overpriced Coke.  The special effects and action sequences are top notch, however, but I would expect nothing less from the creators of Independence Day, another movie that suffered from the same fate.  If nothing else, it's definitely worth seeing for the car chase sequence towards the end; it's the best I've ever seen.  All in all, I'll give it a five out of ten.  Not the best, not the worst.

Alright, I've had enough.  Godzilla was a GREAT movie, and I'm just sick and tired of all the critics and others who view the movie as a complete disaster due to its lack of a story and other problems.Personally, I don't care.  The movie, from day one was meant to be just a big effects laden action movie.  It's just for fun.  I understood the story. The movie should just be viewed as a fun, blow everything up in your way movie.  Don't be so hard.  Sit back and enjoy.

Review title: not as bad as everyone says
Review_body: I thought this movie was going to suck so I didn't want to see it at first. But my mom dragged me out of the house and we went to see it cause I didn't have anying better to do.  I actually enjoyed the movie.  It had real good special effects and Godzilla looked AWESOME!!!!  My only complaints were that at times the actors and actresses seemed like they didn't know what they were doing.  Their facial expressions were blank at times.  And how can Godzilla be 200 feet tall at one point and then the next, he can run in a 50 foot tunnel??  Other than that, this was actually a pretty good movie.

Review title: Godzilla, a blown up version of a T-Rex?
Review_body: Godzilla was one of the most disapointing movies of this year. You dont get a good film if you blow up a Jurasic Park T-Rex, but this was obviosly the idea behind the making of Godzilla.In the same way the size, sound, quantity of monsters raise, in the story and acting performance (Reno makes an exception from this) seem to shrink to invisibilty.

Finally a disaster movie that is not a disaster itself! This is the most fun I have had in a cinema since the Fifth Element. The makers of the film have been consistent in their approach, they have gone for an entertaining film with LOTS of special effects and they don't take themselves seriously for a second. This is where the strength of this film lies. Many critics have complained about cardboard characters and no originality, well in my view, that's the whole point! This is made as a FUN movie, the thousands of clichés are there quite intentionally. It is the action and Godzilla himself that "carrie" the movie. If you tried going for character development in this film, you would get a ridiculous clash of styles. In a film where a several hundred feet tall lizard is attacking New York, any attempts at seriousness at any point would just be out of place and ridiculous (Armageddon springs to mind). As a European, it is also nice to see for once an American disaster movie without any of the sickening quasi-patriotism that so plagued films like ID4, Deep Impact and Armageddon. Emmerich is improving with every movie he makes.

This film deserved to fail. It seems to have been made for no other reason than to sell toys and promote various franchises. I have never seen such shameless product placement in any film. I doubt if KFC sold many extra drumsticks on the strength of this one! It will be quite a while before I forget the ridiculous spectacle of a 400 ft high monster fleeing like a frightened rabbit from a few midge sized helicopters. And couldn't he at least have knocked the Chrysler building over? Japan should declare a day of national mourning over this slur on the name of their greatest son.

"From the makers of Independence Day".That line tells that this movie is probably not going to be very good. I wasn't disappointed. It was almost worse than ID4. And that's an accomplishment.The movie felt like a combination of "JP2: Lost World" and "Aliens" arranged in the manners of ID4. I'm amazed at how much of ID4 we can see in this one. The main character could be the same guy basically. A forgotten scientist who gets drawn into the big events. He's still in love with his long-gone girlfriend. By the end of the movie they get together again. (btw, that annoyed me as hell! I really hated that girl, he should've chosen the other one).I don't think the acting was very bad. There were many good actors in the movie. They just had a bad script.The basic idea of the movie is not a bad one. I like the concept of "Huge Godzilla-monster goes downtown New York". You could do something very interesting with that. But it's sad to see that idea drowned in moronic characters (the french somewhat excluded) and drama effect after drama effect. The dramatic effects should support the story and not the other way around.

Review title: Wine improves with age, and some movies; not this one
Review_body: I waited six years before seeing this movie. I should have waited longer.There are bad movies and there are bad movies. God knows I have seen my share. This movie was beyond bad. It is so bad that even if it had been classified as a comedy (It was funny, strange), it would have failed. I am so thankful that movies like "Glory" came along to rescue Matthew Broderick. On the other hand, one would have to be a real actor to do the lines he did in this movie and keep a straight face.Oh, how this movie made me long for the Japanese dubbed versions.Fantasy movies have lot of room to play with. How do you make a bad fantasy. Use Godzilla as your model.

Review title: My vote for the worst film of all time
Review_body: I heard the hype and was ready to strap in for a great movie.  The only thing I strapped into was bed.  I fell asleep bout 3/4 of the way in this movie.  I don't know how I stayed awake that long.  This is the first I have ever fell asleep in at the theater.  Bad acting, cheesy dialogue and all the action takes place in that typical "dark and rainy night" motife that has become cliche of most special fx movies of the day.The plot is way to thin and full of unlikely happenings.  Are we suppose to feel for the lizard? I couldn't tell.

Good cure for insomnia, that's how I see this film. And it's really strange. Why a movie meant to boil one's blood puts me to sleep? Wherever I watch it - in DTS equipped cinema or at home with my ten years old son - I fall asleep somewhere between Chernobyl worms and Long Island fish. What a mess!The only plus is Jean Reno. Well, I love this guy. Since "Leon". "He's a French man in New York". My apologies to Sting.By the way, did they kill that thing in the end?

I went to see this movie for a few reasons. I wanted to see alot of destruction of major landmarks, and a big lizard doing it. It's Godzilla for crying out loud what did you expect. All you people are complaining about bad writing and less than good acting well suck it up. I can assure you the original wasn't exactly L.A. Confidential. I went to the theaters to see a big fire breathing lizard and that's what I got, and I thought that it was a fun popcorn movie. My hat is off for Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin for making a movie that me and my friends enjoyed.

Review title: fairly average as monster films go
Review_body: (warning: parts of this review *may* be interpreted as spoilers)This was an okay film - worth seeing once, I think. As monster films go, this was fairly average.The effects were good and well done. The acting was also quite good. The arguably main character, the monster, was amusingly maternal, and I found the scene depicting the hundreds of baby godzillas quite surreal.The part of this film I found particularly annoying was the rain. In Godzilla it rains 24-7 and it is constantly dingy and dark. You may say it adds to the atmosphere, but I found it a bit excessive. Also, there is one part where a guy comes face to face with the monster and just smiles nervously and waves to his mates, which I thought was annoyingly unrealistic. Of course, the whole film is unrealistic, but unrealistic in an acceptable kind of way.The last comment I want to make about this film is - I came out of the cinema feeling incredibly sorry for the monster. I really did. It wasn't an evil monster - all it did was try to feed its babies - and humans being humans, went and treated it as if it was a manifestation of Satan or something.I wouldn't advise you not to see it. What I will say is: should the chance come up, see it. But don't go too far out of your way to see it.Overall, it is a fairly unimaginative, fairly forgettable film, but with good effects. As I rate Godzilla as no more or less than an average film, I give it a neutral mark of 5/10.

Review title: Another bad movie by Devlin and Emmerich
Review_body: To put it mildly, this movie stinks worse than limberger cheese.  It's too long, the dialogue is contrived, Matthew Broderick went on acting holiday and whoever wrote this must of have been drunk.  The special effects were fantastic though with the Creature and all that but seriously I've seen Japanese versions of Godzilla with just as much credibility and believability as this load of nonsense.   In all of it's 2 and a half or so hours about ten minutes is good, the parts with creature(s) but that is all. Devlin has been quoted as saying that he wrote ID4 in four days, my question is did he write this in one of his lunch breaks? If you want to see a good funny monster type movie rent Lake Placid.

I watched this thing on video because i felt incomplete not having seen this monster (of a) movie until now. I now feel like it was a waste of time..It just drags on and on with poor dialogue, flat undeveloped characters, bad acting (Broderick is detestable), over-used special effects and the lack of a plot whatsoever.Let's pray nobody picks up the idea of creating another one of these monstrous cult remakes.

This movie was a joke!! It was so bad, I don't even know where to begin. My main gripe is with the blond actress, She was awful! I believe she is the worst actress I have ever seen in my life!! Oh gag! That whole sub-plot about her, getting her shining moment on tv, was stupid! I read another comment on here. They said it was a roller coaster ride, Yeah one that makes you wanna throw up.

Being a fan of the big green monster I was excited when this movie came out. What could be better than a new Godzilla flick, in English, fancy graphics and set in my home city? Everything. I'd rather watch the old 70's Godzilla cartoon than this, at least that was slightly funny.This movie made me wish I was blind and deaf. I gained a greater love and appreciation for a cheesy green suit with a man inside of it. I never knew I would miss that so much. This movie proves one thing: Better graphics doesn't make a better movie.I honestly regret seeing this, and add it to the top of my "Movies that should not have been made" list.
Total trash. Blasphemy of the highest order. This doesn't even qualify as a Godzilla movie in my opinion. Who thought this was a good idea?

Review title: I find myself watching it every time it comes on..
Review_body: This is one of the movies that i end up watching every time it comes on TV. I know its not the best movie, but for some reason i can watch this movie without being bored every time. This is really strange because there are movies that i really liked the first time but i just cant stand to watch it again. An example is TDK; I loved it the first time but could hardly sit through it the second time.I don't know the exact reason i i like this movie but maybe its because its got very few scenes thats taxing on me. There are secens in TDK and Shawshank redemption(two movies i really love)that are a bit taxing for me, like the scenes involving Gordon's faked death and his family or the scenes involving the sisters in SR.I really like Mattew Broderick. I find his acting really unassuming and straightforward which is perfect for the role and i like the chemistry he shares with the girl. Coming to the plot there isn't really anything special or surprising(other than they finding a million egg in the garden), just the usual Hollywood disaster movie formula; thinking that they had killed the monster and then it coming back in the end. But the action scenes were well choreographed and the VG was top class. I Never remembering having noticing the VG, it seemed pretty natural(the matrix style dark/blue ambiance helps in that department).Overall really watchable movie(although not multiple times).

How is this film not in the bottom hundred? I've only walked out on a movie twice in my life, and this movie was one of those times. It's like they were making it up as they went along: "We killed it, yay! Oh, wait, it's not dead. Ok, now it is. Oh no, it's a she and it just had babies!" And on and on. Awful stuff.

Review title: This is the best of all godzilla movies.
Review_body: I can't believe ya'll hated this,this was the best godzilla movie ever made.Seeing godzilla in Digital,and special effects,was alot better than seeing him in some cheap,old,green space suit.My vote for this movie would be a 10.

Well, I was all set to write a review on the movie defending it from all the negative flack it gets and I admittedly assumed that when I logged on here all I would see were negative comments. Actually, I scrolled through two pages and found not one negative review, all positives, so I guess no defending is necessary! So I just want to add that this movie in NO WAY deserves all the criticism it gets. I am an avid fan of the original Godzilla series and have a subscription to G-Fan, so I totally appreciate most of J.D. Lees's comments and opinions. I just do not get the backlash against this movie, except for probably ONE reason. The name.I think most folks were expecting basically a remake of the original Godzilla, same look, same mannerisms, same often-times hokey behavior, and when they didn't get that, they complain and moan. I agree with a previous poster here....if Roland et. al. HAD done that, made a creature that was just like the original in THIS day and age, the movie really WOULD have gotten lambasted and shot down. Besides, they already TRIED that once, remember? (anyone recall GODZILLA 1985??.....practically a carbon-copy of the look of the original monster and if I recall, it wasn't exactly a blockbuster!). So the film makers tried something new, totally updated effects (and no one can deny that they were excellent), an interesting plot, a new twist on the original, a cast of likable characters...and it gets totally ripped apart.Which brings me to my original point I wanted to make. The name. I honestly believe that if the film (and monster) had NOT been called "Godzilla", just called "Monstersaurus" or something, and not been made to appear as the iconic monster from our childhood, the movie would have done great in more people's eyes (well, at least on the level as other similarly-themed films like INDEPENDENCE DAY, TWISTER, and such). The kiss of death for many people was that they felt the movie was trying to "pass off" this monster as "Godzilla". And they didn't like that.......they didn't like the idea of totally changing the look and actions of a very iconic pop culture figure.So yeah.....had the movie been called something else and not associated with Godzilla in any way, I think the outcome would have been way different. Because, there sure wasn't much else to complain about in this movie! It was great!! Just my two pennies!

Review title: Very watchable compared to current releases.
Review_body: Although it's not a particularly thoughtful or artistic film, no sane person expects it to be. It is a competently made and very watchable monster-disaster film, much more so than the voguish Cloverfield, which has stunningly bad characterisation, and a distinct lack of narrative structure. As a film, Cloverfield is woefully underwritten and the monster looks awkward and derivative of the creature in the excellent Host.The action sequences in Godzilla are far more intricately choreographed, and the monster is more convincingly rendered, which is saying a lot considering the CGI is ten years older, but then a number of modern CG films seem to trade fidelity for hyper-kinesis, so that everything is moving too fast to make out details, which is just conning the audience; there are very few money shots, like the Brachiosaur in Jurassic Park.There is a corny aspect, but it is charming, and not hopeless hokum, like 2012, which is probably the worst Emmerich film i've seen, and i've seen 10,000 BC.Like a lot of films of the mid to late nineties, there is assumption that the audience still have a respect for story, and most nineties films of this genre stand up quite well to the dross like the later Star Wars prequels, Transformers, Skyline and Clash of Titans, which have no sense of writing talent behind them, and the characters are just types.Even the effects of newer films look poor, due to aforementioned hyper-kinesis/ shaky-cam visuals.Why is it that most modern event movies are so poor on all fronts?

Review title: SAD SAD SAD !!!! This is NOT Godzilla !!!!!!!!!!!!
Review_body: What the heck were they thinking. This is not even close . All they did was use the name. Horrible !!!!!!!!!!!! Give me the Japan Godzilla any day .

I didn't like this movie at all words cannot describe how disappointed I was. I was expecting to see a Godzilla with good CGI special effects who breathed nuclear fire his main attribute. No fire, he didn't sound like the original and he didn't even look like the original. The only think I liked better was the special effects. The guy in the suit was cheesy looking but the movies were more entertaining.I don't know what they were thinking when they made this but they didn't have old school Godzilla fans in mind. This is more like a lame attempt to beat people out of their money and make a quick buck. I suppose if you didn't grow up watching the original you may enjoy it I think expecting an improve version of the original may have killed it for folks. For old school fans don't waste your time.

I had watched this movie in my childhood and was left in awe to the special effects as well as Godzilla himself. This was the first iteration of any Godzilla movie I had watched then.Now I am 33 years old and I watched many Godzilla movies, which are "true to its nature". After all these years I decided to give it a try to see what the hate is all about and I still enjoyed this piece like it was my first time. The sequences, the creature itself, the sound effects and special effects for 1998 were top notch.Many of the hate coming for this movie is because it's titled Godzilla and titular monster is not what we are used to see in many other Godzilla movies. It has no ulterior motive, not a titan, does not have a radiation breath etc. But this Godzilla is an overgrown lizard who just entered the waking world. Also it has some sort of a radiation breath since it blows up cars just by screaming at them, not in a beam shaped though. Also it's not immortal either.All and all, I think this was a solid entertainment movie. I will probably watch this in many years to come and still enjoy it since it gives everything I look for. I am not looking for the meaning of life in a Godzilla movie, I just want to see effects, get entertained and this film gives it all.And unlike newer Godzilla movies, human characters are not annoying as hell in this one. You can very well skip the human parts in new movies and will not lose a thing. Here, you may not lose anything either but you don't have to urge to skip the scenes with humans in the first place.Overall, a solid 7/10 is what this title deserves in my opinion.

Review title: Awesome monster thrill ride original nostalgic masterpiece!
Review_body: Godzilla is truly a very well made success movie, with excellent special effects, great acting, and with a great realistic story! I just cant help but love this masterpiece film which I've loved since I was a kid. It is a true nostalgic film that I can watch any day. This is practically the best Godzilla-film I've ever seen, as the original from 1954/56 comes in second place and the rest right after. This film finally shows a Godzilla/Godzilla-monster that many people, who never really were fans nor impressed by the earlier Godzilla films and creatures, can love. The idea of taking Godzilla in a more realistic way was just great and it gave us the more realistic, cooler, and more lovable animal-like Godzilla that many of us always wanted. It is a thrill ride from the beginning to the end. I can literally watch it anytime.I really recommend this masterpiece of a monster/Godzilla-film. You can't do more than love it! The film really have great scenes with great animation and other special effects, it has all from cool, awesome, thrilling scenes to great love scenes, especially between the two characters that are played by Maria Pitillo and Matthew Broderick, they really were the best ones for the roles in this film, it's unforgettable, in a good way. There are really many great ideas and details in this film which many, especially haters, doesn't notice or just simply ignores, which is sad because of the genius story which makes this film so very special and which have inspired later Godzilla films and merchandise and really has an amazing legacy behind it. I recommend this film to everyone! It's certainly worth watching.

It's a good movie to learn what not to do when a giant dinosaur comes into your city. But to be the Godzilla movie everyone wanted...it needs some work.The little things...the script is really cheesy, and the characters seem to be acting totally brain dead throughout the entire movie. It just doesn't make sense. But now onto the big thing...I can deal with the cast, the script and the brain dead characters....but. WHERE IS GODZILLA? Godzilla looks like a dinosaur off of Jurassic park. Nothing's wrong with Jurassic Park but I expect Godzilla to be amazing and look like the king of all monsters...sadly he doesn't come close. Even in the ending when Godzilla dies and Nick is face to face with him. I understand there's suppose to be a emotional connection they tried to build...but it just wasn't there and neither was the magic that could have made this film a epic classic. So many things were out of place. Starting with the look of Godzilla.

Review title: Dont look at it as a Godzilla film
Review_body: I've seen so much hate for this movie just because it's called Godzilla. If you take that name away and look at as it's own monster movie, then it's a pretty enjoyable popcorn monster flick. The acting can be cheesy at times, or just not up to par, but the action sets are fun and the effects are fairly decent given its age. I'm a massive Godzilla fan so I can understand the hate this movie has. But if you can block out that association then you have a fun creature feature that could have been more accepted if they didn't tack on the Godzilla name

Review title: This film should quite simply be renamed
Review_body: This is such a sad, misunderstood film on all accounts. "Godzilla" 1998 is probably one of the worst adaptations ever. Godzilla himself really isn't present at all in the monster character featured: A radical re- design, a cowardly nature, being a biological parent to raptors, death by military, etc. It's no wonder why Toho, Godzilla's parent studio, completely segregated the character from Godzilla, copyrighted it as Zilla, and made it the subject of joke and ridicule in at least two of their later pictures. This film should not be counted as a Godzilla film, reducing the count to 29 movies in total. While it's a horrible Godzilla film, the movie is a decent popcorn flick to watch occasionally if you butt out Godzilla himself. The characters are really not that great, Nick Tatapolus, Animal, and Philipe are just as caricature in nature as all of the characters in Michael Bay's Transformer series. The acting isn't so hot either, Audrey being the worst easily, not to mention the script is occasionally atrocious and meaningless dialogue is everywhere, especially during the beginning. The CGI effects are also dated and cheesy looking when you compare them to Godzilla (2014). However, the monster sequences are still fun to watch and are still entertaining, even if there are a few rip-offs from Jurassic Park here and there. Overall, this movie is a half decent monster flick, but a terrible re-adaptation/imitation of the Godzilla character. Although it may hold nostalgia for myself and others, it's really not as good as some people might try to point out. If you're looking for a monster movie, this one isn't too bad. If you are looking for a Godzilla movie, please stay away from this. It's probably best forgotten and left to sit in the dollar bin.

Review title: It was great when I was 10...
Review_body: I do have a soft spot for this movie, as I watched it when it first came out, and I was a kid, so I loved it.But now, I wouldn't really recommend going out your way to see it. If it comes on the telly, and there's nothing else on; yeah go for it. Otherwise, not worth it.I goes on far too long, and also I really thought the idea of Godzilla being pregnant was utterly ridiculous. After that, it just turns into Jurassic Park, with hundreds of dinosaurs running about. Should thought about wrapping it up when they first hit the monster. Although it would have made for quite a short movie if they had done that. Maybe some more action to fill in the gaps. To be fair, there is A LOT of destruction, and New York gets pretty much obliterated, but more of that, and more combat with the beast would have been better, rather than crawling about hiding from mini-Godzillas.

This movie was so sweet back in the day! The visual effects were jaw dropping! Great nostalgia if you were born in the early nights late 80s! I love Roland Emmerich movies! This movie isn't as bad as people say! Not much of a plot but it's a Godzilla movie people! It was a fun movie back in the 90s and still is! The ending made me sad though if you seen the movie you know what I'm taking about!

Review title: This Godzilla is fun and entertaining, though borders on comedy. it's Jurassic Park meets The Gremlins.
Review_body: I love the origin and the mutation of iguanas through nuclear testing. The set up is intriguing, but Godzilla would never "hide" in New York City.I like the characters and the monster is great, though it isn't the King of Monsters. It is an afraid mutation that is trying to understand how to adapt in this world. He actually climbs on top of a building, King Kong style and cries.If this movie had not been a Godzilla movie it would have been rated better with fans.Perhaps The Attack of the Giant Iguana: (you mess with nature and it'll bite you in the but!)

Review title: This was my first Godzilla movie I ever saw
Review_body: Okay, okay, yes. You read the title this was the very first Godzilla movie I ever watched on VHS. I always watched it everyday, you know just seeing a giant dinosaur fighting the army. It's incredible underrated and many people don't give it credit the way it should be. Because when I'm older, I'm gonna show this movie to my kids one day.

Isn't Godzilla (alongside some kid or group of kids) supposed to be the hero of the film? With the exception of this and the first film, Godzilla is the pseudo-savior of Tokyo. Albeit, while he levels half the city, he is always doing it to defeat the real villains or monsters. This film didn't have that. Heck, there is only one or two Japanese people in the entire film.Real Godzilla films have the following... ~Godzilla is breathes radioactive fire. ~Godzilla never actually intends to destroy the city. It is always a side effect of his fighting the monsters that want to destroy the city.~The movies are always based in Japan, primarily Tokyo.~Godzilla fights other monsters. These other monsters (Ghidora, Megalon, space Godzilla) are the real bad guys.This film did not have any of that. Part of the whole appeal of the real Godzilla films is the cheaper graphics, the man in a lizard suit, poorly dubbed voices, and NO Americans. (I don't hate us, it's just that we have a tendency to want things our way only)Let's face it, the only thing really going for this was the clean look of the film. And as a final thought, why DID Godzilla go to New York? (New York belongs to King Kong) Why didn't he go for Los Angeles or Seattle? Both are closer to the south pacific.Verdict: Godzilla belongs in Tokyo, facing other monsters, whilst destroying parts of Japan. This film is not a Godzilla film. It's sci-fi film that resembles Godzilla films.

What an agonizing task it was to sit through this mezmerizingly banal opus to the brain dead. A child with Forrest Gump's IQ would be insulted by this charmless embarassement. Please stop the makers of this film  before they make another picture.

Godzilla was just another summer blockbuster flop. Slightly above-par effects could not make-up for shoddy acting (especially from Maria Pitillo), poor dialogue, and supposedly tense scenes which lacked their key ingredientsuspense. Broderick was also a major disappointment.  However, he was not given any intelligent lines and he is not an action hero. Godzilla, itself, lacked a frightening demeanor and the infant "Godzilla's" appeared as if they were taken straight from the set of Jurassic Park. Overall, one the the worst movies I have seen this summer

with the amount of money and the cast they had - how could this movie have been so bad??  How could the studio let this movie be  released?  The previews were so much better than the movie itself.  People were sleeping in the movie theater when I saw it opening night.  Hank Azaria was the only non-disappointing factor involved in this film.

Godzilla is the best movie I have ever seen. It's #1 on my movie list! IT'S BETTER THAN TITANIC!! I'm not a Godzilla fan at all, and I love it! Even my sister liked it, and she doesn't care for Sci-Fi movies! I think it had a good simple plot. The special effects were great! I was shocked when I saw how many baby Godzilla's there were... I can't wait for the sequel! Godzilla vs. King Kong lol

First, I should explain that I'm not really expecting much from a film that is basically an Americanized CGI update of a man in a rubber reptile suit stomping on toy buildings and tanks. But based on what Mssrs. Devlin and Emmerich have delivered, I'll take repeat viewings of the old Japanese movies any day. Even the bad ones, like "Godzilla on Monster Island ".Let's just take this point by point:1) Characters with no personality2) A monster with even less personality3) Can somebody explain to me what was supposed to be so funny about the Ebert and Siskel characters?4) Ending stolen directly from DeLaurentis' "King Kong" - note to Dean and Roland - if you're going to borrow, at least borrow from a GOOD flick!Final assessment: If there is a plan for a sequel, let's just give it to Schumacher. Based on how he tanked the Batman sequels, he would be a natural for the benchmark set by this garbage.

Review title: An enjoyable film to waste an afternoon with
Review_body: There is no reason to castigate the producers of what is essentially just a sci-fi monster movie for being unable to create a cinematic masterpiece out of this material.  It was enjoyable and had some good lines.In fact, I especially enjoyed Matthew Broderick playing his usual understated character.  The French Secret Service agents and their comments about our fast food were also good for a chuckle.There was, however, too much gratuitous profanity for what was essentially a children's flick.  It detracted from the story and, if it had not been there, would have made this a better movie.

When i were going to see this movie i had great expectations. But instead i was very disappointed.Why? Bad story if none at all. The effects doesn't impress me any longer, I've seen all that can be seen. The Lost World for an example - it had great effects much better then Godzillas effects. And why did the makers of Godzilla make it a movie for kids.I mean why isn't it any blood? It's much more exciting if the movie would contain blood.This movie sucks.
PLOT.DOES.MATTER.Someone should have told Devlin and Emmerich.

Review title: A roller-coaster of a thrill ride, yet with a detracting sub-plot
Review_body: This movie completely blew me away.  It definitely wasn't what I was expecting, which worked in both good and bad ways for it.First: the effects.  Uncanny.  True, there were some rare occasions where the monster looked almost as campy as the old Japanese movies, but overall, I'd put them just under Jurassic Park.  From the first half-hour onward, until the credits rolled, the whole movie seemed to be one gigantic climatic scene, leaving my heart beating almost twice as fast as when I first sat down to watch it.Second: the plot (& sub-plots).  The plot going on through the entire movie of the three friends and Matthew Broderick, as well as the whole deal with the news station, really killed the plot for me.  It seemed that Maria Pitillo was just whining the entire movie.  Her character was a complete waste of film.  The movie should have concentrated on the team containing Broderick and Vicky Lewis, whose character could have been evolved much more than was.Hank Azaria was good in his role, and Jean Reno was great, although the sub-plot with the French really could have been smoothed over and explained in more detail; it stuck out like a sore thumb.  Also, the entire Madison Garden scene seemed to be ripped off from Jurassic Park, however it probably was the most intense scene in the whole movie.And how could we forget pudgy Mayor Ebert and his bald friend Gene.  What was with that?  Probably the single stupidest thing in the whole movie.  The only reason I could see for putting them in here is to garner points with Siskel and Ebert.  Terrible idea.Overall, I did enjoy the movie, but it could have been improved immensely by revamping and/or removing some or all of the subplots.  Let's hope they fix their plot problems in the sequel.Out of 10, I give it a 7.

Everybody is saying this movie is total crap and that it's no match for the original G-movies.I've seen most of the original films and almost all of them stunk.Then I saw this brand new,computer-generated Godzilla waltzing around New York City creating mass destruction and I'm saying to myself "How could this possibly be worse than the originals?"Sure,this movie doesn't have the best acting,but what Godzilla movie ever did?Also,people say this movie's plot is stupid but near as I can recall the original films had even wackier plots.This movie has been totally underrated but I enjoyed it.

Review title: Godzilla's giant footprint is left in the history of the worst movies ever made!
Review_body: This movie was horrible!!! Obviously the storytelling is lame and the premise is ridiculous. The effects everyone hyped were awful. Godzilla moved and acted like a CGI monster and the entire movie had to be dark and rainy to hide the Softimage CGI animations. Microsoft's softimage software recently purchased by Avid should have been blown up along with the baby zillas in Madison Square Garden. The best part of this film was the very last credit because I knew that it was finally over. Why do people buy tickets to movies like this? We will never get any good films out of Hollywood if we continue to fund these moronic films.Part II should be Bill Gates versus Godzilla and they should both be destroyed by a giant Janet Reno!!Enough of this nonsense!!

Review title: It knocked me off my feet...
Review_body: When I was going to rent this movie I didn't think it would be a good one but after I saw it it knocked me off my feet. I even cried at the end figure that. It was a good story and the special effects were great.

Review title: Oh no, it`s back.....REALLY oh no!
Review_body: It came, it roared and it SUCKED!!!!! This movie must be one of the suckiest box-office movie of all time. I admit it.. I was really looking forward to this. I have always been a huge fan of the original japanese movies so I thought: " Hey this is the coolest monster in the world, Roland Emmerich is going to make the movie, the SFX are gonna be awesome!!!!" Sure, the special effects were great. Actually, they were the only thing about the movie that was great! ONE HUGE FAILURE: THE ACTING. Never has so many acted so stupid without any sense of feelings or realism whatsoever on such a short period of time!!! Final thoughts: Big disappointment. Could have been so cool, turned out to be a 100% "lamey" ( A lamey is my word for a ridiculous movie!!!!!!

The Godzilla remake was a let down.The long-winded story details Matthew Broderick as "Nick," the bio-scientist tracking this creature from the Pacific (where is decimates a Japanese canning boat) to New York City, where it destroys the town.Negative aspects of the film include weak acting, particularly Broderick, who was as stiff as a board. (bored!)  The exception to this was the acting of Jean Reno, who's always the sauve, tough and adept international man, this time in a "friendly" role.Some New Yorkers liked this film, in as much as it's always a kick for us to see our town get blown up by the inept military that's chasing this monster. Don't waste your time - see the original.

Review title: Take it how it was intended...
Review_body: Everyone I know hates this film. They don't seem to understand that it is made in the same style as the Japanese originals. These movies had little plot, in-between various cities getting trashed, so this re-make follows the same pattern. Devlin and Emmerich were paid silly money so they made a silly film. No-one complained about Independence Day. If they had made Godzilla first it would be ID4 that would be getting the worse reviews

WARNING!! DO NOT READ IF YOU HAVEN'T ALREADY SEEN! TINY SPOILERS SHOWING UP ON RADAR! MAY REVEAL WHAT LITTLE PLOT THERE WAS! WARNING!!This lame excuse for a movie is an insult to every sane movie-lovers' intelligence. I saw it on video so was glad I did not have to shell out dosh to watch it in a theater.From beginning to end, this monstrosity of a film was one big cliche-ridden pile of shat. I did my ultimate best to ignore them, but one hour into this, so-called cliches became virtually impossible to ignore!!!Acting was abysmal. Even I could've done a better job. Matthew Broderick was simply awful. It looked as though he was forcing his lines with no effort whatsoever. As for his girlfriend, her acting was worse. It would have been nice to see the lizard eat her!  Some reviewers likened this to light-hearted slapstick comedy. Slapstick Comedy??? More like slapstick farce!! None of this drivel was slightly amusing!There are mind boggling scenes: submarines in rivers firing torpedoes - and said rivers looked more like oceans. Helicopters quite capable of flying up to escape stomping, chomping building-sized dumb lizard - but flies forward all the way. Most mind-boggling of all - how in the world can a giant 20-story tall dinosaur hide in New York subways?? Oh yes, we mustn't forget the hundreds of eggs it laid in a stadium building and somehow going completely unnoticed. And then there is the unbelievable climatic ending in a New York Yellow Cab.There are dozens more along this vein, but space wouldn't allow me to put them in, such as Guess What Scene We Copied This From. There are enough scenes in this to infringe the copyrights of nearly a dozen other movies, don't movies have copyrights?MY CONCLUSION? So its a kids movie. It does not have to mean - kids movie atrocious acting = reiiculous plot line. This is the worst movie of all time. I give it 0 out of 10

This film starts out with a great deal of promise, but soon degenerates into a display of the efforts of the special effects department to dazzle the viewer. Unfortunately the story line somehow gets lost in all of this. A major glitch occurs when the creature, Godzilla, has attacked New York but disappears, only to be found underground when Matthew Broderick opens a man hole cover. A creature of this size can burrow underground without leaving a trace? NO WAY. The creature then pops out and once more terrorizes the city. The city is supposed to go through an evacuation, but, if this happens, it is cleverly concealed, since it remains populated with myriads of people. The creature supposedly lays a few zillion eggs, requiring massive efforts to destroy them, apparently successful until the ending. I wonder how Matthew Broderick managed to get himself trapped into this turkey. He was excellent in Torch Song Trilogy, The Freshman and Glory, but this was a real mistake for him. I think he needs to fire his agent and get a better one.

Godzilla is a good film for the whole family to enjoy.  The lack of blood and gore make it suitable for the young'uns (though you may want to tell them not to say some of those naughty little words) straight up to the elderly.  As for the film itself, what kept it from being a classic monster film and one that could be forgotten in a few years is the lack of intelligence of the people. To start, the poor old fisherman in the beginning he stands their so long waiting on godzilla to turn him into a fishersmear I thought he had died standing there with his hands on his face.The next example of sheer stupidity (the next example I'm going to tell you about, not the next example of unsmartness in the film by the way) is our nations army/air force, they did so many stupid things I thought it was a joke, for instance, at one point they had a group of men armed with M-16's,yes,you heard right,no,this is not a joke they had M-16's to fight a 300 foot tall monster they brought M-16's,why, those things barely work on people. Ok, the last bit of dumbness I will address,are our next country neighbors the frenchman, when Nick, and that french fella were trying to get clearance into the city, a guard stops and asks him, why they were there and who they were  Nick talks to him instead of the French guy (when the French guy should have spoken by the way)the guard blows up at Nick because he's just a soldier and not a high ranking officer (he's actually neither but)anyway, the guard asks frenchie overhere could was something wrong with him and he says in a fake southern accent  "Why, no sir."  now my question is if he could fake an American accent why didn't he do it to begin with? I could go on and on but I won't. Oh one more thing if it sounds like I don't like the its not true I love the French. These French in Godzilla just didn't play intelligent parts. Cest'la vie(whatever that means)!

Review title: The Nay-Sayers Are Wrong! All Of Them!
Review_body: This is especially hypocritical, since 99.9% of these people enjoy garbage like It. But herein lies the question; Why do movies like this fail, while movies like It succeed? I mean, It somehow got a sequel (don't know why), while what did this get? An animated series (a cool one, but still). It just annoys and bugs me beyond belief.Seriously, people need to wake up; This movie is a masterpiece, It is just garbage. Thank you for reading my review.

It's interesting that another re-make is coming out this year. Man, time flies because I vividly remember when this movie came out and the excitement it caused.I thought when the movie came out it would be good because of the filmmakers.Personally, I didn't care for the story. However, being a kid growing up with that series with all its innocence, these wonderful Godzilla cartoons you watched.Anyway, this is simply OK entertainment. I do not think a sequel will ever be made. This is the problem of not getting it right the first time.

The most disappointing aspect of this movie was not its almost-always crappy special effects, below-F-grade acting, or even the script that was probably written by a twelve-year-old with ADD. It's the fact that this piece of crap was the work of movie-making wizard Roland Emmerich.It's astounding how bad this movie reeks compared to Emmerich's other groundbreaking titles, such as Stargate, the Patriot, and the Day After Tomorrow. Granted, this movie may be good compared to other Godzilla movies, but to anything else it's a C-level monster flick.Am I being too hard on it? I don't think so. I usually give movies more leeway than most, and it's surprising because I thought I would love this movie. I'm a sucker for giant reptiles roaring and blowing up buildings and stuff like that. But this was poorly done, for many reasons.One: the special effects. This movie must have been released the month that computer graphics started being used, cause this is some of the worst CGI I've ever seen. Except for a few instances (when Godzilla's underwater, for example) you almost want to barf at how fake it looks. Almost every time you see Godzilla, and especially his babies, they're nothing more than cloudy animations that stand out against the background. Emmerich's other movies seem to have jaw-dropping effects, so this came as a surprise to me as well.Two: the sound. There are three explosions where you hear the same effect of a tiger roaring. Almost every time Godzilla opens his mouth, you hear an elephant, perhaps mixed with a lion or a car engine. I bet the sound effects team had a blast at the zoo during their one week of work. I would've liked to hear more imaginative and original sounds...something that sounds more like a dinosaur than that stupid frikkin' elephant.Three: the acting. Whoever thinks that Matthew Broderick delivered a stunning performance in this movie obviously hasn't seen any others in their entire life. I have seen better acting in high school...no, middle school productions. It's almost as if they rehearsed for one night, then filmed everything and got the heck outta dodge. Nobody in this movie carried out their full potential as an actor. It makes me cringe.And I could go on and on about the script (nothing was funny, by the way), the endless clichés (some idiot gets hired by the government, finds his long-lost love...even the egg hatching at the end), and everything else about it that belongs in the "miscellaneous" category of stupid (Godzilla NOT eating Matthew Broderick in the first fish scene, starting the car with a knife, and the old Asian man somehow understanding the Frenchman's English, thus uttering the name of the creature).That being said, the only reason I took the time to finish the movie and write this review was because I rented it for $2.50 and spent almost two hours watching it that I know I'll never get back. Please take this as a warning. If you appreciate movies and expect much of them, this film will only disgust and disappoint. If you're a devoted Godzilla fan (non-purist, by the way) that doesn't really care about plot line, acting, etc. and can stand to see the crappy special fx (as well as listen to overused animal sounds), go right ahead and watch it.

Review title: Judge it on itself, not by the Japanese versions
Review_body: Yes I know a lot of other reviewers keep comparing this to the Japanese versions. Don't. Yes, this movie lacks in the acting department, ("Animal's" wife and Nick's reporter girlfriend, for instance.) But for a science fiction movie it explains itself pretty well. How Godzilla was created, why it goes to Manhattan, etc. Most importantly though, in my opinion, this movie lacks all the sex, smut, blood and guts that movie makers of today want to cram their movies with. I had no problem letting my 6 and 9 yr olds watch this movie. Yes, there is plenty of property damage, but overall I would consider this a perfect movie for the junior set. Plenty of action and excitement, without all the garbage.

Every flick has it's share of flaws, and this one is no exception. But none of them would prevent me from recommending it for your next family movie night. It has something for the whole family.I purchased this movie when my kids (particularly my son) were around 8-10 yrs old. He fell in love with it. The scientific information is explained in a manner that is easy to understand and it has NO foul language, "blood/gore" scenes or anything else that any normal parent with at least half a brain would object to.This film offers plenty for grown-ups as well. There are tons of "inside jokes" that will soar right over your kid's heads and settle directly on your funny bones. It satires many clichés (soldiers chewing gum because it makes them look "more American") and the spoofs of Siskel & Ebert are a hoot. Sure it gets campy at times, but that's part of the fun! My only real criticism of this movie is Maria Pitillo (Audrey Timmonds) acting. I hope she took the money she earned from this movie and got some acting lessons. But considering the campiness of this film, it doesn't detract from the viewer's enjoyment of the film.I know a lot of die-hard Godzilla fans took issue with this movie's not sticking with the true 'spirit' of previous Godzilla films, but this is American Godzilla, not a Japanese one - and I think this film deserves a lot more credit than it received.

Probably one of the best films in the giant monster genre. The special effects are fantastic and the monster if highly believable. I fully agree with everyone here praising the movie. But I felt I needed to explain to those folks who don't understand why so many of the original fans don't like the film.By any monster movie fans standards this would be an utterly loved classic if you had given the monster any other name. Many of the fans name this monster GINO (Godzilla in Name Only) and that about sums up the real reason they hate the film. Through all the iterations and different directors in the Toho films, cheesy as they can be, Godzilla (Gojira) developed and maintained a very distinct character. He is an unstoppable force of nature to which humanity is a mere annoyance that at times he deems to help but mostly puts us in our place for overstepping our bounds.Its fairly obvious early on that the writers and director of this movie made no effort to understand or capture that character in their creation. Perhaps that can be forgiven since their stated goal was to try and create a Godzilla that moved and acted like a real giant lizard would act and they largely succeeded but in the process they totally lost the 'soul' of the original character. Their creation has a soul and personality to be sure but its just not Gojira's.I remember watching the movie in the theater for the first time with my wife during the scene with the helicopters chasing the Godzilla through the maze of buildings. I leaned over to her and said the first thing that came to my mind, "Godzilla doesn't run from helicopters" He just doesn't. He might change direction out of annoyance but not run away.I think most hard core fans will admit in private that this is a good film but publicly they just can't get over what they see is a completely wrong portrayal of a beloved character.TOHO even played off on the comparisons between this Godzilla and the original by pitting her(?)against the original in Godzilla: Final Wars in one of the most one sided, quickest defeats in the film.

Skipping all the rubbish at the start of the movie, the movie properly starts with a man fishing at the end of a pier in rainy Manhattan. He catches a fish! Oh it's a bigun! The fish is putting up a fight, but he is reeling this bad boy in. Oh no wait IT'S FREAKIN' GODZILLA and Godzilla is hacked off. But suddenly the 1000 tonne monster who is as tall as a skyscraper runs off and disappears... in Manhattan... and this brings me on to my first point.Through out the movie Godzilla frequently comes out of nowhere and does some godzillarly stuff then runs off again into Manhattan and disappears. I don't know that much about Godzilla, but I doubt he employs the tactic of a black man in Philly and does drive-bys.Another problem with the movie is there is a giant monster running around, destroying Manhattan... so who do the US Army call on for help? a Dinosaur expert? a weapons specialist? No, a guy who researches worms. To add insult to injury, this worms expert completely ignores the US Army and enlists the help of the France's answer to the CIA, Jean Reno, but that's okay, because he is as cool as a cucumber.Overall, I'd have more fun attaching jump leads to my nipples.

Review title: Godzilla the friendly lizard creature versus his Fruedian alterego
Review_body: Brilliant special effects really bring Godzilla to life in a way that far surpasses the original films and only fails to compete with the parabolic meanings behind the classic, although some grate comic performances and witty dialog make the transfer from low budget mayhap to blockbuster smash hit more bearable in a film which has been underrated by most critics.Where most misinformed critics go wrong is to project some sought of romanticised view of Godzilla as `man's best friend' and `defender of the innocent' (as if he were some 100ft tall Lassie compared to the original incarnation who tore up everthing in his path) or classify it as a farcical monster movie which is thankfully not what it is aboutin keeping faithful to the original. The black and white classic, which started the whole thing off, was trying to explore very relevant concepts before it became a ridiculous B movie franchise. It confronted a philosophical paradoxic in human nature as man is both a creative and destructive creature which is culminated in the symbol of the atom bomb in bothnfilms. The atom bomb which in the original film releases Godzilla from hibernation is the closes thing we have to witnessing the explosion, which scientists say, birthed our universe all those millions of years ago. Godzilla symbolises a part of mankind's duel nature, a repression of his psyche which had lad dormant for thousands of years and had been supposedly tamed over centuries of Enlightenment and rationalism but in fact the very thing which unleashes this creature is one of man's greatest scientific discoveries and greatest human disaster.So what is more poignant than this creature arising out of a post war Japan to as a result of man not learning from his mistakes and takes on the persona of man's self destructiveness even in the midst of peace time.For some very obvious reasons this is a story that is almost impossible to rival in terms of its parabolic significance as it was released in the wake of the events of Horroshima and Nagasaki in a climate of what in hiensight of the arms race seemed even more relevant with the MADness (Mutualy Assured Distruction) policy of the US. So what have the writers of the new film done but tried to accommodate some allegorical comment while really concentrating on a monster movie that would blow over the public. The theme of recompense is central as the creature is nature bitting back at mankind who has abused her and in the new film in a subtle plot twist [possible spoiler alert] Godzilla through asexual reproduction posses a even greater threat of replacing man as the dominant species. Where as in the originalfilm it took a new weapon that could match the atom bomb in it destructive potential but developed ironically enough by a pacifist we have a final balance of the two forces when the creature is destroyed and all trace of the new weapon which apeases this conflict in taking the life of a willing participant in the creation of new scientific wounders which manipulated to a destructive end. In the new film we do not have this reconsiliation there is a relationship built up between the creature and Broderick's character which convey the overwhelming sense of awe and respect for the creature prooving he may have understood the irony even if the writers have not. It is all culminating in the final scene with the creature outwhitted it seems it is only Broderick who has really recognised the creature for what it is.

I don't remember seeing Godzilla the first time, but it is still ONE of my favorite movies of all time. They make Godzilla MUCH more then just a crazy monster who wants to rule over the earth. All she wants to do is raise her family, she cannot help it if she is super huge. And it is obvious she loves her children for when she is dead you can see the sadness upon her expression as she looking at the humans who killed them off.It's also very heartbreaking when they finally kill her. I think they should have taken her to an unknown island so she can live peacefully.I've also seen the 'other' Godzilla movies. like the one where Godzilla is 'fighting' another creature. These movies SUCK. I mean my 6 year old nephew could make a better movie then those >.< Those make me SO angry. The ONLY good Godzilla movie is THIS one. All the other ones are poorly made. They should have stuck with this one and never mad the other ones I luff this movie <3

Sorry to say this is one of the worst disaster flicks I've have ever seen. The monster looks fake cross between the Alien and a T-Rex. I'm actually watching it right now and I can't believe how bad the acting is. The whole opening scene is dumb Godzilla is supposed to be a dinosaur not a mutated iguana. Also so far nobody has gotten eaten nor does it look like much damage to NYC at least in ID4 the totally wrecked NY. too bad that they couldn't have created something similar to the original movies. Also the scene with the baby zilla's is a bad rip-off of Jurassic Park.If I could I would give this hunk of junk 0 stars!!!!

Godzilla was a great movie and one of the best of Roland Emmerich. Firt of all Godzilla is not a guy in a rubber suite anymore but looks like and moves like a realistic living thing.Don't get me wrong in this but for the 50s a guy in a rubber suite and no script was OK and passable but wanting from a new movie to be exactly as an old one is absurd.Secondly no death rays no trying to destroy as many buildings as it can and at the end you find out she just wanted to nest in New York, you almost feel sad for killing it in the finale.So i give it 10 out of 10 for being excellent in every technical aspect good acting and for being exactly what you should wait for a movie of this kind.

OK for starters i'm probably the only Godzilla fan in the world who liked this film. the plot concerns a group of scientists (Dr. Niko Tatopoulos ,Dr. Elsie Chapman and Dr. Mendel Craven) who have been rounded up by Colonel Hicks to study Godzilla an iguana irradiated by nuclear tests. it is also the first of its kind and it decides no make NYC it's nesting grounds for the thousands of eggs it was soon to lay. here in NYC is also where we find Audrey Timmonds nick's college girlfriend and Victor "Animal" Palotti a camera man who is a friend of Audrey. now since Godzilla invaded NYC
