obviously it would be the news story of a lifetime so Audrey and victor decide to try and get it on tape and victor is almost crushed by Godzilla's foot in the process. soon after Godzilla's first attack mayor Eberto (played by none other than ...well Eberto)decides to evacuate the city and find a way to put a halt on Godzilla permanently. meanwhile hicks nick Elsy and craven decide what the best way to stop Godzilla would be the nick suggests that the best way to stop Godzilla is not to force him out but to draw him out. so they decide to use mountains of fish so Godzilla will smell the bate and come to them. the plan works but also backfires seeming as Godzilla escapes destroys 4 choppers and in the process destroys the Chrysler building. after this happens we see nick and Audrey in the tent discussing the creature when Audrey decides to steal a top secret tape of Early footage of Godzilla never seen before. then after her story is seen on TV by the army they decide to boot him out of the assignment. as nick leaves new york Audrey tries to apologize but unfortunately nick isn't so forgiving seeing as this is the second time Audrey has emotionally scarred nick.after this happens the army hunts down and finally manages to kill Godzilla with the shot of a submarine torpedo. when nick leaves NYC the cab driver kidnapped him and tells him his name is Philippe Roche and wants to find the eggs that Godzilla has laid as much as nick dose. when they are seen at the base of Philippe and his men it is soon discovered that they are not alone and that victor has been spying on them. after this discovery victor decides to tell Audrey that nick is planning to destroy the eggs and he wants Audrey to come with him to tell the world of nick's heroics surly enough she agrees and they follow nick and the others to Madison square garden where the eggs have been laid. soon the thousands of eggs begin to hatch and Audrey and victor meet up with nick and Philippe where they participate in a chase throughout the garden and are hunted down by the baby Godzilla's. soon they find a camera hooked up to the news station Audrey works at and they use it to contact the army for help. it is then discovered that they have less than 6 minutes to escape before the building blows up. our heroes get away but a shocking discovery is made that Godzilla never died and chased nick and the others to the Brooklyn bridge where they all take place in a car chase across the bridge.soon the army is notified and finally destroy the creature on the bridge as our heroes just manage to escape. but after Godzilla is dead it turns out that there is one last egg and it was set up for a sequel that never happened but there was an animated series that continued the story that i also highly recommend. all in all i don't get Way everyone hated this film so much i can understand being disappointed by the fact that Godzilla doesn't have his trademark atomic breath but other than that its a fun entertaining movie and is Roland's finest work in my opinion. great flick check it out.

Ok so the Godzilla in the movie is not really Godzilla (a creature that can't be destroyed, hence the name God-zilla); it was more like an over-sized T-Rex and a mortal one at that. But it's still a different take on the iconic Godzilla series and if one gives it a chance, it kind-of grows on you. I remember they used to show this on cable TV all the time and I always used to stop (winding through the channels) to watch some of the scenes. This movie has a blend of humor (almost as if it's not taking itself seriously at times) and the casting of Matthew Broderick, Jean Reno, Hank Azaria is just perfect, and the girl is cute too ("it's Gojira you moron!"). It has it's share of a stereotypical Hollywood action-flick moments (which I found myself smiling at), because it was all done in a humorous way. The movie is no masterpiece by any means, but last I saw, this had a criminal rating of 4.2, now thankfully up to just about 5.5; but I feel (looking back now) this movie should have a solid rating of 6.5 to 6.9..

OK, let me just start of by saying this: I am NOT going to try to force others to feel the same way about this film as I do, NO. But I do have to be honest here and just come out and say it: I am seriously SICK AND TIRED of all of the negative hardcore Godzilla purist BULL HONKY that "Godzilla 1998" keeps getting! I mean, to simply say "I don't like this movie," state your valid reasons why (in a NICE and RESPECTABLE manner), and just leave it at that, I can honestly accept viewpoints like that. But what I can't accept are many hardcore Godzilla fans taking the TriStar film WAY to seriously, OVER-BLOWING their negative opinions on it to RIDICULOUS levels, and treating the movie like it shouldn't have existed. THAT I CANNOT except, and trashing a movie like this in that exact manner SERIOUSLY CANNOT BE.OK, with that said, I just want to say that I am a true fan of "Godzilla 1998" and I always will be. NOBODY is going to force me to think of this film differently, NOBODY. Now do not get me wrong, I WAS familiar with the classic Toho Godzilla and I truly LOVE the original Big G and everything that has made him a cultural icon. I like to think of Roland Emmerich's 100% American take on Godzilla (which is what it's SUPPOSED to be in the first place)as a very fun, entertaining movie that has a well-executed plot/story that actually makes sense (for me at least), very well-developed human characters that are relate-able as real people and move the narrative along, and a creature that IS a very realistic depiction of Godzilla.Now I've heard about the scientific inaccuracies related to this film, and I say that conventional scientific thinking DOES NOT APPLY AND IT'S NOT SUPPOSED TO APPLY. You see, in this movie, even though Godzilla (or "Zilla" as the film's creature is now called) is a mutated marine iguana, that's just what he is, a MUTANT. He's MUTATED. Conventional scientific knowledge and facts about real-life marine iguanas honestly DOESN'T APPLY because Godzilla (a.k.a. Zilla) is a MUTANT. His entire anatomy and body structure has adjusted to suit a very different lifestyle & diet. His reproductive system has also developed in a way it which it's SUPPOSED TO BE DIFFERENT from how most other reptiles reproduce. Plus, "Zilla" has to have SOME WAY of spreading his species, so the way the movie handles it makes sense. And by the way, about the dinosaurs in "Jurassic Park?" If you remember from that film, SOME of the dinosaurs TRANSFORMED THEIR GENDER AND BECAME MALES. In "Godzilla 1998," he has the ability to REPRODUCE ASEXUALLY, there's a difference between the two. Finally, the Baby Godzillas (a.k.a. Baby-Zillas) are NOT rip-offs of the "Jurassic Park" Velociraptors! They look EXACTLY like their parent, only in baby form, people! SHEESH!Now I don't know about anyone else out there, but I believe the main reason for the negative bashing from both the hardcore Godzilla fans and the critics is that people keep comparing this to the Toho Godzilla series when really, "Godzilla 1998" SHOULDN'T be compared with the latter and I don't think it's supposed to be compared with the Toho films at all. This, to me, is a 100% American, alternate universe version of the same character of Godzilla. I repeat: A 100% American, ALTERNATE UNIVERSE VERSION OF THE SAME CHARACTER OF GODZILLA. That's how I see it, and there may be folks out there who see this in a similar fashion. It's NOT supposed to be compared to the Toho films at all because when Roland Emmerich and Dean Devlin set out to make "Godzilla 1998," they had it in their minds to give America IT'S OWN GODZILLA while keeping their version true to the original in some ways. For example, "Zilla (I personally call him Godzilla, but that's just me)" does have a breath weapon. I really DON'T CARE NOR SHOULD IT REALLY MATTER what exactly comes out of his mouth. In my mind, as long as something deadly comes out of his mouth, then Godzilla USA has a breath weapon just like his Toho counterpart. Also, most conventional military weapons really DON'T do any thing to stop him; they just leave tiny scratches on his body. Not even submarine torpedoes could kill him! And even though "Zilla" didn't completely destroy all of New York, he truly DID DESTROY stuff in general (vehicles, villages, boats and a fishing ship). Finally, there are plates on "Zilla's" back just like his Japanese counterpart. Should it really matter what exact shape the plates are? I say 'NO, NOT REALLY' to that. Bottom line, if this film's creature has a breath weapon, is near-invincible, and has plates on his back, then he's good enough for me as GODZILLA. Most others will disagree with me on this review, but that's truly OK. I really do respect other people's opinions on "Godzilla 1998" even though I don't agree with them. All I wanted to do here is put in my own personal two cents about this film. And while it's fan-base isn't nearly as big as the one surrounding the Toho series, TriStar's film IS loved & supported by a good number of people (myself included). And really, that makes me smile!So in conclusion, I personally give "Godzilla 1998" 5 out of 5 stars in all conventional areas of film-making, cinematic storytelling, character & relationship development, and action & creature design/animation. So this is me, signing off. Enjoy!

Review title: Does exactly what it says on the box ............ ENTERTAIN...
Review_body: Who are these people comparing this to the older Godzilla movies.. ? There is absolutely no comparison....this film stands on it's own and is a fast action paced, highly entertaining movie with special effects that were the best at the time.You have to smile at the people who take the Godzilla mythology far too seriously. I had to smile when I read some of the reviews from the die hard Godzilla fans.Personally, I don't care. The movie, from day one was meant to be just a big effects laden action movie. It's about comic book character.AN EXCELLENT ENTERTAINING POPCORN MOVIE........BRILLIANT

Review title: Don't Hate The Monster, Hate The Movie
Review_body: Hard to believe it's been 16 years since we were force-fed this film! But, on the eve of a new Godzilla thrashing theaters, I felt the urge to see a blast from our G-Fan past. Fortunately, much of the hatred for Zilla '98 has died down (mostly due to anticipation for the upcoming redemption by Hollywood next month).While I could sit here and write volumes and volumes on 'the bad' of the film, I think it's been done to death. Instead, I'd like to focus on some of the 'good' the film had to offer (yes, there was SOME good to the film). For parents, this movie is what I could call a "safe" G-flick (much like the original Toho films). By this, I mean there's barely a foul word uttered, no graphic violence I can recall, and no "every film's gotta have one" sex scene. I felt it was safe enough for my 8 year old step-daughter to watch (yes, my step-DAUGHTER loves Godzilla! I'll make a Jedi out of her yet!).The action is over-the-top, well in line for a Godzilla movie. Lots of Godzilla stomping (away from the military), big and loud building explosions (mostly by the military), and absurd amounts of "under-the-line" references to other sci-fi and action films (mostly by the military). There's a lot in Zilla '98 for giant monster fans, action movie fans, and summer "popcorn" movie fans.As a giant monster movie, Zilla '98 works, and it works rather well. For a Godzilla film, maybe not so much. I myself have accepted it as part of the Godzilla mythology, much in the way as "Halloween-III: Season Of The Witch", or maybe "Friday The 13th Part-V: A new Beginning". It will forever be razzed as a Godzilla film. But, if you look past that, and see it more as a giant monster film, it's not half bad. In the end: don't hate the monster, hate the movie.

Review title: I can never hate this film despite what everyone says
Review_body: When I first saw this film, I was about 6 years old and I loved dinosaurs at the time. Seeing a cool looking giant lizard walking around New York was eye candy to me. I can never hate this film because it was the film that introduced me to the king of the monsters, even though it tried to be but failed. I understand what everyone says but I feel like its my duty to try to defend this film. I'm not gonna act like its a masterpiece, its not, but it is entertaining. Is it a Godzilla film? yes. Is it good? It's watchable to say the least. Does it stand as a great Godzilla film? no. It's far from perfect but not to the point where its God awful. So I don't think its right to hate this film. I've seen plenty of other Godzilla films like Gojira 1954, Godzilla vs King Ghidorah, Godzilla Tokyo SOS, Final Wars, and when it comes out on theaters, Godzilla 2014 :3 If someone told me to write down the names of all the Godzilla films I've seen, I'd add Godzilla 1998.

when this movie came out I was only one but 15 years later I watched it after I got into Godzilla at first I didn't think the giant monster was him I thought that this giant T-rex was going to get his ass kicked by the real Godzilla but instead they just have Robocop and tetrameter references my brother wanted to barrow it to show to his daughters I won't give it to him due to its sucks that thing is not Godzilla unless he turned into a " long legged chicken footed square headed no atomic breath piece of &*^(&^%^%&^)*)(*&^&^(%(*&)(^*&" said honest trails and I agree with them. they have not bad actors but they could have cast this better and given the guy a better name then doctor afactogolus (its Greek)

Review title: Has nothing to do with Godzilla, just the title
Review_body: Has nothing to do with Godzilla, just the title. And the new movie comes, and people are saying this the best Godzilla. Is that a joke? Im laughing about that. It is not a bad movie, but this is not Godzilla, not the Godzilla storlyine, and has nothing to do with the orginal Godzilla.

Gone is the guy in the baggy, rubber suit tromping through starkly lit minatures sets of a Japan. Enter the slick, computer-generated Godzilla, as he crashes through New York skyscrapers leaving huge holes through the middle of them. No more tiny cars glued to over passes, waiting for Godzilla to stomp on them. Instead, Godzilla '98 blows cars hundreds of feet in the air with the breath from his roar. A cross between Jurassic Park's T-Rex and a giant lizard, this Godzilla is a technical marvel. He is remarkably fast and agile, cleverly evading heat sinking missiles and casually ignoring rounds of artillery shells puncturing his reptilian skin. Unfortunately, improved film-making techniques don't necessarily mean a better movie.The new Godzilla is revealed to be a by-product of nuclear testing in French Polynesia who manages to swim all the way to Manhattan with out being detected along the way. He has come to New York City for no apparent reason other than to nest. It seems Godzilla reproduces asexually and has chosen Madison Square Garden to lay his eggs. As usual in movies of this sort, the only person who realizes Godzilla's true animal instincts (Matthew Broderick) is summarily dismissed by the military because secret information in his possession was leaked to the press by a dim-witted ex-girlfriend (Maria Pitillio) trying to prove herself a worthy reporter. Meanwhile the baby Godzilla's hatch and run-a-muck in Madison Square Garden, but are bombed by military aircraft before they can descend upon the city. Seeing all his dead offspring, papa Godzilla goes on an all out rampage and this last fifteen minutes of the film offers the most exciting and entertaining sequences of the entire two hours and thirty minutes.The original Godzilla movies, all 22 of them, were genuinely silly, but you rightfully assume a $120 million remake to rise above the cheesy and knock your socks off. Well, the visual effects are far from cheesy, but they don't show you anything you haven't seen before, many times before. Initially it's impressive to see the sheer size of this beast and the way he lithely maneuvers among the buildings of Manhattan. But eventually you tire of his massive feet coming down and crunching cars and people-whose bodies you somehow never see in his wake. In fact, Godzilla doesn't eat people unless they smell like fish (his favorite snack) or kill his babies.One would have expected David Arnold (Tomorrow Never Dies) to write one of his usual techno-laced soundtracks rather than fall back on a traditional orchestral track with sweeping strings for melodramatic effect. Yet, he does creating a score that just doesn't fit the visual content. On the other hand, the 5.1 sound effects in the film are exceptional creating one of the few enjoyable aspects of the production. Perhaps the best example of this is the scene when all the baby Godzilla's are hatching and you can hear their tiny roars all around you.Godzilla trashes more than buildings and cars, he devours the talents of some very fine actors on hack dialogue and poorly scripted plot lines. You get a sense that the script was written as they went along and most of the characters are just plain dumb and useless. Oddly, unlike other monster movies these useless characters aren't killed off, they just plod along with little to reveal or contribute to the story line.Of all the actors, only Jean Reno, a Frenchman with his own commando group, plays his part with the right balance of humor and action hero. Matthew Broderick is sadly out of his element and Hank Azaria spends most of the time running away from the great beast. Vicki Lewis from TV's 'NewsRadio' was undoubtedly brought in for comic relief, too bad they didn't give her anything funny to say. Meanwhile, Broderick's screen love-interest, Maria Pitillo is so obnoxious you are begging Godzilla to swoop down and gobble her up.Coming from the filmmakers behind Independence Day, you might have expected a lot more humor in this film, but unfortunately it's not here. Only a few sight gags and quickie one-liners ever hit their mark, leaving the movie is surprisingly empty, lacking a real sense of fun, despite its non-stop action.

Review title: The best Godzilla movies up to its point
Review_body: If you're trying to start watching all of the Godzilla movies, and make it this far, congratulations because you're an alcoholic. All Godzilla movies prior to this should just be considered points of reference to compare this one to, because the effects are so incredibly campy despite their historical impressiveness that they're just hard to watch. This one is the first one that feels modern enough to really enjoy it. You should watch at least a few of the Toho ones to see what Godzilla was, and then watch this one. It's better, despite its rainy flaws. The effects are worth watching, the monster behaves in the way you would expect Godzilla to behave. There wasn't enough mention of its nuclear origins and warnings, but the destruction is what you probably expected to see in at least one of the Toho films and did not get to see. The Toho films are like going to a museum, watching this movie is like going on a mildly outdated roller-coaster ride.
Will never go down as a classic but for it's time it's a decent watch, picked it up on 4k today and enjoyed watching it again after all these years.
Classic entertainment. People expect to much sometimes. Come on it has Mathew Broderick and Hank Azaria.. How bad can it be :)

Review title: Wow, my expectations were low, but I can't believe this.
Review_body: It had to happen eventually. 44 years after the original the Americans have to bastardize the Japanese classic. Well the results are here, and they are not looking good. The story is simple, all you really need to know is what you expect. Godzilla comes, he destroys, people fight, they die, eventually they defeat the creature. Well simplicity isn't the problem. Stupidity isn't either. Don't get me wrong, the film is stupid, but what do you expect from Roland Emmerich and his pals. I am not going to talk about how the people manage to lose a 400 foot tall creature several times, and I am not going to talk about how he changes sizes throughout the film. Stuff like this is to be expected. The Japanese movies commit atrocities just as bad as this.What I am here to talk about is the shere boredom induced by this movie that the Japanese movies never brought about. The film is over 2 hours long, and throughout the only mildly entertaining scenes are the first time the creature shows himself and the car chase that concludes the film. There is a certain visual wowness factor at watching Godzilla tear his way through the city, but it wears away quickly. It was more effective on me when I first saw it when it came out when I had just turned six. I mean seriously, this movie is over 2 hours long and Godzilla is only on screen for about 15 minutes. Something is wrong with that. I mean really, did they expect us to be entertained by the idiot humans and their pointless talking.The comedy is lame and so is everything else. We don't care about these humans and would rather Godzilla just kill them right of the bat. The movie also wastes a full 45 minutes dealing with Godzilla's children in a blatant Jurassic Park rip-off. It is yawn-inducing, as is most of the film. This film is a dull experience, from beginning to end, only occasionally resulting in some fun, but it is not nearly enough for a watch.

This is an enjoyable popcorn movie... just as all other Roland Emmerich (who according to me is "The people's director" to prove my point note that Emmerich won Audience award for the best director at the European film awards) Yes it is highly commercial. The graphics are good. The special effects may be the best ones that year. The movie is not too violent - makes it ideal for all ages. I has got laughs. The music is good too. Not judging it - but the movie is not for those who want to find some meaning. It is pure entertainment. It's called sci-fi but its only fiction not science. People go watch it. Its good entertainment.There is also a bit of politics. Emmerich was very careful not to stress on the nuclear tests as it could lead to unwanted attention on the sub-plots.Ted Elliott(story) & Terry Rossio (story) and Dean Devlin (story) & RolandEmmerich (story) Dean Devlin (screenplay) & Roland Emmerich (screenplay seem to hold to the Shakespeare method of making subplots for realism instead of Aristotlian principle of here and now. But they are careful not to get too much into the subplots to take away the electricity - good job! The acting was bad (flat). David Arnold won the BMI film music award for his music as he deserved. David Bloch and April Webster did a bad job finding the crew. The sound effects were good then again all technical aspects of the film were good. Over all it is a good movie. Watch it Watch it Watch it Watch it Watch it ........

Review title: This movie will make you dumber...
Review_body: This movie is the worst piece of trash to come out of the summer of '98. This proves that the success of "Independence Day" was a fluke for Devlin and Emmerich.  Why on Earth would Hollywood ever hire them to do a film is beyond me...Don't watch this film.  Watch "Jurassic Park" or "JP: the Lost World" instead, this film does nothing but rip off these films among others (such as "Alien" and "Hunt for Red October").  The reason the entire film is in the rain and/or in the dark is to hide the poorly done not-so-special effects.Except for the noble attempts (despite the script) by Jean Reno and Hank Azaria, no one who starred in this trash should ever star in a movie again. Broderick is a has-been actor, and both he and Pitillo show they have virtually no talent at all.Only those with no taste for *decent* film will like this, this abomination.

This movie did not have one redeeming quality.  I almost felt sorry for Matthew Broderick as I watched it.  The special effects were lifted straight from Jurassic Park (the babies looked uncannily like velociraptors).  The scary parts weren't; the funny parts even less so.  The writing bit, and Maria Pitillo's performance was possibly the worst I have ever seen in a major motion picture.  Give me an over-dubbed Japanese flick with a guy in a rubber suit any day of the week over this waste of celluloid.

Don't take it so seriously.If you go to a movie like this for plot or acting that was your first mistake.  Since when have monster movies been known for plot or acting, or heaven forbid (realistic motivations or responses by the characters). Monster movies are here simply for fun and action.  And this movie fills the bill on both counts.  Don't take it so seriously and expect it to be what it was never meant to be.  Just enjoy.

I must say it was very cool to see good old Godzilla in action again - and more ominous than ever! But nostalgia and decent effects is where it ends. How many films have we seen with this plot?? Are we not yet tired of it? Boy gets called in to help (sure, he's worked with mutant earth worms but come on!). Boy meets girl (and gee whiz, the girl's a wannabe reporter who gets the story of her life!). Blah blah blah and then they all run toward the camera from a ball of flame. Sound familiar?? This American plot is wearing thin.

I cannot believe how people could give this film a 10. Haven`t  they seen Jurassic-Park? The first time it was ok, the second time "lala", but the third time it`s a joke. But it seems to work(in Germany), unfortunately.

Review title: A movie with lots of effects but not so good story.
Review_body: My comment on this movie is just BIG. A big monster and a lot of big effects. The story is very thin but the movie was quite funny.

This ain't a movie, it's a commercial!Well it seems to be new way of making a movie: "SPECIAL EFFECTS" There is no room anymore for real acting, I guess. :(During the movie I fell in sleep. That never happened to me before.I will say, stay away from this movie, FOREVER!!!

Okay, so I rented Godzilla so I could see Jean Reno, because he was so good in Mission: Impossible. Turns out he was one of the good things (and by that I mean the *only* good thing) about it. The bulk of the film is running from Godzilla, chasing Godzilla, tricking Godzilla, finding out we weren't really tricking Godzilla, and finally, not really caring what happens to Godzilla because we suddenly have Godzilla's bouncing babies to worry about. Most of the dialogue is clumsy, over-used or unnecessary. There are also some lovely sub-plots (the budding romance between Nick and Audrey, Audrey's struggle to get ahead in life, Nick unbelievably ANNOYING quest to get people to pronounce his last name right)  that do a great job of making the movie very cheesy. But to say *something* in the movie's defense, if you are in to special effects it could be fun to watch, and if you like Jean Reno (or "Rambo") his character is really great, and ALMOST makes the movie worth seeing. But not quite.

Review title: A monster movie like I remember.
Review_body: This movie has received an awful lot of bad press, but I feel it is misdirected.Perhaps the problem is the level of excitement and edge of your seat excitement that many of us have come to expect from today's science fiction. Admittedly this is not one of those movies.Godzilla (1998) is a MOSTER flick.  I watched this film with little expectations and was delightfully surprised.  The movie brought me back to simpler times as a child when I was enthralled by moster movies.  Thanks to incredible computer graphics, the monster was sleeker, smarter and more agile than those of the older generation Godzilla movies.  Don't let these modern updates make you lose sight of a movie of this genre's basic plot and purpose: BIG BAD MONSTER THREATENS THE CITY- PEOPLE MUST KILL THE MONSTER LEAVING SUFFICIENT DOUBT OF ITS DEATH TO ALLOW FOR A RE-MATCH!So many people have cited a lack of a plot to this film.  I'd love to know what they are talking about.  Perhaps the plot was not intricate enough to satisfy them, but there certainly was one.If I may stray from this film for a moment consider that by today's standards, "The Creature from the Black Lagoon" wouldn't last past the first showing, yet I'm sure everyone reading this review has seen it and can picture the "Gil Man" in their minds eye.  Consider "Frankenstein" & "The Mummy", can't you just hear Boris Karloff's eerie voice saying "ankh senama"? No, these movies wouldn't hold up by today's standards yet they remain classics.If you're a monster movie fan, rent this one.  It's worth the three dollars.

What more can you say?Acting - Bad. Plot - Stupid. Dialogue - Worst.The only positives are the great special effects...but even effects-laden blockbusters like "Jurassic Park" (which this is striving badly to be like) had a plot.I rate this movie 10 stinky fish out of ten.

Review title: Why bother watching this movie, when the TV series was so bad?
Review_body: They blew it bad! This movie, even with improved effects, obviously better than the japanese TV series, is as bad as that unmemorable piece of film. It is not worth the film it was made with.

Review title: A great test for your Dolby Digital system, but too bad the movie stinks.
Review_body: How can this be a Godzilla movie? Where's Raymond Burr as the big fat gaijin? Godzilla has been awakened by French nuclear testing in the Pacific and proceeds, for some reason that only a giant, fire-breathing 100 meter tall lizard would know, to New York City to lay his (her's? its? whatever?) eggs. Dr. Niko Tatopoulis (Matthew Broderick who is completely wasted in this role), an expert on radiation mutated life forms is called in to find out exactly what has been leaving this trail of huge 10 meter long footprints pointing at New York. Jean Reno plays Philippe Roache (an even more criminal waste of talent than Broderick's role), an agent of the French government who is trying to cover up the fact that it was the French who woke up this 100 meter tall lizard. This movie is great video fodder if you can get it at "Two for the price of one" night at your local video store, and it will test your Dolby system to the limit, but in the end it is funnier than it is frightening and the only reason why I could give it even three stars was Reno, who somehow manages to come off as a serious character in what is otherwise a very silly movie.

Review title: Could there BE a worse monster movie?
Review_body: Well now.  We're all familiar with the age old movies whereby an oversized monster wreaks havoc on an unsuspecting metropolis.  Godzilla '98 tried to update one of the more popular of these movies to the 90s by adding spectacular effects, a kickass soundtrack and removing all traces of plotline..  and let's not forget our hero Matthew Broderick (who's acting career peaked with Ferris Bueller's Day Off and should have ended directly afterward).  Unfortunately, the movie lacked pretty much EVERYTHING that made the old b-grade flicks worthwhile.  Godzilla '98 lacks atmosphere, character depth, acting skill (acting, period?), context, lastability and watchability.  In general, the film gives Godzilla a bad name.  Take my word for it, this is not what a regular Gojira movie looks like!  This is a new kind of B-grade movie -- The high budget, but unbelievably AWFUL b-grade. The movie genre that can never attract a cult following.Could there BE a worse monster movie?Read the comic instead ;)

Matthew Broderick and Maria Pitillo. Of course no good vote for "the best film in 1998"...so we have heard it in TV in the days before starting. The film is good when you only want to see good sequences of monster-action...but really...I prefer the good old T-Rex in "Jurassic Park"!In my eyes it could be a good movie if Emmerich nominated real characters and not these two "experts".4 of 10

When I went to see this movie I was not expecting another "Shawshank Redemption" or "Schindler`s List". I was going to see this movie purely for its special effects. But when they look like something out of the old 50`s version, you can`t help but feel a little disappointed. That combined with poor acting (especially Maria Pitillo!), pathetic story line and an absolutely terrible script make Godzilla the worst film of 1998 and possibly of all time!

Ok, it wasn't Gone With the Wind or something, but COME ON!!!  Movies are all about escapism, and it's great to watch a movie and not need to keep thinking "Oh, that actor is so gorgeous", instead concentrating on the movie.  And the movie was good.  It could have been better (Much Better), but it could have been Much Much worse!  Cut them some slack!

Inept, bumbling, stupid, asinine.  The worst movie I have seen at a theater in my life, and the first one I walked out of halfway through.  Only the comic-relief Frenchmen were at all interesting or funny; the rest was merely deeply, deeply stupid and implausible even for a silly monster movie.  Either the writers were brain-dead, or brain-dead directors and producers ignored most of what they wrote and substituted their own drivel.  Not even so-bad-it's-good...no redeeming virtues whatever. Didn't work on any level, not as monster flick, spoof, anything at all.

Review title: Fun movie that's getting a bad reputation.
Review_body: This is an enjoyable movie to watch. For those of you out there that have written reviews and have used words such as "contrived", "characterization", and etc. you really shouldn't have wasted your money or time seeing the movie in the first place. These people are so full of self importance that they would go to the lengths of rebuking a monster-movie for it's intellectual worth. It has no intellectual worth. It's a monster movie. That's not difficult to understand, and for those of us who don't place ourselves on a pedestal, we can just enjoy it for what it is - a Godzilla movie. For those of you who had enjoyed Godzilla movies previous to the US version, then there isn't any reason not to enjoy this one.

Ladies & gentlemen, let me introduce myself as one, unique, warped individual.  In what sense?  Am I the only person on this planet that enjoyed this eye-fest of a flick?  If you went into this movie expecting a high brow, thought provoking, deeply characterised, emotion-stirring movie then of course you are going to be disappointed.  What Godzilla is though, is a thoroughly enjoyable special-effects laden romp.  Yes, the acting is a bit ropey in places.  Yes, it relies heavily on special effects. Yes, the characterisation is a bit shallow.  But so what!  Did  you enjoy it?  My answer is an emphatic YES!!!  Grab a tub of popcorn, dim the lights, turn the surround sound up and marvel as Madison Square Gardens see more action than it has done for many years.A definite 7 outta 10

Review title: My pick for the worst movie ever.
Review_body: I felt compelled to post a review of this movie after reading some other reviews that referred to it as, "Not that bad."It IS that bad, and worse.  From the terrible plot, riddled with inconsistencies, to the acting (everyone) which made my fourth grade's production of The H.M.S. Pinafore seem Tony award-worthy, to the dialogue which was inane when supposedly serious and pathetic when supposedly funny, this film sets a new standard for drivel.The special effects are ok, but come nowhere close to saving this film. If you want to see good special effects, there are literally hundreds of movies you should spend time watching rather than this one.If you are thinking of renting this movie, do not.  In fact, if you come across the package for this movie sitting on the shelf in the rental store, turn around and run as fast as you can in the opposite direction and pray that you did not get close enough for the aura of black energy emanating from the box to poison your soul.This was the only movie for which I have ever left the theater before it was over.  I left at the very end -- I didn't want to walk out after the theater lights came on and run the risk of being recognized.

The plot was mediocre, the antagonist godzilla seemed near invincible in one scene, and completely weak in others. and it seemed the movie tried to make the audience care about the giant lizard The acting was fairly bad with all characters who aren't in the army completely under-reacting (at lack of a better word) to the situation.(Mild spoiler) The CGI was one of the movies big flaws, the movements of godzilla are too human, and skin appears too un-organic and leather like. The bright colored eyes definitely subtracted from the overall feel of the creature.The creature only ever appears at night, i don't know maybe CGI doesn't work during the day or something.Worst of all the infant reptiles' movements are exceedingly robotic in many scenes, and smooth in others.The dialogs are bland and mostly snappy responses followed by action, the movie is completely LOADED with cheesy scenes/strategies of defeating the monsters/lines.

Review title: Like Hot, Bitter Asparagus Pee in Your Face
Review_body: Ten years later, this film's memory still burns.Its *way* too long, for one thing. By the time Broderick and Co. are facing down the Baby Raptor-Zilla menace at MSG, you will wish this piece of dreck was all over.By now, you are probably well aware that the titular giant monster isn't *really* the Godzilla you grew up watching. He doesn't look like Godzilla; nor does he breathe radioactive fire. Lame.It seems the director and producer didn't really like the Godzilla films produced by Toho in the 1950's through the 70's. That's like hiring someone who doesn't believe in electricity to wire your home.The only thing heretical than the film is the soundtrack. Sweet Christ, why would you allow Sean "Puff Daddy/Puffy/P. Diddy/Diddy" Colmes and Dino-Rocker Jimmy Page to tear up and disgrace the Led Zep classic "Kashmir?" I swear, at one point the lyrics read "I Do Not Like You/I Flip then Bite You/Uh-Huh, Come With Me"
I don't think it is as bad as people say if it would be a original kaiju i don't think it would have gain as mush hate,

Review title: Good movie, but too much disappointment. :(
Review_body:
Godzilla looks:5/10
Story line: 5/10
Hype:2/10
Action:8/10
Visual effects:6/10
Comparison to Toho's Godzilla movies:1/10
Comparison to Legendary's other Godzilla movies: 3/10
Overall:3.6/10
Which is about: 4/10
Truly a dark, gritty, brutal monster movie. They don't make them like they used to anymore :(

Being a Godzilla fan for many years you can imagine my excitement when the museum trailer burst on to screen showing Godzilla's foot! Finally my favourite movie monster was getting the BIG budget re-make it so deserved, coupled with my favourite movie makes Devlin and Emmerich it seemed as if the film was going to be taylor made just for me! After the months of hype and grabbing every scrap of info i could find to try to get the plot, Zilla's final look, and inside gossip, i bought my ticket and grasped it tightly as i was so wound up to see this movie and could only imagine what modern technology would do for my beloved monster.After 2+ hours of movie and coming back down to reality, i could not help but remain a little confused as to what i just saw? It sounded like Godzilla, the plot was a typical Godzilla plot, even both versions of his name were mentioned, but try as i might, i have to admit, it just didn't FEEL like Godzilla.If your just looking for a big monster mash up with some tongue in cheek humour, then this is for you. If its the essence and spirit of Godzilla then you might feel like me. Its a good movie but it promised so much, i suppose it was unrealistic to expect a movie with this kind of material to deliver the 'total package' that was in ID4.

Didn't anyone laugh at the original Godzilla? I mean, the thing looked so hokey that you either had to laugh or change the channel.This movie has great special effects, so I guess a lot of people took it more seriously, and thought it was dumb.Yes, it's dumb. That's the point. That's what makes it funny.*** SPOILER ALERT *** My favorite part is when they just destroyed all the baby godzillas and eggs, and are now face to face with an angry mother godzilla. So they all stand around for a second, and then someone says "What should we do now?", and someone else says "Running would be a good idea", at which point they all run screaming.

Review title: A GOOD FILM, but shouldn't bare the name Godzilla
Review_body: This is a good action popcorn movie. The thing is, it shouldn't be called Godzilla because it bares more respect towards Jurrassic Park than it does Godzilla. Godzilla doesn't even look like Godzilla, he looks like a T-Rex, Godzilla isn't a T-Rex, he's a cross between two dinosaurs (the T-Rex and Stegasorause) In this film he doesn't even breath fire (the scene where he roars and the cars blow up is often mistaken as him breathing fire) Godzilla isn't to be taken out by the military, he's suppose to be attacked by another monster which defends the city. Over all, its OK and great for the action, but doesn't count as Godzilla. In the Film "Godzilla, Mothra and King Ghidorah: Giant Monsters All-Out Attack" they mention that a giant monster sitting happened in New York City which was believed to be Godzilla, but really wasn't. Then in "Godzilla- Final Wars" the Japanese Godzilla fights the American Godzilla (Japan renames him Zilla) and the Japanese Godzilla take him out with his fire breath easily. This should be renamed "Zilla" thats all it should be, GREAT FILM, not a Godzilla film

It's been almost five years since this film came out back in 1998. I can remember the very first TV Spot on television around New Years. As a HUGE Godzilla fan I was excited to say the least. And I must tell you, when I saw it when it finally came out I wasn't dissapointed, and to this day I still feel the same way.It's a darn shame that this film gets blasted like it does. It shows me that the majority of the people (and Godzilla fans) that take the time to write reviews for films probably don't know what they are talking about when they talk of America's "Godzilla".There are a couple of main issues critics and Godzilla fans have with the film. The story and the monster itself, 'Godzilla'.If you look back at all of the original Japanese Godzilla flicks, you aren't going to find a great (not to mention BELIEVABLE) story or plot. I realize this, even being a fan of all things Godzilla. Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich's 'Godzilla' atleast, in my opinion, had the audience believing what was going on up on the screen. And if the story was slightly dull to some of you, you should let it pass. Remember what 'Godzilla' is about, afterall.And what was wrong with the monster itself, Godzilla? Nothing. If you get two action figures, one being a model of the original Godzilla from the Japanese series and a model of the new American Godzilla you will find differences but both are remarkably alike in alot of ways. They both have the spikes, gigantic size, and famous roar. The major differences being the skin color, face, and longer legs. I loath it when people bring up how they shouldn't have changed Godzilla's looks. I mean, I love the old Godzilla look, it may be silly to some, but to me it's still cool. But it would NOT have worked for this film at ALL. If they had made the American version with a creature that had big 'googily' eyes and flying around on his tail kicking monsters, it would have ended up being a laugh-fest at the theaters.What the American 'Godzilla' brings us is a believable monster that has the spirit and characteristics of the original, that satisfies the audience. It was just more realistic. Shouldn't we have expected that? Devlin and Emmerich came up with a monster that was realistic. Something the creators of the original attempted at doing but were limited to rubber suits. Something the Japanese audience accepts, but the American audience will not. It's sad that most Godzilla fans and critics do not understand this.I personally believe that the majority of the general audience ENJOYED this film. It's just the critical blasting from G Fans and Critics that got alot of attention, unfortunately, and therefore this gets labeled as a 'bad' film. It's sad really that people can't enjoy this film.This is one of my favorite DVD's to plug in. It's Big, Loud, and Fun. And although we've had lots of great films with tons of Special Effects, there's nothing quite like it.So take a look at it, be open and I'm sure you will enjoy the fantastic pop-corn entertainment known as "GODZILLA".

Review title: Highly underrated......one of the top monster movies
Review_body: I am happy that so many people have written here in favor of the movie although it was dumped by the critics. Frankly, as far as monster movies go, this one should rank among the top just because of the numerous subplots that it employs which sort of adds to the primary event. Also there is an elaborate attempt at the background behind the appearance of Godzilla and his activities, which is often missing in much more acclaimed films like Cloverfield (which I feel is a one-dimensional and grossly overrated movie). When you decide to watch a film like Godzilla, you are ready to suspend your disbelief but you hope that the events shown will be coherent and at the same time unexpected. That, in my opinion, this film achieves. Also, it is well acted, especially the ever reliable Jean Reno and a clever and vulnerable Matthew Broderick, ably supported by a cameo from Hank Azaria. It manages to be funny at the most unexpected situations, like the incredulous scene where the taxi is inside Godzilla's mouth. All in all, it deserves a 7, but an extra star in sympathy for the unfortunate critical response.

Review title: Good as a film in it's own right but as a Godzilla film...
Review_body: Godzilla is a brilliant franchise and a remake was going to happen sooner are later, but what we got, well, It wasn't really Godzilla at all was it? I mean nobody was expecting the original man in a suit campy monster film that captured our hearts but we at least expected a monster that looked like Godzilla. They made some big changes, eg: Godzilla can't breathe fire, he is much smaller and is not indestructible. Up until a certain point in the film the movie remains true to the original film apart from one thing. In the original Godzilla Godzilla was created by American nuclear bombs. In this remake he is created by FRENCH NUCLEAR BOMBS. Just shows how willing America is to pass the blame from themselves to their arch rivals. And why the hell is Godzilla killed by the military! That ruins the film for everyone. Then it just completely strays away from the original. GODZILLA LAYS EGGS? THAT HATCH INTO VELOCIRAPTERS? Godzilla's offspring was just an excuse to rip off the rapter scene from Jurrasic park. Overall it is in some ways worth watching just, don't expect much!

Wesconnosehny wrote one of the shortest, funniest reviews of this movie.I'm a huge monster/sci-fi fan, but after seeing 'Godzilla' in a theater on opening day, I felt oddly ambivalent. I didn't hate the movie, neither did I fall in love with it. The film was okay, but nothing special. As with 'Independence Day' and '2012,' 'Godzilla' was crammed with tankerloads of expertly-rendered CG imagery, but the film had very little magic, or heart (or soul). It didn't fire my imagination the way I expected it to. It didn't inspire the sense of awe I was looking for. Godzilla him(her?)self just looked like a bigger version of the pet iguana I used to have--nothing remarkable there--and the human characters were so flat and forgettable, it was hard to care what happened to any of them. A couple of lines of pithy dialogue don't make for engaging characters. It wasn't the fake-looking rubber shark that made 'Jaws' such a success (the special effects weren't that great), it was the script and the characters--things that had nothing to do with special effects.I read that Roland Emmerich insisted on having Godzilla be able to run really fast. Which, again, would be very accurate if Godzilla were an iguana. But to me, one of Godzilla's most compelling qualities is that he is ostensibly so massive and powerful, he's not afraid of anything and doesn't have to run from anybody. If Emmerich wants to push the 'realism' issue--which is a mistake--I would argue that no reptile, no matter how big or fast, would be able to survive or outmaneuver a squad of F-14 fighter jets. (The conundrum, of course, is that the bigger Godzilla is, the harder it would be for him to outmaneuver them.) 'Jurassic Park' set the CG bar pretty high. Since then, CG effects have become so polished and prolific (and overused?) that they're a dime a dozen. They've lost their 'wow' factor. (Except for 'Avatar' maybe.) Perhaps I've seen so many fantasy/sci-fi movies that I've gotten a little jaded, but it takes more than just a few ingenious digital effects to impress me these days. During the fighter-jet chase through the maze of Manhattan skyscrapers, I felt less like I was watching a movie than a giant first-person shooter game. If I'd wanted that, I'd have played with an X-box. (At least I'd have had the fun of doing some of the shooting.) I wasn't disappointed with 'Godzilla' because it was all that bad, but because it just wasn't all that good.

If it be relevant, it be here. Pumpkin Swirl's Blog of Everything HomeAbout Me « Resident Evil ReviewResident Evil: Apocalypse Review » Godzilla (1998) ReviewIn 1998 Godzilla was being hyped as the biggest movie of all time. If you can't remember just imagine back in 2009 when Avatar was released and it was hyped beyond belief and predicted to break box office records. Zilla was predicted to do the exact same thing in 1998, but it eventually fell short and is considered a flop by most. I on the other hand think it's a damn good movie. It has everything I want in a big budget action movie. But that's REALLY why people hate it. Because they don't look at it as a summer movie. Instead they look at it like it's supposed to be an epic like Lord of the Rings, a drama featuring a giant lizard, or a big ole tub of cheese like the Japanese Godzilla movies. This means that there's two kinds of people who hate on the 90s Godzilla. Nerds who love the crappy Japan version and movie Nazis who hate everything. I mean seriously, what do you expect from a movie about a giant lizard who is running around New York City? I personally got what I wanted from it. A fun action packed movie that kept me entertained for a few hours.The picture about is another reason a lot pf people hated the new Godzilla. They hated him because he wasn't the bulky, slow moving, guy in a suit that is the original Godzilla. I personally think that Roland Emerich's Godzilla looks 10 times better than the thing below.90s Zilla looks much more vicious and bad ass than Tokyo Zilla. I will admit though that if I was a big fan of Japan Godzilla i'd be very disappointed at the American design. But I'd also realize that most Americans (myself included) wouldn't pay money for the pure cheese plots that Japanese Godzilla movies have. Yes, Zilla battling another monster could be done okay if the right director did it but I think they took the right route by making this one a movie about Godzilla attacking a city. If you watch the 90s cartoon they make Zilla Jr. exactly how you want him anyways. So don't bitch about the movie version. As if a giant lizard would emerge from the Hudson river and run around the city and the mayor would say "ohhh lets make friends just in case another monster ever comes along."Overall I thoughly enjoyed the movie for what it is. I enjoyed the bad acting, the story, and the very well done action scenes. This comes from a guy who really likes man vs beast movies though so IO'm probably just a little bit biased. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who wants to sit down and have a good time watching a movie for a few hours. It's great for that.4/5The above review was taken from my blog so it might not make total sense, but I think it gets the jist of it.

I saw Godzilla with my grandfather and my elder brother Abhinav in one of the cinemas in Shimla. It sure brings back some great childhood memories. With some brilliant special effects, good background score, nice performances and awesome cinematography it surely tops my list of favorite movies of all times. From the very beginning Godzilla was just meant to be enjoyed and not criticized. The action scenes are so well executed you can actually feel the chill run down your spine.Matthew Broderick as Dr. Niko does some commendable job as a geek main lead. The romance between Maria Pitillo as Audrey and Dr. Niko is not over the top but it surely shows nice chemistry between the two of them. Jean Reno as Philippe, a french agent and Hank Azaria as Victor, the cameraman (The scene where victor almost gets stepped down by Godzilla was nail biting) add humor to the story. The one liners are good but there's a lot of situational comedy in the action scenes which makes you laugh. In the end one feels a bit pity for the giant being, clearly showing that the presentation can alter the perception.With no obscenity or abusive language and no sex I would recommend Godzilla to all horror and action lover children and adult alike. The memory of this movie is etched in my memory forever. I am really unable to comprehend all the bad reviews that Godzilla got, but then to each his own.

Firstly, I'm one that never looked twice at the old GZ films, tho I'm sure they're good in their own ways, they just never caught me. But I did love Jurassic Park (first AND second, both awesome movies)- as well as Independence Day (what is up with other positive reviews for GZ'98 having to diss JP & iD4?)- and this movie has everything I loved about them combined. I don't see movies just for "special effects", I see them for good adventures and snarky humour. If you're looking for the same, this movie shouldn't disappoint. I loved the casting AND the writing- all of the characters are memorable AND quotable (same writers as the Pirates movies!). I remember, when I went to see JP2 in 1997, there was a teaser for GZ'98 during the trailers. It was the scene where GZ's foot comes down on the T-Rex display in the museum (tho that later turns out to be a deleted scene). From that moment I was excited to see it- which I did the next summer on the bigscreen. I've loved it ever since. Matthew Broderick and Hank Azaria and Jean Reno are just great to have along in this adventure. It's one of those movies that I can watch whenever, and get hooked for the entire ride all over again, every time. Another memory is when it was on Pay-Per-View around late '98, sometimes I'd watch / listen to it in scribblevision (if you had cable back then, you might know what I mean). I got the video as soon as it came out. And then the DVD. When I started vidding in 2005, I made a vid for it, which you can see at my YouTube page (SimbiAni), it's titled "Feel The Rain". The reason I finally got around to leaving a comment for it here at IMDb, is because it is on TV right now and it occurred to me to check its page here, and after seeing the unfortunate low user ratings... decided might as well. It seems these days (from various movie boards) the majority of "average ppl as movie critics" can't make up their mind for what they want in a movie- either there is a somewhat or complete lack of plot or too much story to understand what is going on. Thankfully, I'm neither. If I had to choose a fave scene, it is definitely the taxi chase thru the city and onto the bridge. Likewise, if I had to choose a favorite quote (tho there are SO many!), it would have to be also from the bridge scene- Victor: "Oh you gotta be kidding me, man! We're in his MOUTH! We're iN his MOUTH!" *crunching* "You're going the wrong way, man! You're GOiNG the WRONG WAY!" Phillipe: "Will you shut up now?!" Just awesome!

OMFG! I mean, you cannot really expect the worst of the grandmaster of tard-fiction, but this one pretty much nailed it. I mean, the book is so ridiculously bad in every 3rd sentence of dialogue and non-dialogue. Why TF is an unknown worm-expert is called to a "so-called" Godzilla Task Force and every other people in this "task force" seem so incredibly incompetent. I mean, even the chaos mathematician in Jurassic Park played by Jeff Goldblum expressed more applyable knowledge than Matthew Broderick in this movie. And he is not even a bad actor. So it's the playwright's and director's fault all the way.And before the book, there is the idea, the concept. The idea, the concept to start is so ridiculous: why TF would a gigantic lizard voyage from Japan through the Pacific Ocean, then the Atlantic Ocean, only to land exactly in Manhattan, propably the most populated area in the world, to build its nest? Is LA not sufficient enough? I mean: I feel personally offended by this "twist of drama".The latter half of the film I didn't watch because the first half was an insult. To me. The audience. To people with an IQ above 80.

I only saw this movie yesterday (yes, I know, it's been out there for 14 years now). Well, kinda 'saw it' - luckily, I was wise enough (or bored enough?) to keep switching channels, so I saw maybe half of it, maybe a bit less. The movie is too bad to waste much time writing a review about it. All I'm gonna say is this: yes, he really pushed a giant head of a killer monster, with mouth filled with sharp, snapping teeth, out of an elevator WITH HIS FOOT. Hush, go away, bad bad godzilla, leave me alone now! He really did, I saw it on TV!!! The movie starts dumb and it only gets dumber as it progresses. If you like that kind of films, this is the one to watch!

Review title: What is Really Wrong With This Movie
Review_body: This is in fact a really decent movie in my opinion. Sure the human characters can be annoying at time,that doesn't mean it is a bad flick. Now that doesn't mean I like the movie, it is decent but think to yourself, what is really wrong with this movie?Follows more on Jurassic Park then Godzilla - Rain Overdose - Annoying Human Characters - And much more.The reason why a lot of Godzilla fans hate this movie, is not for the reasons above, it is just the fact that is called "Godzilla". If it was renamed something else (or renamed 'Zilla' to 'keep' it in the Godzilla Movie Family) then this movie wouldn't be as hated. But still if you are able to push the flaws somewhere else and tell your brain that this isn't a Godzilla movie, then I encourage you to watch this movie.

Review title: French nuclear testing on island mutates a lizard inhabitant so it grows to huge size, which then swims to New York and begins to wreak havoc.
Review_body: A lot of people seem to bash this movie based on the success of the first Gojira movies and the whole franchise. But I think it is a little bit harsh, and the reviews I've read that pan this film seem to take the movie out of context. For what it is, Godzilla does a relatively good job.It it's not supposed to be a great character study. It's not supposed to be high drama - it is a special effects movie, and an action movie. For someone who was quite young when it came out would be entertained by its whole "cool giant lizard" aspect, and that's what matters. The film sets out to entertain, and, for the most part, it does. The special effects are good, the acting satisfactory, and the dialogue passable. Come on, it's not that bad! All in all, I would say it's a good movie for a class of kids to watch on a rainy day in the last week of school.

It isn't that bad of a movie when you look at the movies we have today. I find this one to have more story and better characters then the new Godzilla. And Godzilla himself got a rather neat and sleek look!OK. The story isn't great, the characters are silly and a male Godzilla being able to vanish in a city to lay his eggs. Yeah. I get you. Its very silly.But that is what makes it great! Its not trying to be identical to Japanese Godzilla. This one isn't a laser beam breath GOD! It is simply a animal trying to find a place to nurture it's offspring. The people in the city will serve as snack for the kids!The actors are aware their roles are silly and it shows. Only a couple of them had poor acting. They are all slightly silly and goofy and even likable and memorable.Godzilla is pretty likable himself! Hes not going after humans as a food source. He eats fish! And lots of fish! If you get under his feet...well that's a shame but he wont target you(unless you murder his children!). He can take damage, he flees and fights for his life. He mourns and wants revenge for his lost children and walks in a trap doing so.All in all. Its a silly movie with quite a bit of action and you get to see the monster a lot! unlike most of todays movies. Just don't turn it on and expect a movie with great plot and similarities to the Japanese Godzilla.
Dont expect a nomited oscar movie, its a great movie for entertaiment, thats all. Great chilhood memories whit this movie
No, it's not Gone With the Wind, but it is fun, action packed, fast paced, comic as well as personable, character laden, hero laden, and re-watchable. The best of the genre.

Don't get me wrong, I did enjoy watching this movie, but I felt (possible spoiler) that the directors should have picked a CGI Godzilla more like the classic Godzilla I grew up with. I don't mean a bulky man-in-a-suite looking Godzilla but a sleeker version of the 90s version of Godzilla. But other then the CGI-zilla, I have no problems with the rest of the movie. One thing I noticed was the stupidity of the military I think is a tribute to military of the old Godzilla movies, who never learn that tanks do not hurt the giant monsters. I think people should just sit back and enjoy the movie as a fun action romp with big explosions.
What do you want? It was fun, it had no blood and guts,no sex or nudity,no one shown to be killed.We're getting too critical sit back and enjoy.

I was really amazed: Roland Emmerich dared to actually turn Godzilla into the most ridiculous rip-off of "Jurassic Park". And a poor man's Jurassic Park it became. We see T-Rex in New York, for 2 hours. If the special effects would have improved compared to the original there would have been at least a minor reason to see this trash. But they didn't improve. In fact , they are much inferior - that's probably the reason why 90 % of the CGI effects take place in darkness and pouring rain. To conceal their unrealistic looks. But then again, who would complain about the effects if the film was thrilling and fun ? We have an extremely weak script here that bores us with cardboard characters who keep saying the same old unoriginal lines over and over. It's really hard to keep yourself from thinking "I could have written this when I was 10". At the premiere I attended in Germany, about 1/4 of the audience left the cinema prior to the ending. I wasn't one of them, but I wish I hadn't wasted 2h of my lifetime with such a boring, unentertaining film. I'd hope Emmerich will spare the world with a sequel, but of course he won't.

Review title: Very happy that I waited for cable
Review_body: Glad to see that it lived up to all the hype for badness. Now if Ron Underwood had done this, it might have been as much fun as Tremors.

I have been looking forward to seeing this film for months....and I wanted to shoot myself midway through.This film is bad in every sense of the word, it serves up cliche after cliche after cliche and worst of all no payoff at the end!Look at Jaws for example a movie where the audience marvelled at the sight of a shark. Usually there would be nothing amazing about it we've all seen one before right? on T.V. in a documentary or in Sea World. However in that movie we were not given a glimpse of the shark until 3/4 of the way through, just the carnage it left behind...which was what made it so terrifying.In this movie a half an hour hasn't gone by and this totally unoriginal unscary monster shows up and the audience had nothing to look forward to.If there was rating lower than 1 on the imdb I would give it -15.

Review title: Godzilla too quiet and too nice
Review_body: If Godzilla had made the high pitched scream of the old movies and purposely stomped a few people into the mud, this would have been a really good movie.

Watch some of the old Godzilla movies!  If it werent for Godzilla being such a cool monster, they are pretty lame - plot wise!This Godzilla is no different!   Well actually, this is a different monster - A cool monster, but not the old Godzilla!This Godzilla is a whole lot more watchable than the old movies... Get rid of the Raptors from Jurassic Park tho!I enjoyed Godzilla 98 trashing New York and in particular the building that I work in!! (maybe thats why i like the movie!)For those who say the cab scene is unbelievable - its a dinosaur rampaging through Manhattan!!!!!  That in itself is unbelievable!I give it a 7 out of 10

Review title: What a complete waste of time and money!
Review_body: Well, messieurs Devlin and Emmerich have done it again. I was 100% certain they couldn't come up with anything worse than the utterly dismal Independence Day, but these guys always seem to come up with the goods. Godzilla must be one of the worst movies I have ever seen, and believe me, I've seen a lot of bad movies. First of all, it's a nitpickers' heaven; the script is chock-full of illogical skips and jumps, nonsensical ideas and just completely stupid in-duh-viduals. The photography looks like a TV -show, the actors (in the broadest sense of the word) have been left completely without direction and despite the loud action, the movie's boring you to tears in less than an hour. When the movie had been running for 75 minutes, a friend of mine leaned over and whispered "This has to end soon. I can't take much more of this", to which I replied "only an hour more to go". He got up, collected his jacket and left. I used to think that Matthew Broderick was a passable actor. Well, no more. While he was horribly bad, it was nothing compared to the female lead. In one scene, she is sitting on a bed, sobbing. I couldn't tell whether she was supposed to be faking it and trying to get some sympathy from the other person in the room, or whether she was actually trying (and failing miserably) to portray a woman crying. Even the most preposterous faults in the script are too numerous to go into here, just go and find a nitpicker's website and laugh yourself silly. I'm going to see the movie again, this time armed with a print-out of the script's faults and ready to ruin the movie for everyone by pointing out the faults in a loud voice. Thank God I don't have to pay for the admission. I suggest no-one else does either, ever.

Review title: Just the film you can expect, though good in its kind
Review_body: I went to this movie expecting a kind of Independence Day-alike spectacular special-effects movie. And I wasn't disappointed. Although it takes the movie a long time to come to the end, it is in its own kind a good movie. It is pure entertainment, don't expect any characters other than flat, the movie doesn't dig deep but you don't waste your time watching it.

Review title: Seeing this film can cause brain damage
Review_body: As pathetic as most remakes are, this one is more fitting of Mystery Science Theater 3000 than the original Japanese movies.The only thing I liked about it was getting to see the Air Force level Madison Square Garden.You MUST see this film, but only to believe with your own eyes this shoddy piece of work.

I liked this movie.  I guess a lot of this has to do with my attitude coming into it.  I wasn't expecting much drama, and I wasn't surprised.  But what attracted me most was the tongue-in-cheek style comedy throughout the movie. It's kind of like James Bond in this way.I think Matthew Broderick and Jean Reno both did an excellent job.The DVD features included a quote from the Writer/Producer.  He said he was looking to create an infectious popcorn movie.  I believe he succeeded.

I'll easily name Godzilla one of the worst movies ever made- and I truly wasn't expecting much, but I would have paid money not to have sit through this.  If you haven't seen it, consider yourself lucky.  The one thing this movie had going for it, the special effects, were far outweighed by the horrible acting and bad dialogue, which is is ridiculous, unbelievable, unimaginative and just plain cheesy.

Review title: You either love it or hate it.
Review_body: My wife and daughter thought Godzilla was worth the time, they gave it a 7. I didn't......worst plot line, acting and script of the year. I was generous with a 3. Better luck next time Mat.
This movie was very cool! My favorite part was the baby Godzilla chase in Madison Square Garden! Animal is very cool=)He rocks in this movie and The Simpsons=)

Godzilla is a giant, nuclear mutated lizard. With that, how could anyone possibly take it seriously? This goes for the "old" Godzilla (a giant, nuclear mutated extinct dinosaur) as well.I have loved the "old" Godzilla movies since I was 7 and in all honesty, they are terrible. The acting doesn't even make it up to the level of "poor." The effects are laughable at best. But what they are is fun. This is the same as the "new" Godzilla. This time there is no man in a big rubber suit. The monster looks just plain good. And at least there is some sort of reason for it running through NYC instead of it crashing through a city because it's in a foul mood. The reason may be full of holes (why NYC, Tokyo is closer. How'd it KNOW about cities in the first place?), but at least there's a reason.All of the negative things that have been said about this movie thus far have been some of the things the older versions had been praised for. And while there are obvious rip-offs of other movies, remember these are the same makers of Independence Day, a film that didn't have one original idea, but is a collection of other science fiction movies. This is apparently the producer's method of making movies. People can see this as ripping off -- negative -- or see it as an homage to other great films -- positive.I'll buy this movie. I'll sit and watch it over and over again. I'll laugh at all the rotten parts. I'll have fun doing it. Sometimes that's the whole point of watching movies.
Not exactly a Godzilla vs Rodan here. Rent an old Godzilla movie, and spare yourself the beany-baby 'Zilla they tried to foist on us with his new movie.
Despite what has been said, I thought that Godzilla was a good movie. The special effects are great. The acting isn't anything special but is good enough to be overlooked. Overall a 9.
I saw the film and I liked it very much. It shows good sense of humor. I also liked Jean Reno.

I'm almost ashamed of myself for having to review this. Godzilla turns out to be a tremendous disaster. Poor effects, awful acting, and just plain stupidity come off the screen for over two hours. This one makes the Japanese Godzilla films look like award winners. The pits! I think the producers should have at least read the script before filming this turkey. Broderick is totally miscast. And does anyone ever wonder how Godzilla as big as he is-manages to fit in those 8' sewer drains? Whatever!

A lot of people disliked Godzilla. Not so with me. I found it a very enjoyable, fun movie to watch, with great special effects. I additionally liked the new American Godzilla a lot. There were no Oscar worthy acting performances here, but most of them do a sufficient job, and I was especially impressed by Frenchman Jean Reno, who was really a funny, interesting character to watch. Godzilla isn't the greatest movie, but it is a great one to watch on a boring, Friday night. Check it out!

I expected much, but it turned out as a waste of money. Really I fell asleep during the final scene, the scene that supposed to be  really exciting and full of action. Also the special effects were not what i expect of an 1998 movie.3 out of 10

Review title: O.K. movie if you fastforward through all scenes with people
Review_body: I never though a new godzilla movie could be made with a worse plot then the old japanese classics. The reason this movie sucks and the classics rule is that the oldies were so bad they were good, this movie is so bad its almost unwatchable. Plus why was this godzilla based on some guys iguana and not GODZILLA! I have to admit that even though this Godzilla really isn't Godzilla it is cool watching (Iguanamonster) run around smashing stuff. Just don't pay attention to the plot(Worm Guy!!!) or the acting, or you will cry.Gojira, Gojira, Gojira!!

Review title: Perhaps the most irritating movie I've ever seen
Review_body: I wish sci-fi/action movie producers would hire decent writers and directors; people capable of providing realistic and interesting characters. The effects in this film were somewhat satisfying and engaging, but the main characters (with the exception of Hank Azaria's character) ruined most of the scenes.Audrey, the "love interest" for Matthew Broderick's role, is perhaps one of most irritating female characters I've ever seen on film - shallow, stupid, totally lacking in judgment, and she runs like "Gloria" from Body Double; a film not known for its satisfying female characters.What's perhaps most sad, except for the fact that she miraculously manages to triumph (sort of), is that the director tried to make Audrey lovable and appealing to the audience, as a vulnerable, sweet, yet misguided woman, despite her effective ability to alienate the interest and care of most female AND male audience members. How could they not see their blunder and correct it by feeding Audrey to Godzilla at the end? I have never been to a movie wherein I eagerly joined audience members chanting "EAT HER!" We were disappointed.And why, I wonder, did they think it was a good idea to name 4 or 5 of the French characters "Jean-_____"?A recommendation to any aspiring directors: make sure the annoying characters get eaten, and if you really insist on naming 80% of your French characters Jean-something, at least have them laugh at themselves for it IN the movie - don't just hope people will notice and think its funny, because they won't.

Review title: What I expected is what I got
Review_body: I scored Godzilla 10 out of 10 and let me tell you, why:First, this is a monsterfilm and what I want from a monsterfilm is a monster and maybe some stupid humans it squeezes. And we've got it.Second, this is a spectacular film and what I want from a spectacular film is a bunch of monumental scenes made with the latest technics (CGI here), which stick me to the seat. And Godzilla's got lots of them.I don't know, why do people watch a movie, if they don't like its style in advance and write later stupid reviews comparing the film to completely different ones or expecting things, which are absolutely not the part of that type of movie (like here criticizing the actors).So if you like spectacular monsterfilms, Godzilla is your film! And you'll get the actual level of CGI animation in '98.

Review title: Possibly the worst movie ever made.
Review_body: Any human who actually took the time to rate this movie and not give it a 1 must have been smoking large quantities of crack immediately before they voted.  I would rather have my eyelids removed than sit through this movie again.  I hope the corporation that made this movie is very happy with all the money they've made.

Review title: Couldn't be further from the truth
Review_body: Ok, I think we are missing something here. Wasn't Godzilla supposed to be the good guy. The big lizard that saved Tokyo more than once when the people were in trouble. So why not has Godzilla suddenly become the bad guy. I just don't get it. It's probably the army's habit of treating anything they don't understand as a national threat and want to destroy it.Highlights of the movie were the street chases through Manhattan. You got the army throwing everything they got at Godzilla and not even a scratch, they even lost some of their own men and weapons. And they went and did it again! Gives new meaning to military intelligence. And since when can a torpedo lock on to organic material. Great move evading those torpedoes Godzilla.

I don't know why this film has gotten such a bad aggregate rating, it's brilliant! I watched the 2014 Godzilla movie recently, and then this one, and this is the one to watch :D It's a love letter to New York, it's slyly funny, and there are plenty of belly laughs too. The actress playing Audrey is playing the role like she was directed, I think, because she is the perfect foil to Matthew Broderick's character... and what a character - instead of the usual steely-eyed macho man, we have a mild-mannered, serious guy who studies worms ;> It's all a heck of a lot of great fun, really intelligent, really funny, the requisite amount of explosions, I guess... even the monster has personality. The basketball scene in Madison Square Gardens? HA! Love this movie.

A lot of people have criticized this movie since it first came out.There is absolutely nothing wrong with this movie. I don't really understand what is there not to like in it.I am guessing that only die hard japanime Godzilla (Gojira) fans may find it out of context because 'Godzilla didn't spit fire' or something but , on a more serious note,the movie was well directed, the special effects were top notch back (10 years ago!) , the acting was really good , which made up for an awesome and credible storyline.Unlike a lot of the haters out there , I think I had not even heard of Godzilla or Gojira before the movie came out , therefore I think those who enjoy action-packed movies , should indeed enjoy this amazing movie.10/10

Review title: Imdb has to make a new category: the movies which have low rating you should definitely see...
Review_body:
First of all I can assure you that it's definitely one of the most underrated Motion Pictures. When I first watched it on big screen in 1998 I liked it most, but after too many years I tried to look at it again and I was just stucked at it. for 1998 the vfx is amazing. You can still watch it without being distracted. Just very few carefull eyes can catch something.Director Emmerich established a massive production and in my opinion He managed it highly succesfully. Music is huge orchestral composition which tailor-made for the movie. Somebody found the cast a little goofy at times but it isn't a problem for me, maybe I don't expect it to be a scary movie or some horror stuff, I've always enjoyed godzilla with some comedy in it.Sound effects are also great. and lastly Stages are very well-designed. when I compose this article it's imdb rating was 5.4 which is a total nonsense.
Imdb has to make a new category: the movies which have low rating you should definitely see...

Review title: sucks, sucks, sucks, sucks, ad infinitum
Review_body: You know a movie is bad when you start rooting for the monster (see "Jurassic Park 3"). It had bad everything, from acting to plot to sfx. Matthew Broderick runs like a girl. And Spielberg (in most of his films) did the whole open mouth look of awe to death, but we get even more of it here, at least they stole from a good director. The indestructible (almost) taxicab was such a leap of faith that, well, I can think of no adjectives to even barely describe it.
