If Ed Wood had a hundred million dollars this is what he would have made. Without a doubt a strong contender for worst movie ever. See it only if you have time to kill. Otherwise stay away--it sucks beyond anything, arrgghhh.

The graphics were brilliant. It's 2021 and it's still comparable to the technology used now. Every thing about this movie is very good. Not sure why it is so under rated. The people giving it 1 stars are the kind of people who skip the movie to end and doesn't know to enjoy it for what it is.

Review title: This film was made before I was born it was life changing.
Review_body: I watch this movie and got so bored but I still give it a 10 out of 10 because it was so boring honestly I could have died whilst watching this movie, at least they tried to blow things up which made me really happy because I love it when things blow up. At the end gorilla died with his baby's which was sad but all the army soldiers were dancing on Godzilla's body which was funny they was doing the L dance which is weird because that game came out either 2016 or 2015.

Japanese Godzilla cannot hold a candle to American version. Special effects and sound bytes are top notch. Maybe a little to graphic for small children. This is a must have movie for Home Theater enthusiasts. Way to go Hollywood. Godzilla purist's may be disappointed with the new and improved Lizard King, but I say to bad. Look at it this way it just may force Japan's movie makers to try and up the ante if they ever decide to resurrect their boy. I give the animators of this movie an "A+" grade for the seemingly real lifelike depiction of their monster. He beats the pants of the original muppet wanna be puppet reptile. I hope that the makers of this flick do decide to outdo themselves with a string of sequels of this new much more truer and believable version of this sci-fi classic.

Review title: It is not Godzilla we all love
Review_body: This is not godzilla. It's just giant velociraptor who is running in the city.

God, one of the best Directorial team-ups made this movie. They've accomplished in so many different movies. Why does this one disappoint me? The movie had so much potential to become a great movie. Yet... IT Didn't!!! Instead, what we have is poor acting and very long boring moments in between every battle. The only actors I enjoyed were Hank Azaria and Jean Reno. The whole thing with the nest was definitely an interesting point in the story and the action during that time was great, and then when Godzilla came back and saw his children dead was a heartfelt scene where you could sympathize with the creature. However Godzilla's death sucked balls!!!! NOT GOOD WAY FOR MONSTER TO DIE!!!

This is not a very good film, the story is weak, the acting is wooden and the fish are a plenty, in fact you may say there are a lot of them, and this is one thing the films delivers on.So if you like your giant monsters movies to have heart pumping action, suspense filled scenes, great acting and fantastic special effects, give this film a wide berth.If you like a lot of fish, then this film has fish, a lot of fish.Review - 4 fish down

The year is 1998... And it is EXCELLENT, that Roland was able to make this film with those magnificent special effects! The story line is simple from one side. But from other - it makes us to think about the world. About the creatures in it, about our mistakes...But there is one-e-e-e little thing that i can't understand =D All those buildings, streets that was destroyed - it can't be believable in real life, isn't it ? =D If you hadn't saw it - do it as quick as you can! 9/10 P.S. Sorry, if there are any mistakes in my English...

What were some of you expecting? Shakespeare? Tennesee Williams? Its a movie about a giant lizard in New York - just accept it for what it is! Its entertainment and no more - and on that level (at least for me) it works just fine! Its's not "realistic" enough? Again, how realistic is a giant lizard supposed to be? It's a FANTASY movie! Besides, I thought the special effects were pretty impressive! And its not as if the ORIGINAL Godzilla movies were good, with their actors in rubber suits and laughable, ridiculous "monsters" (gamera, mechagodzilla, etc etc)- the Godzilla in THIS movie was an animal, not a monster driven by a need to destroy things! I didn't think Matthew Broderick was bad at all - although I DID find Animal's girlfriend extremely irritating with her shrill voice! Really, I didn't think this movie was bad at all - no, its not a profound meaningful work or art, but then who expected it to be? It's an enjoyable diversion - that's all anyone should expect!

Review title: And settle for less? I think not.
Review_body: First off, you'll read lots of critiques ranging from people who are purists of the Gojira franchise to those with less expectations for a monster movie. I've read some reviews here that sound frustrated about purists not being satisfied. They want them to accept the movie for what it was. A special effects laden movie and nothing more.Well.. I'm going to say one word followed by reason. "NO"Gojira fans deserve much better for a movie that claimed itself to be the revolution of Godzilla just because of its use of amazing CGI.This movie bombed. Pure and simple. It sucked and you will have more agree to that than the otherwise. The film director took a beloved creature which was created in Japan based off of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima. Radioactive residue turning a lizard into a mutant giant monster.The sole idea here, was that the monster was basically created by our stupidity with warfare activities that took place a long time ago. Something that emerged from our wrong doings. A giant monster karma of a problem to put it in short words. This monster wasn't evil. But it had the instincts of an enraged creature seeking exploration of its surroundings and clashing with humans for the second time.The film, Godzilla 1985 (Gojira 1984 in japans aka Gojira Returns), pretty much successfully set that idea and created a very respected, inspiring and intense movie that was ahead of its own time. The 80s.This new American Godzilla film however, changed and denied 80% of the original creator's intention and turned our beloved monster into gargantuan mush.And for those who are saying "who cares, its just a monster movie", you're a disgrace to the G-fan base whether you care so or not. Therefore your sub-standard ideals about movie quality no longer hold weight to me.I'm the kind of person that pushes a job until it cant be pushed no more. I'm all about top notch quality. Not just visual quality, but EVERYTHING quality. Story had to be much better than this nonsense. It could have been good. Really good. But it really wasn't. It just wasn't. The special effects, amazing in its own respect to the artists behind them, did not aid the movies direction. The major disrespectful approach to change an iconic monster into a chicken legged giant iguana, really let a lot of fans down and with good reason as that thing just wasn't God'fricken'zilla.However... had the film been renamed to its actual now fan labeled name "Zilla", I would have not had been received as badly. Dropping any expectations and possibly even appreciating this movie only as a second rate monster movie. Which would probably have helped it in terms of reputation.And yes, I do understand that this monster is no longer called Godzilla in Japan either. It is now known ONLY as "Zilla" by the Japanese. It was so iffy, they couldn't take in what the American bought license did to their beloved monster. I mean, let's be honest. When the news first leaked out about an American release of Godzilla, we were all hyped up expecting that same powerful iconic nostalgic feeling we got in the 80's when Godzilla first hit Hollywood theaters. IT WAS HUGE NEWS!Thats why many including I, feel this movie was a let down. Quality is everything. As a creator myself, I live by those words. If you adapt to low quality or moderate quality and tell yourself "it was good"... then you will never taste the fruit of a truly great quality production. And Im not going to discuss the Japanese G movies as those were understandably being made on low budgets. What do you expect with little money. :/ But for an American film, I really expected something that would have embedded itself in my memories as well as the memories of our kids today. Sort of like what Godzilla 1985 was back then.Alas, not this time. My chime. And Im sticking to it.

Review title: I want my hour and a half back
Review_body: This was one of the worst movies I've ever seen. I can enjoy stupid movies when they are done well The Day After Tomorrow and Waterworld to name two, but this movie was a total waste of time. Between the technical inaccuracies, the physical impossibilities, and the improbable actions of the characters, I found myself the entire time thinking (and even speaking to myself) "this is a really bad movie, why am I still watching this".To be brutally honest, I prefer the old Japanese movies with a guy in a suit stepping on models. At least then the cheese is consistent.What are my complaints? I don't want to give anything away so as to be a spoiler, but let's just say the actions of the military personnel, the effect of the munitions, and the reactions of Godzilla are so ridiculous at one point I thought to myself, "the writers obviously didn't spend any time on research." And the dramatic pauses? Talk about ridiculous. "I'm about to be eaten, I'm just going to stand here and look curious." "I'm about to fall in a hole, I'm just going to stand and look dramatic." If I had to sum this movie up in one word fit for family consumption, blech!

and it made me hate this movie even more. Not that Godzilla could ever be Cloverfield; Godzilla requires back story and context whereas Cloverfield completely avoids both, but when it comes to sheer monster butt kicking, Cloverfield shows Roland Emmerich how it SHOULD have been done. WOW, did his version of "Godzilla" SUCK.I'm still mad about it... nearly 10 years later and I can still remember the abject disappointment I felt walking out of that theater. I was a Godzilla fan since I was probably 6. Watched the cartoon every Saturday morning (Godzookie!). Started getting into the TOHO movies when I was a teenager, then, THIS piece of crap hits. The CGI wasn't bad for it's time, but, like pretty much every Emmerich movie, the script and plot were ATROCIOUS. Too bad he didn't have the sense that J.J. Abrams has; make an awesome 35 story monster, then get the hell out of the way. Instead we got dialogue like this:NICKYou just left me without a phone call, a letter, nothing. All this time. Yeah, I guess I'm still a little mad.AUDREYThat was eight years ago. Some people change, you know.NICKMost people don't.AUDREYI'm sorry you feel that way.Audrey turns and walks away. Nick regrets his behavior and calls after her.NICKWait. I'm sorry. You're right. Eight years is a long time. Can I offer you a cup of tea? OH GOD... I think I'm going to get sick all over again... I don't remember who the actress was that played "Audrey" but I think this movie pretty much sunk her. Thankfully, Broderick's career survived. They can't all have "but I was Ferris Bueller" to fall back on.

This movie is awesome! It is the most realistic version of all the Godzilla movies that I have viewed. It really makes you think about what the world would be like if an incident such as this were to actually happen. How would our present-day government and military officials handle a situation of such gigantic proportions! Would they even believe that such a creature actually exists or would they prefer to keep everything hush-hush until it's too late? What would be their strategy to safely evacuate a large city such as New York or California, and how would they go about removing the threat? What I would really like to know is, if there is a equally realistic sequel to this one?

This movie (watched at home on my home cinema system) rocks. The actors are not the best you have ever seen, but Godzilla him (her)self steals the show. I don't care what others say about this film it's just a pure adranaline shot. It keeps you on the edge of your seat with the sound and visual effects. It's just great to hear Godzilla screaming in your surround speakers. About the acting part, not bad at al, the actors haven't got the best part in this movie but they are about average. I do like the humor in the movie. So if you want to enjoy yourself for 2 hours just rent the movie and enjoy, don't think, just watch it.

I don't understand yet why the product company did not create a second part of this film... some of us, (people who saw the movie) wished, at the end of it, that, in some way, it continues. The egg at the end of the story is a kind of misunderstanding end, that made that people like me, hated Godzilla only because it has not a second part... I now that Goszilla was a wasted of time and money, but the company did not think about there fans. I am very angry with answer in hands of the company which put his money in it. For me, it is a joke, it is not funny that i do not know what the story continues.Thank you very much!

Review title: This is how an action movie must be (almost)
Review_body: Emmerich must have thought, bigger is better ! Well in this movie it is. T-rex is for kids, Godzilla is here. If there was an Oscar to be given for the best CGI character, Godzilla would definitely have won it. An action movie should be about explosions,(gun)fights, pursuits and most importantly, a seemingly invincible hero. A plot or a difficult story just distracts you. (thats why they invented drama) This movie has it all, it is a thrill-ride that keeps you on the edge of your couch from the beginning to the end. Put your home theater set to the max and feel the movie almost like he is ravaging your own living room. The hero in this movie is of course Godzilla himself and in the end I really felt sorry for him. After all, he is not evil, he is just trying to survive. Unfortunately Emmerich made two mistakes: the first was not to erase the the whole whining role of Audrey Timmonds from the script, and the second was the casting of Broderick and Pitillo. Maria Pitillo rivals with Tea Leoni for the most annoying actress to walk the face of the earth. But hey, thats just a small part of this movie. Grab your popcorn but don't forget to chew now and then! 9/10

A fairly good story in search for a better story than the one they were given, but despite that, it's still pretty good. It's no ID4! The cast are great, and so is the rest of the cast. It is an extremely PC look at a rather un-PC time period.There's enough story, explosions, fights, drama, love, etc. to entertain you. Never gets too slow, but you do catch yourself thinking they could of cut 15 minutes from it and lose nothing! I would rather have had Godzila be more of a monster on the scale of Cloverfield though.Overall, I give the film a 4 out of 10

Review title: I was one of the fans this movie!
Review_body: I wonder why so many people criticize this movie very much. I have seen many science fiction films, and really happy, excited to see Gozilla. Attractive content, the acting is not bad. However, despite being released after a period of two parts of Jurassic Park, which had pretty good skills in creating dinosaurs like real life, then techniques in Gozilla still not perfect. I'm just not happy about this aspect, Gozilla somewhat rigid, less is realistic to make films, giving viewers can still feel something is not true in the Gozilla. Anyway, for the cinema in the late 20th century, this really is a film great entertainment for those who love adventure genre films, science fiction, and especially about dinosaurs like me.

Review title: Emmerich is made for this business!
Review_body: I just think that Godzilla is not ever boring at any point. Its one of these movies that is only meant to be for the people who know what to expect....and that is action, great special effects and awesome pictures and stunts. Just like Independence Day, which didn't really have a unique storyline either, this reminds me why I like going to the movies....Pure Excitement and adrenaline rush....one after another! The acting was suitable for a movie that focuses on a big monster. I just really liked the way Emmerich takes the size of this thing and makes us think about what it could do with a city like New York. It looks expensive and some funny lines here and there were to be found as well. So I really don't understand why it didn't do as expected because I thought that most of the American Audience would ask for movies like Godzilla, Independence Day and others. Very surprising and disappointing to me!

this is movie is pretty good.only thing is that they call this creature Godzilla.this is NOT GODZILLA!!!!this creatures name is Zilla.at 1st his name was American Godzilla.and 4 some reason,people call him GINO.but in 1993,toho gave tristars rights to make a Godzilla movie.at 1st they were gonna make a "GODZILLA" movie.heres the original script: HTTP://www.SCIFISCRIPTS.com/scripts/GODZILLA.TXT(just copy the link).i'll upload the URL that has the suit they were gonna use,put my computer is messing up(I HATE IT!!!!)put the producers and such all agreed that the original version was better.i give this movie 4/10and a lot of kaiju fans,(kaiju is giant monster in Japanese)hate this movie/monster cause its sometimes called godzilla

Review title: This is a critical review on the 1998 Godzilla remake directed by Roland Emmerich.
Review_body: In 1954, the film "Gojira" was released and became an instant classic spawning numerous sequels some of which became classics too. The 1998 American remake, however, just isn't that.Keep in mind that this is a review from my critic side and not my fan side.The story centers around a giant reptilian monster that was created by nuclear tests in French Polynesia. After attacking a Japanese cargo ship carrying fish in the Pacific Ocean, the creature somehow swims towards New York City of all places to make a nest. Now, it's up to Nick Tatopoulos and his friends to stop the monster.The story as you just read is just a typical monster plot, and the writers try way too hard to make this flick interesting by including "realistic science". What do I mean by this? Well, Godzilla is a mutated lizard specifically a marine iguana, but he doesn't look anything like the lizard he originally was. Another example is when the film explains that the monster is asexual which is absolutely absurd because a mutation caused by nuclear bombs does not include being asexual. I know about "suspension of disbelief", but there's only so much the audience can believe. If having ridiculous science talk isn't bad enough, "Godzilla" down-right steals scenes from "Jurassic Park" that this should have been called "Jurassic Park 3" or "Jurassic Park- Giant Dino".The characters are either bland, hateful, forgettable. The main character is Nick Tatopoulos, played by Matthew Broderick, who is the clichéd boring, dorky, socially awkward scientist who never are good main leads. I understand that Emmerich wants to make heroes from normal people, but they have to be interesting and/or likable. Tatopoulos is not likable. In fact, I don't know a thing about him. He's a bore, but what's worse than a boring character? A hateful character. The romantic interest Audrey Timmonds, played by Maria Pitillo, is a despicable, selfish character who I wanted Godzilla to eat so badly. Here an example on how she's hateful: She is talking to her New York stereotypical friend about her relationship with Nick, and her friend asks her how long they dated. Audrey said about 3 or 4 years, and this is what her friend said, "Girl, I'm surprised he didn't ask you to marry you." Then, Audrey says, "That's the thing. He did." There's nothing more we learn about their relationship expect that they get back together in the end. So, she wanted him to ask her but declined when he did. Why should I care about her? Also, she steals top secret information from Nick's tent when she knows she's not supposed to, and it was for her career as a news reporter. Additionally, after putting the information on the news, we see her crying while watching the news, but she's not crying because of what she did- we know this because we see her give a horribly acted and soulless apology to Nick prior- but because her report was stolen by her boss. What a selfish broad. The other characters aren't all that memorable outside the fact that they're just New York or French stereotypes giving us some tasteless stereotypical dialogue and jokes.Despite the poorly written characters, the actors do a decent job playing them. There's just nothing else to say about the acting. They did what they could and did okay.That is expect for Maria Pitillo who was just awful.The special effects when looked at a modern aspect are bad, but in the context of 1998, they're from okay especially when you compare the effects of "Godzilla" to the film that it strongly plagiarizes, "Jurassic Park". One scene from "Godzilla" that might have looked good in '98 but looks really bad today is the footstep scene shown in all of the trailers and commercials where Godzilla's foot slams down and raises back up. However, some effects still look really good which include any particle effects, and, my favorite shot, when Godzilla jumps over the bridge to dive into the Hudson River. That shot still looks really impressive.Now, let's talk about the monster Godzilla. I will not be judging this creature to the original, but instead on how he stands on his own which is pathetic. One of the main problems with him is that he's not scary or endearing. If you're going to do a monster film, you have to do one or the other, and this monster fails trying to do either one. He's not enduring because you don't see any reason why we the audience should care about him, and he's not scary because not only does he not look scary, he's a coward and a wimp. The only reason he stays alive as much as he does in the film is because the military sucks at hitting him. Additionally, we never see him showing why he's a force to be reckoned with. He's constantly running away. Bottom line, this is one of the worst monsters put on film.Overall, "Godzilla" is a bad film, but there are a few good things in it. Outside of the monster and Audrey, nothing in the film can be heavily criticized or hated for. This is one of those movies where if you "turn off" your brain and just put it on to kill some time, this film would be fine to put on, or if you want to watch a movie but don't care what it is, "Godzilla" would be alright to watch. Now, I can't hate on this film too much because there is a good or even great monster film in here but just not fully realized, and "The Word to Sum It" best explains it best.The Word to Sum It: stale. This flick feels that everything was rushed and not fleshed out.IMDb Rating: 4/10 Personal Rating: 2/5 Rotten Tomatoes Rating: 2.5/5

Let me first start with telling all you morons why this movie got bad reviews. There is one reason. The Fu**ing title! This would, in fact be a great movie if it had no affiliation with the big G! If you compare the original Godzilla with this anorexic iguana thing, you will realize that they are two completely different entities. S**t! The two fight each other in Final Wars! This movie has low ratings because it was reviewed by legitimate Godzilla fans! You random movie watchers who gave it a good review have obviously never even seen one of the original G films. Watch the real films and watch this one again and you will see the difference. That is all.

Review title: Big Lizard makes babies and they all meet Ferris Bueller
Review_body: So it's Friday night & I'm going through the DVD collection and a found this wonderful little gem of a film that I've never seen before. All I can say is thank goodness for the scan button on the remote. I've never seen money wasted so much as in this 2+ hour piece of s***! Fast forward to the end, those last few seconds, I've never laughed so hard in my life. I still don't know how this DVD got in my collection but it's going out with the trash in the morning.Can someone tell me where I can be reimbursed? I hate to fill our landfills with even more trash. I think...peace ya'll GODZILLA

I have seen it again yesterday with my kids and it is wonderful. Some of the films I liked most I didn't like at the beginning. I walk out of Tarzan The Ape Man because the gorillas were unrealistic, and now I think that that movie is adorable. So I recommend to the all those beautiful people who didn't like Godzilla to look it just for once and without prejudice.
The Twin Towers are filmed in this movie encapturing a beautiful eerieness.

Anyone remember the trailer for Godzilla ? Godzilla's foot smashes a T-Rex skeleton on exhibition in a museum. This was at a time when we weren't quite sure if Roland Emmerich had talent. ID4 was cheesy but no doubt had its moments. 15 years later we know for sure that he is one of the worst directors ever to have made it to Hollywood. Flicking through his works that were yet to come and insult our intelligence, I am now sure that Emmerich is the one big (not great!) Hollywood director to even make Michael Bay look "maybe not quite as bad". Comparing Godzilla to Jurassic Park fits quite nicely as both film makers had the ambition of creating a fun and exciting roller-coaster ride of a film. But JP was about ideas. It had some profundity to it where Godzilla was merely about size and discarded the actual appeal of the original. Spielberg was able to create suspense and tension. In JP he refined it to perfection. The T Rex was beautifully designed and somewhat had the weight of a believable entity. Godzilla's design was ridiculously puberty-boyish, had no weight, didn't scare. The set pieces were awful. The logic gaps were a disgrace. Matthew Broderick was a bad cast. The reporter's behavior was as non-sequitur as that of a schizophrenic idiot. And then the rain... Godzilla's dead.. Broderick waddles up to its carcass and now we seem to be supposed to feel sorry for this misunderstood creature.. I mean it just wanted to destroy the city and kill us all :( I can't understand how anyone could ever like or even appreciate this peace of cinematic horse.. manure. I hate the fact that I watched it all the way through. I'll never be able to get that time back.. ever.Conclusion: Jurassic Park relates to Godzilla like Spielberg relates to Emmerich or like Marilyn Monroe relates to Paris Hilton or like Dolphins relate to Leeches. :)

I loved this movie. It's so cool. Can't get enough!!!! The actors are so excellent, giving life for the characters. The director knows to do destructions scenes, using the famous buildings of N.Y. I hope that have a sequel, because it deserves! Maria is so fantastic in this movie and Matthew Broderick too. Hank is the funny soul of this movie.Jean Reno shows that he is an excellent action actor. The story shows to the new generation what is Godzilla. This is one of the best Hollywood's movie!!
The story is flat and characters act stupididly (including godzilla)Due to the massive use of (indeed well done) special effects, this movie lacks any b-movie qualities.

Simply the worst Godzilla movie ever made. There isn't a whole lot to say about it other than the entire movie was a reach at best. The last half hour of the movie is terrible - almost unwatchable. What a dismal effort.
I love that he is unique from the other Godzillas. I love that he is the only Godzilla that walks scientifically correct. i love that it could be an actual thing.

The overall view of This movie by film critics and Godzilla purists is that it is bad. Very bad. It sounds like this movie was almost unwatchable by the world. But to a twelve year old boy with no idea about previous Godzilla films living in the middle of upstate NY in 1998, this film was great! Seeing this in theaters was a fun experience as a kid. Pretty sure since they made an animated series and plenty of Godzilla toys and figures and merchandise that this movie was made for kids like me. As an adult rewatching I can see the things that people criticize about the film but that just makes it funny. Like understanding an adult joke in a kids movie once you're older. Super inappropriate but another sign of how times have changed. I would definitely recommend this movie for for older kids and adults looking for a laugh or to unwind. I would not recommend this to people studying film or people who feel strongly about the lore of Godzilla.

this is a nice movie,why do certain people have to keep lambasting it? in this movie,godzilla proves her agility by dodging many helicopters and turning the tables by destroying them one by one effortlessly.This film also makes me realize how overly selfish human beings are as they only are concerned about protecting their own interests and mistaking godzilla in this movie for some monster.Hello,those guys have got it totally wrong!this is just a giant iguana,an animal that is trying to get along in the human world.Godzilla in this movie,in my point of view,is living according to the laws of nature.She sought food,shelter and a nesting place.The motherly love and sorrow that was in godzilla was felt strongly when she was seen weeping over her dead babies and nuzzling their remains.Just look at how she nourished her 200 odd children with enough food and shelter.Furthermore,it really grieves me to see godzilla being killed at the end of the movie in such a ruthless manner when she barely recovered from the trauma of losing her loved ones.We,as the most intelligent and also the dominant species on Earth,should use our knowledge and try to befriend this giant iguana like how zoo trainers befriend animals,not kill whatever species that we consider inferior or threatening just because of their looks.This is plain murder!Anyway for the F-18 pilots in this movie,shame on them for using military armaments against a defenceless lady like godzilla who just witnessed her kids' funeral!Although this is only a movie,sensible people should be able to read between the lines in this senseless bicker of Man with a potentially harmless creature.Anyway,Godzilla rawks!

Review title: What's the problem? This is a good monster movie. (SPOILERS!)
Review_body:
Okay, I understand the Godzilla purists who enshrine Ishuri Honda's masterpiece of post world war two commentary of the effects of the first atomic bombs dropped on Japan. The 1954 film is a classic in film history that started a genre that continues today. Some of the sequels also merit that respect, most recently, Shin Godzilla which tackles the problems of government bureaucracy during a crisis.Perhaps the biggest mistake that Centroplis Pictures made with this film was paying the millions of dollars that they did to Toho Limited in order to use the Godzilla name. They could have made it a remake of 1953's Warner Brothers classic, The Beast From 20,000 Fathoms which was released a year prior to Godzilla and inspired Toho to make a box office success, not just a post war statement.Just like you know what you're in for with a Michael Bay film, the same can be said with director Roland Emerich and producer Dean Devlin who reimagined The War of the Worlds with their first blockbuster, Independence Day. This is a fun popcorn movie with a great cast including Mathew Broderick, Hank Azeria and Jean Reno whose comedic timing is pretty darn good considering the monsters that wreck havoc on New York City. Emmerich continues to destroy landmarks in his trademark fashion including the Fulton Fish Market, the Brooklyn Bridge and Madison Square Garden.Once again Godzilla is the consequence of nuclear testing during the 1950s but not American. France's nuclear testing has resulted in the monster this time and Jean Reno leads an undercover JSOC team to stop the beast. The French inclusion provides some wonderful humor from American coffee and donuts to Reno imitating Elvis when getting past American military security. Another fun thing that you might miss is that everyone in Reno's command first name is Jean except Reno, whose name is Phillipe.Matthew Broderick brings his charisma similar to his performances in Ferris Bueller, Wargames and Biloxi Blues as a scientist who is researching the growth of earthworms as the result of nuclear contamination when he is drafted to help in the investigation of a mysterious radioactive creature that is sinking ships. He pulls off the role with humour, intelligence and wonder. Hank Azaria is hilarious as Animal, a New York news station cameraman who is more afraid of his wife, played by Arribella Field than he is of Godzilla. Director Emmerich also takes a major jab at film critics Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert who blasted his first disaster epic, ID4, one of the first summer mega blockbusters. The characters of Mayor Ebert and his aide Gene are funny enough but even more so when you know why they are portrayed. Perhaps the weakest point of the film is the love connection between Broderick and his long lost love Audrey who is an aspiring television reporter played by Maria Patillo but it's not awful and I don't watch movies like this for deep romantic moments anyway.
Just like the original this Godzilla is a destructive monster. He/she is not the protector of man or the wonderful friend of little children and he/she brings a destructive potential that, if brought to fruition, could devastate the Americas.If it makes you feel better don't call this Godzilla even though it evidently followed the strict criteria that Toho demanded for a movie using the Godzilla name. The Monsterverse that brought us the last 2 American Godzilla movies also had to comply with distinct Toho Limited rules. Instead get some popcorn, sit down turn up the volume and enjoy a reality good, very humorous Roland Emmerich/Dean Devlin blow a lot of stuff monster movie.

Showed this movie to my girlfriend who has never seen any Jurassic Park/Dinosaur movies ever and she couldn't believe this movie was made in 1998. Her unbiased opinion was that she found the movie to be pretty good. I Appreciate the work that has been put in to make the creatures look so real, the SFX were stunning and the storyline wasn't half bad either. Too bad there wasn't an official sequel to it but a classic in my book, dare I say it better than Jurassic Park? Nevertheless, see this movie regardless of the critics and for your love of dinosaurs. I rate this movie 9/10 on the bases of SFX alone.

Review title: Godzilla - has it's moments and flaws as well
Review_body: This is one movie which got more criticism than it's really deserved. I agree, it has some flaws, but don't forget that it's a popcorn movie. If you want to be educated by watching a movie, then go somewhere else. All Emmerich's movies meant for entertainment, and they are not for intellectuals and perfectionists. As an average movie-goer, I have felt entertained though having some problem with its run-time. I have seen people comparing this with some Japanese Godzilla movies, and making negative remarks. Honestly, i feel that Japanese Godzilla movies look pathetic, and make no-sense at all. Technically, American Godzilla is far superior to them. Even, i don't have a problem with characters; you can see these kinds of things in every superhero/sci-fi/disaster movies. Don't expect every movie to be a Jurassic park; avatar, the dark knight etc. just enjoy these kinds of movies over a weekend with your family.

I can't think of another movie with more non stop action than this movie. I came in expecting great action and special affects and it actually exceeded my expectations. Yes the acting was terrible, but who actually came in to this looking for great performances. It's just a great action movie to sit back and enjoy. It's also the best movie to watch with surround sound. Other than Michael Bay flicks this has to be the best way to test out your sound. I've actually gotten complaints whenever I watch this to turn it down but how can you when your watching an Emmerich movie. Of all of his movies this one is my favorite. I really wish this movie had done better so they'd make another one but I don't think its going to happen.

The first time I watched this film, it was way back in 1998, when it just got released. I have little memory of it after that, but boy, it had a SUPERB soundtrack! It was the talk of the town Now that i'm watching it for the 2nd time, wow did it blow my mind! 2 words, AWE-SOME!!!! The giant iguana was made more realistic than some of the King Kong's (2006), Spiderman's or Harry Potter's shots. It was 1998, 8 yrs ago!! & roland Emmerich, man, he does some wonders sometimes. Just take a look at ID4, Day after Tomorrow, & i'm a big fan of expensive CGI effects! My only complaint would be, there should be *at least* an A-list actor in a big-budgeted movie. I think that contributes partially to a b.o success, more or less

Everyone lighten up. This was a fun movie. Godzilla with humor so what. I get the humor I'm a New Yorker (Brooklyn). I get the accents & NY attitude in the film. I enjoyed it. Madison Square Garden gets blown up!! Loved it.

OK, this Movies isn't as bad as its reputation.The thing for me is, it's not a Godzilla movie. It may be a decent monster movie, but not a Godzilla movie. It misses VERY IMPORTANT trademarks.E.g. the monster doesn't really breath atomic fire. Where are the Stegosaurus spikes? The worst thing is that it's getting killed by the military. That never happened in any of the movies before. Godzilla is pretty much immortal. Only another Monster has a chance against Godzilla.It's not a complaint about the plot or the CG-effects in General. This movie just does not have the Godzilla feeling. The 2014 version did a way better job.If the movie wasn't "Godzilla in the name only" it would have been decent.

Review title: The Perfect Action Godzilla Movie For Its Time
Review_body: I wonder why so many people did not give this movie its proper merit in terms of some great Special Effects, Action, the Monster Godzilla itself and the good acting by Matthew Broderick and supportive casts. When I watched this movie in 1998, I watched it as a standalone Godzilla movie, not relating it to the Godzilla comic books or cartoons... and to my surprised it was great for its year of release, surpassing the special effects i expected to see.When I watched new Godzilla 2014 movie, it was as if I'm watching a cartoon movie again at the cine. And... and.. Godzilla was just the supporting cast in the new movie lol :P At least I expected 45 min of Godzilla out of a 1hr45 min. I did not see a full close view of Godzilla itself.Godzilla 98 seems way higher quality special effects and better disaster movie than the 2014 movie.In terms of entertainment I give it an easy 9.5/10

Review title: "The French save the day, and we don't like that".
Review_body: That's the only reason. The French save the world. That's the only reason almost all people - in USA, I must say - hate this movie.In despite of the people searching for sci-fi in a movie named "Godzilla", of the fans of the Japanese movies (Heavens!), of all the past times the duo Emmerich-Devlin had ruined a not-bad-but-remake-of-an-old-idea (i.e. almost all their past movies) this one it's not so bad, guys. But that is not the point. It's about the "masterpiece" of Dean Devlin and Roland Emmerich.The aforementioned duo have spent last years delighting us with some remakes and the like of sci-fi films or ideas (Years ago a young jury at a Cinema Festival for the young here in my country voted "Joey" as best movie, while the real jury voted, more accordingly, "My Life as a Dog". If you want to know for sure Emmerich's opinion about his favorite film, pay attention to the Star Wars DVD Trilogy extras(1)).The first real "success" of the duo was "Stargate", which is nothing but "Flash Gordon" with the Army around. An almost decent movie, not much expensive (by Hollywood standards) and with a script capable of solve the whole crisis in a hurry that would make George Lucas face turn red in envy. We arrive, we discover this Egyptian demigod (Ra!), we killed him and destroy his superior technology and his powerful pyramid-vessel, thanks for everything, next time will stay a bit longer. Pathetic (the TV series is terribly boring. Sorry).And then came the martians (whatever). And this, my friends, is your idea of a good spectacle. In that time was fun to see the White House blowing up in a zillion fragments, and your sympathetic army saving the entire world by destroying a whole technologically superior civilization (I'm sorry, not too advanced after all; 50 years and they use the same fighters-computers, as we see in the 51 area sequence), I repeat, an entire civilization (as the president reads in the mind of the "martian", remember? They traveled all at once as friends, like the Indians in an old Spanish joke :D) destroyed in 2 days, at time for the 4th of July. You know, here in Europe we laughed deeply at cinemas with the speech of the president. And cheered, too.And then came this Godzilla flick, which is, I'm sorry again, the best movie this German-americanized-in-more-than-one-way duo has ever made.I can remember that in that time, France was really doing nuclear tests in Moruroa (or was Mururoa?). This was the perfect starting point. Given the love this two, Devlin & Emmerich, feel for their land of adoption, USA couldn't at all be responsible for the needed nuclear explosion that, traditionally, unleashed the beast, oh, no. Not the only country who has ever used the bomb against civilian targets, making later the role of victims in "The Day After"."But ¿what the politics have to do with a movie like this?". Since ALL the cinema is politics, everything. And in this very case, the most. This is a film in the "tradition" which gave fame and fortune to Emmerich-Devlin: an old idea modernized, for all audiences (meaning this you can save the dog but not the woman in certain situations, I suppose), a constant rip of classics (it was "Lawrence of Arabia" in Stargate), like the galactic trench run of the helicopters after the lizard in the middle of NY among other "homages" (not to mention "Jurassic Park", another "masterpiece") and with nerd-but-nice scientist and too-much-nice army men (not to forget the real heroes, the french secret service) who save the day and everything.At this point I want to call your attention to the other duo, with much more artistic sense than the first one, responsible of the script; I mean the Ted Elliot-Terry Rossio tandem, writers of some very good blockbuster movies like "The Mask of Zorro", "Aladdin", "Pirates of the Caribbean - Episode I :D" and others. I bet my neck about the fact that, having in mind what the first team can do, the best ideas in this movie are the second's: the french not only creating the monster (only an animal hungry for fish!) but in the end destroying it (while the army destroys the luckily evacuated city; luckily for the MPAA and the rating of the film), the origin of the name of the creature and the joke about the Americanization of the original name-film, from "Gojira" to "Godzilla", and fortunately, the US army dying as idiots and destroying NY (is a right-wing classic topic to despise the media, so that's another very different thing, more to the likes of Emmerich-Devlin). About the fact that the french agent's names are "Jean-Claude", "Jean Patrick" and "Jean-Philippe", the "bad" news chief is "Caiman" and the "good" cameraman is "Animal", I can't possibly imagine who had the idea.The real thing is that the French save the world, man. The Army almost destroy New York. That is no good, right?Like another American hero would say, I have nothing more to say about this. And sorry for my mad engrish.(1) In Roland Emmerich's own words "My friends in school liked Fassbinder, and I liked Star Wars", or something like that.

I was there when people were seeing it in theaters, people were enjoying it and telling other people to go see it, the vast majority of people didn't walk out and say, "This was certifiable garbage". - Critic 2021It won a lot of awards and it sold a lot of tickets, I would argue this is the reason so many people watch/know Godzilla today. Before 1998 it was just an old monster movie mostly cult fans cared about (at least in my part of the world).I can't say it's flawless or has everything (no film does). It's a monster/disaster film. It doesn't have monster's battling the whole time, quite frankly it was more believable than the newer one with mothra, and had better characters. (Not that the newer one doesn't have advantages).In all, watch the film if you are interested, it may not be as true to the source material (I don't know, nor have I ever cared to) but so many people these days say it's bad just because that has become the expected perspective. Or maybe modern critics can only stand out by bashing formerly popular films?

this was my first Godzilla movie i ever seen. the special effects i thought were good, the plot i thought was fine nothing great or really bad either way there, the soundtrack i personally really liked, i still even had the ost soundtrack on cd in my cd library that i play on occasion. the design of this new and improved/updated Godzilla i thought was the best aspect of the movie, he was apparently redesigned from the original movies and i thought he looked better overall in this incarnation. they made Godzilla look more lizard like and more sleek or nibble is the proper work to describe him, he was not some huge bulky beast that seemed to struggle to walk around in a effective manner.

Review title: I liked this Godzilla movie the best out of all of them!
Review_body: I just recently watched this movie for the first time. I'm not usually into watching big "monster" movies but I thoroughly enjoyed this one! It has such a good sense of humor and the acting was for the most part quite good. I enjoyed this version of Godzilla more than the 2014 one. I've viewed other movies I really enjoyed and found out later they have a low rating so don't automatically not watch a film because it has a low rating. Although I will admit that most movies with a really low rating deserve it. I do base whether I am going to view the whole film or not on how good the acting is. If that's not in place then I switch to something else. I also liked the actual monster; I thought he was "relatable".

Review title: For all the people who liked this..
Review_body: This movie is not Godzilla. On its own, the effects are really good and the story is alright, but the acting is still pretty bad. Now you may be thinking, "you're just a Godzilla fanboy! It says it in your username!" Well, I am, but just watch one of the original films and you can easily see the comparison. The atomic breath, the size, the stance. But I'm here for the review. Basically, they chase Zilla around New York until he gets stuck in the Golden Gate bridge and is SHOT DOWN BY Missiles. If you've seen the original and like the original, you might enjoy this, but not as a Godzilla film. As you may know, you cannot kill Godzilla with missiles. You can only TRY to CONTAIN him. I'm not saying that the original Godzilla films were better, but just because it was made in America doesn't make one of the best! I mean, I'm just criticizing this, but don't get butt hurt when others have other opinions. In my eyes though, this is the worst "Godzilla" movie I've ever seen.

Review title: A particular brand of comedy that many don't get
Review_body: This is a fun movie. It pays tribute to the original series in that it's so far-fetched that it ends up being funny. This is what Godzilla has always been about, and the 1998 remake pays homage to this aspect of comedy.*** spoiler ***.The best example is when they have just destroyed all the eggs and are then discovered by an angry mother Godzilla. At this point - they stand around looking at each other and say "what do we do now?" And the reply - "running would be a good idea!" at which point they all run screaming...

I think people need to get there head out their butts and lighten up. Why is this "hated* so much? Oh wait the design of monster is different from then original (which I thought was creative and actually scary compared the orginal) and "bad acting and the plot doesn't make sense" get off your high horse. I watched this movie when I was about 5. I watched it lastnight and I'm 22 by the way, and I was still scared and on edge as to what happened next even though I already seen it. I mean what exactly were you hoping for? I mean, the original black and white films is just Godzilla walking around the city destroying and everything. If you are actually rooting for Godzilla in this movie uh, I think that's what it wants you to so people humans are NOT always the "good guys".

Some friends of mine were discussing why they didn't like some movies. They complained about people being morons to see that kind of crap! Well apparently they saw those movies too so I take it they're morons too? Hehe.. And c'mon.. Movies are an escape from reality for an hour or two.. Do you expect everything to be "realistic"?It reminds me of when I saw Godzilla (1998).. There was a guy in front of me with his (never to be his) girlfriend, on what I assume was their first (and hopefully last) date. He complained and moaned about how unrealistic this piece of crap was. Yes, I do agree; a big lizard eating New York is as silly as believing that the World trade centers (and building 7) went down without controlled demolitions (but that's another story)..But I couldn't help my self from mocking him on the way out as he continued to complain to the poor girl about how unrealistic it was by adding: "For an example, do you really think Godzilla could dodge those missiles..?"Let me get this right.. He accepts that a lizard mutates from nuclear experiments. He believes that it swam to New York. He accepts that she laid eggs even though there was no Mr. Godzilla. He also could cope with the friggin' thing running around and eat chunks of the Big Apple.. But when she dodges some missiles he reacts..!? Unbelievable..So when you see a movie, don't believe it, enjoy it!

Billed as one of the biggest summer blockbuster's ever, this movie fell short in just about every category. It is no wonder the previews showed nothing of the creature and revealed none of the story. If Godzilla fans had known that 'Godzilla' would turn out to look and act like he does in this movie, nobody would have gone to see it. This creature does not look like Godzilla in the least, and that's not even the worst part! He ACTS nothing like Godzilla, does not trample buildings, does not run towards a battle, and is a big coward. It is no wonder that Godzilla fans have taken to calling this creature G.I.N.O. (Godzilla in Name Only). The one highlight of the movie is Jean Reno. Oh, and the title sequence isn't bad either. This movie may single-handedly killed off any chance of a good film maker ever working on an American big-budget Godzilla film.
